PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 October, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak with respect to the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . I wish to put on record a number of factors. Firstly, the opposition does not have a problem with this bill.
—Does or does not?

—Does not. We believe this bill amends the Broadcasting Services Act to give effect to some decisions announced by the government with respect to X‐ and R‐rated programs on narrowcasting services. They were measures that were announced in April 1997 by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), as well as the Attorney‐General (Mr Daryl Williams).

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, X‐ and R‐rated programming is banned on subscription broadcasting services and on free to air services. However, with respect to narrowcasting services, our understanding is that those services limited in availability or appeal are not prevented from providing X‐ and R‐rated programming. That, of course, is certain narrowcasting services.

We are also finding that, increasingly, pay TV companies are offering extra channels of specialised programming, and doing so through this broadening range of narrowcasting services. Amongst those channels we have companies which do have and do want to broadcast explicitly sexual material, which mainstream television free to air services are prohibited from showing.

That has raised a policy issue for all sides of the parliament. The government tackled it in April this year, and the opposition I think made it clear at the time that we had no problems with the government's announced direction. The government decided to amend the Broadcasting Services Act to prohibit programs that have been refused classification, or which had been classified as X on subscription television narrowcasting services and also on open free to air narrowcasting services.

The government also decided to apply to open narrowcasting services the same restrictions regarding R‐rated programs as currently apply to commercial TV broadcasting services. These include such things as modification of R‐rated films to comply with the previous adults only classification, and restrictions as to what hours during which M and MA material may be broadcast.

The interesting aspect of the government's decision was with respect to R‐rated material on subscription television narrowcasting services. The opposition announced at the time that it would also support that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —This then raises the second part of what I wanted to say this morning. We were asked just a few days ago whether we had any problems with the cut‐off being lifted with respect to this legislation. We agreed to that. Given the government's need to try and get some legislation through before Christmas—and recognising that this legislation was such that we, on this side, did not have a major policy difference with it—we agreed to that. But we are, I must say, quite surprised to find that, less than 24 hours after such request was made to us, this legislation was listed for debate yesterday afternoon. We did not get to it yesterday afternoon—it was to be first debated yesterday, but workplace relations intervened—but it was curious that this bill was listed so quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The other curious aspect of the government's announcement was the way the government tried to portray its decision as something new, something radical and something which—as announced at the time by the Attorney‐General—showed that the government was tough on X‐rated and R‐rated programming which may involve sexually explicit material. The truth of the matter is that, despite the spin in the Attorney‐General's statement, despite the spin in the joint ministerial statement and despite the backgrounding of the media, very little had changed in the context of the whole decision. That needs to be placed on the record as well.

The public, to a certain extent, was conned. The public was conned deliberately by the ministers and, as a consequence, families in Australia thought, through the spin doctors, that the government had intervened to remove from the airwaves certain material. So we do not see the government really acting with totally clean hands on this issue. But, as I said at the outset, with respect to the fundamentals of the decision—as I think is widely known—we do not have a policy problem with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have heard from the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1997 seeks to amend the Broadcasting Services Act so that the prohibition in relation to the broadcasting of programs that have been either refused classification—and, of course, the Democrats agree that programs that have been refused classification should not be shown on broadcast, narrowcast, free to air or any television program—or those that have been classified as X, which relates to commercial television and subscription television broadcasters, will now also apply to open narrowcasting services or a subscription television narrowcasting service. The bill seeks to apply not only to X‐rated material but also to those programs which have received an R rating by the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

SPEECH.PARA: We find it quite fascinating that the government has introduced this legislation. The Broadcasting Services Act distinguishes between broadcasting services—those programs intended to appeal to the general public—and narrowcasting services. Those are the programs whose reception is limited through specialised program appeal or is restricted in some other way. Currently, material rated X and R is prohibited on free to air commercial television broadcasting services and on subscription television broadcasting services, but there are no such restrictions on narrowcasting services.

The government stated that there is widespread community concern about X‐rated material on television narrowcasting services. I have received very little correspondence in my office about this matter. I tend to believe that, in fact, it is something to do with the government internally—particularly the Lyons Forum—which has been pressing for a legislative solution to the broadcasting of X‐ and R‐rated material.

The government have also decided that open narrowcasting services should be subject to the same level of regulation in respect of R‐rated programs as is applied to commercial broadcasting services. The reason they give for this decision is that children can readily access open narrowcasting services. Firstly, I do not think the government are giving enough credit to those many hundreds of thousands of responsible parents who, themselves, can police their children and supervise viewing habits. Secondly, they discount the fact that much of this material is available in any video hire store, and the material that goes onto this channel that is not available in a video hire store is available through the mail from the ACT.

This bill is highly interventionist, and it was drafted by a non‐interventionist government—or that is what they tell us they are. Let me remind the Senate of the current provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act. At section 123(1), it says:

It is the intention of the Parliament that radio and television industry groups . . . develop, in consultation with the ABA . . . codes of practice that are to be applicable to the broadcasting operations of each of those sections of the industry.

ASTRA—the Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association—has recently developed, through extensive consultation, codes of practice which relate to the broadcasting of X‐ and R‐rated material. These codes have been registered with the ABA, as is required under the act.

BREAK.PARA: Further, the ABA, as the industry regulator, is required under the act to review the operation of subsection 123(3A) to determine whether this subsection is in accordance with community standards. The report of the ABA, together with any recommendations, is to be tabled by the minister in both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days of receiving those recommendations. That is a very important issue, and perhaps the minister can tell us where that report is.

This legislation pre‐judges the ABA's review. This legislation assumes that the community standards have changed and that the act now needs amendment. But how can we know this when the minister has not reported to parliament and when we have not seen the report?

The issue then is not about the need to further regulate an industry which the government is assuming should act like free to air broadcasters when, clearly, its establishment was to provide broadcasting services directed to particular audiences wanting access to programs which the free to air broadcasters could not provide but which, in this case, could be provided by going to the video store. And, since the codes deal with all the matters raised in the bill in identical terms, the issue is about one of perceived compliance of the industry by the government to those codes of practice. The minister should provide the ABA's report immediately so the parliament can realistically and properly determine the need for amending legislation—before this amending legislation is voted on—and determine its needs in the context of current and future technological developments: cable, satellite and other technologies.

The Democrats oppose the restriction of material to adults that would be generally acceptable to responsible adults. Further, if that material is granted classification by the Office of Film and Literature Classification, then, arguably, there is no need to subject that material to further censorship and to further regulation across narrowcasting services—especially when those services offer filtering and other blocking devices.

The Democrats support an independent complaints handling body which is adequately resourced, has powers to investigate complaints and is empowered to enforce its decisions, and we also support the codes of practice. In relation to codes of practice, the Australian Democrats believe that codes of practice should be enforceable and should be overseen by an independent body which is adequately resourced, has powers to investigate complaints and is empowered to enforce its decisions.

I am disappointed in the position on this matter of the opposition, who have agreed to pass this legislation on the basis of previous party policy. Certainly, from what I can gather, the industry was not consulted by either of the major parties on this, and that is hardly the way to develop sound policy, or particularly, good law.

The industry now faces having to amend its newly registered codes of practice and to negotiate those again—right from scratch—through the ABA. That is after the very extensive consultation process with the industry, the public and regulatory agencies over the last two years, which resulted in the recently registered codes of practice. Having worked long and hard to secure an agreed outcome on these issues related to violence in the media, as outlined in section 123(3) of the Broadcasting Services Act, the industry and the ABA now have—or at least had—a common understanding of what was required of everyone.

This bill puts into motion a process that will undermine the codes before they have even had the opportunity to operate and before a review process was undertaken to determine their effectiveness. The Democrats are opposed to the bill. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to say anything in the debate at the second reading stage because it is my intention to ask the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) a number of questions in the committee stage. I hope the minister will be able to respond on behalf of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions in the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 go some way towards overcoming a problem which was created by the ABA itself and which was quite contrary to the legislative intent of amendments that went into the Broadcasting Services Act and were supposed to have been upheld. But I will be asking those questions of the minister and I hope to get some response from him.

The only reason I am standing here is to make the comment that I was quite surprised by the previous contribution made by Senator Bourne. It shows that Senator Bourne, who was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, has somehow or other changed her view as described in the various reports. I must say that I did not expect to have to respond as such. Suffice to say that, in Part 1 of the Report on R‐rated material on pay TV, part (1) of the recommendations that were made by the Senate select committee reads as follows:
(1) The Committee, having regard to the following matters:
(i) the community's concerns about the levels of violence in the media, especially depictions of sexual violence, and of realistic and degrading, demeaning or exploitative sexual material;
(ii) the contradictory views expressed about the effects of such depictions on attitudes and anti‐social behaviour;
(iii) the lack of clarity of the R classification which permits an excessively broad range of material to be permitted within its definition;

PARA.TAB: recommends that R‐rated material be not permitted on pay TV.

SPEECH.PARA: It recommends that R‐rated material not be permitted on pay TV. In the situation before us it appears that the Democrats have now sold out to the industry, including the porn industry.
Senator Bourne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can respond to that in the committee stage, which is in about five minutes.
—Thank you, Brian. That is very kind of you!
—Order! Senator Bourne, you have had your chance.

—I am not saying something that you cannot respond to. I would be very happy to see how you respond to it, and to see how you respond to a valid accusation that the Democrats, because of what they are doing, are facilitating the spread of hard‐core porn through pay TV. Indeed, they are not only spreading hard‐core porn through pay TV but also spreading niche violent films through pay TV. You can respond to that very shortly. In fact, I will sit down and you can respond immediately the minister finishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not canvass all the arguments because I think they have already been traversed, and they will be again in the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Harradine is probably referring to the first report on R‐rated material on pay TV where the committee recommended that R‐rated material be not permitted. Senator Bourne was, of course, a member of that committee that always assumed that X would remain banned on pay TV, and went further to a position beyond which the government is not able to go. I think Senator Harradine is also referring to part 2 of the report, which similarly recommended that measures be taken to prevent the broadcasting of X‐ and R‐rated material on pay TV. The membership of that committee included Senator Woodley from the Democrats.

I think Senator Harradine is simply making the point that the Democrats seem to have made a pretty monumental backflip on all this. No doubt Senator Bourne will have the opportunity to deal with these matters later.

As far the ABA report is concerned, I am not sure to which one Senator Bourne is referring because there have been a number. But, if it is the one in relation to the Broadcasting Services Act, my advice is that that really only relates to planning and does not deal with these issues. Obviously these issues have to be assessed, taking into account the report of the Senate select committee and the other sources of material that are available to all politicians—not just lobbying by the industry. I do not recall ever being lobbied by people like Eros; I think they have stayed well clear of me. Certainly we have taken this issue through all the various processes of government to arrive at the position which has now been incorporated in the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond to a couple of things that have been said. First of all, the original report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies, to which both Senator Harradine and the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) have referred, was one which was talking about pay TV broadcasts, subscription television services, and not the narrowcast television services which are only to apply to small sections of the community—or at least that is my understanding of it. I do not have the report in front of me but from memory, and it was a while ago, that is what we were talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, let me respond to what Senator Harradine says is a valid accusation—that I am facilitating the spread of hard‐core porn through pay TV. I think that is a thoroughly non-valid accusation on Senator Harradine's behalf. This does not facilitate any such thing. It applies only if somebody has paid to get a specific service on their television—it does not force anybody to watch anything; it is not forcing children to watch anything. I would most certainly hope that parents are able to make sure that their children do not watch R‐rated videos that they get from the video store and leave hanging around. I would certainly hope that parents have the sense not to do that. If they have the sense not to do that, then I would certainly hope that they also have the sense not to allow children to watch a narrowcast service—if they have put it on, which they do not have to do.

Thirdly, the whole point of this legislation is that there are codes of practice which have been developed by the industry in consultation with the community. I understand what the minister is doing but I would quite like a response on this. There are codes of practice which have been developed by the industry after extensive community consultation over two years.

One of these codes of practice—this is the main point of this bill—is now about to be invalidated by an act of parliament, even though the minister has not put out a report about that code of practice. He has not explained why the code of practice does not have community standards in mind. What is wrong with the code of practice? Why did two years of community consultation result in a code of practice that does not reflect the wishes of the community? What is wrong with that code of practice? Why does the validation of that code of practice now have to be stopped by an act of parliament? That is the main question about this bill. I would really like to hear an answer from the minister on this question now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not at all clear on what Senator Bourne is referring to. The fact is that, as provided for in the Broadcasting Services Act, four codes have been registered with the ABA and those codes came into effect on 12 September. They refer to television subscription narrowcasting; television open narrowcasting, which is effectively the sixth channel; radio subscription narrowcasting; and radio open narrowcasting. Those codes ban the broadcast of programs classified X or refused classification, restrict access to R‐rated materials to those with appropriate disabling devices, restrict services devoted predominantly to adult erotica to late‐night access only. In effect, those codes comply in anticipation of this legislation passing the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure what Senator Bourne is referring to when she talks about some code that has been around for a couple of years and which is now out the window. If she is talking about television open narrowcasting, then there is a code which effectively does what this bill will do. I am happy to respond if Senator Bourne can give me details of the code to which she is referring.

Let me also say that R‐rated material has always been banned on pay TV. That was taken by the ABA to refer only to broadcast pay TV and, as I understand it, the two reports of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies were effectively dealing with narrowcast pay TV. What Senator Harradine is now pointing out is that both of those reports advocated the extension of the ban on R‐rated materials—in other words, R‐rated was not allowed on normal pay TV. These reports simply went one step further and said that R‐rated materials should not be allowed on narrowcast pay TV either.

That was in the wake of the ABA identifying some of these late‐night services as narrowcasting—therefore in a separate category—and saying that it was not covered by the current legislative prohibition which only applies to broadcast. The Senate committee report wanted that extension covered. This Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , in effect, validates the ABA decision. On that basis, I do not quite follow Senator Bourne's explanation as to why her recommendation that R‐rated material be not permitted on pay TV was not clearly intended to apply to narrowcasting, which I think is clearly Senator Harradine's position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish I had that report in front of me but, unfortunately, I do not. As far as I recall the report to which the minister is referring—R‐rated material is and was banned on normal broadcast pay TV—we were looking at whether or not that was a reasonable point of view. We had been asked to look at that by several proprietors or potential proprietors of normal broadcast pay TV stations.

SPEECH.PARA: This was right at the beginning of pay television. We were looking at whether R‐ rated material should be allowed on those stations at all, and we decided that it should not be allowed on normal broadcast pay TV stations. But that does not mean it should not be allowed on a narrowcast station.

The minister made a point in relation to the codes of practice. When he was reading out the code of practice, I think I heard him say—I did not write it down, and I would appreciate it if he would let me know—that R‐rated material should be allowed on a channel if it could be disabled somehow, or a term such as that.

TALK.START.PARA: —With appropriate disabling devices.
—Why is it now being disallowed even if it can be disabled?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, it is the second report of the Senate select committee that is probably more relevant to the context of the debate that has been going on at that end of the building, because it is post the ABA decision. That is the one that Senator Harradine would point to as calling for a ban on the broadcasting of R‐rated material through pay TV across the board—in other words, through broadcast and narrowcast. That is the one to which Senator Woodley has attached his signature.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the current codes are concerned, those that have been lodged with the ABA came into effect on 12 September. The pay TV narrowcasting codes restrict access to R‐rated material to those with appropriate disabling devices. That was essentially one of the matters that led the ABA to decide that this was a narrowcast service even though, as far as the customers were concerned, superficially, if you walked into the room, turned on the television and operated it as a pay TV outlet, you were able to get something that you could get on other channels just as easily. In this instance, you have to specifically subscribe, you need a pin number and, of course, it is a late night service. On that basis the ABA said that that distinguishes it sufficiently, makes it a narrowcast operation and it ought to be treated differently. Therefore, the act adopts the ABA distinction and the codes now comply with that approach as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does the act adopt the ABA decision?
—By effectively ratifying the decision to treat narrowcast pay TV separately from broadcast pay TV.
—Where? A very interesting response, Richard.
—I think the position is this—
—That is not in the act and you know it. And you didn't know it until now.
—No. It does it by omission, if you like.
—Ha!
—Because the original act provided a ban—

SPEECH.PARA: A quorum having been called and the bells having been rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —The ABA has dudded you. And so has the Attorney‐General, which I will tell you about directly. (Quorum formed)

—The position is that in the current Broadcasting Services Act 1992, part 6 applies to subscription television broadcasting services but, effectively, to broadcast services. Part 7 of schedule 2 applies to narrowcast services. Part 6 explicitly provides that licensees will not broadcast a program that has been refused classification or has been classified as X by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Condition (g) says:

SPEECH.PARA: The licensee will ensure that access to programs classified as R is restricted by disabling devices acceptable to the ABA.

In so far as narrowcasting is concerned, there is no similar prohibition. Therefore, the ABA, in passing judgment on the Night Moves application, took the view that it was dealt with separately. The amendments before the Senate do not overturn the ABA decision. They do not explicitly legislate to overturn it and therefore, in effect, accept that interpretation which would allow for R‐rated material to be shown on pay TV narrowcast services. Of course, the act does allow for codes of practice. Those codes of practice which have been registered, and which cover a number of other areas as well, also effectively support that ABA decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I now have the document in front of me. The first recommendation of part 2 of the report on R‐rated material on pay TV, which was presented in October 1996, just one year ago, says:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 be amended to define with greater precision the manner in which reception of subscription narrowcasting services is to be limited under section 17 of the Act by removing section 17A(v) so as to prevent the broadcast of R‐rated and X‐rated material through the medium of Subscription Broadcasting Service (Pay TV).
Senator Bourne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me have a look. Senator Woodley was the Democrat representative at that stage but you had signed the previous one which I read out. I thought you were still on at that particular time. Nevertheless, that appeared to be a unanimous decision. In fact, it was a unanimous decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, that entrenched, as it were, the statement that was made in regard to subscription television services, pay TV. We were talking about pay TV. We knew what pay TV was. What I am asking the minister now is how can he endorse what the ABA has done to him and to us—that is, the legislators? The ABA knew jolly well what we meant. How can he allow them to get away with what they have got away with—in other words, to describe what in any terms is pay TV as a narrowcasting service? And they did that at the behest of you know who—a very influential media magnate in this country who is a part owner of the particular service.

I would suggest to the minister that the parliament deserves somewhat more from the people who serve it, such as the ABA, than what has occurred thus far. Parliament made its decision that there should not be R or X‐rated material on pay TV. The ABA knew what it was doing. It got around that by defining that as narrowcast. I put to the minister that that is something that he should have regard to because of the implications of it. If you allow them to get away with it on this occasion, you are going to allow them to get away with it on other occasions—such as with the Internet, for example. You will be able to have hard core porn merrily going through the Internet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do now, don't you?

—Well, we are waiting for the minister's response in respect of that matter. But you watch the ABA. They will wash their hands of it. They are not a pro‐active organisation. They are not acting in this particular respect and in some other respects in the best interests of the community they are supposed to serve.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to hear from the minister why the ABA chose to define pay TV as narrowcasting. He will suggest that there are certain times at which programs are to be shown, et cetera, and that there are certain disabling devices. Taking up Senator Bourne's point, we are talking about hard core porn and other stuff, including violent stuff, being beamed directly into the homes of Australian families. Where is the guarantee that only adults are in control of this situation? Where is the verification? These are the sorts of things that you have to think about. I know the minister has an interest in it. I do not particularly blame him, but I think he has been ill‐served by the ABA and, as I will show in a moment, very much ill‐served by the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that this is a difficult issue and that there will be strong differences of opinion in the community. Indeed, until Galaxy started to show Night Moves , there was not an issue about the distinction between broadcast and narrowcast pay TV. They effectively approached the ABA for an opinion as to whether, given the restricted basis on which access could be had to this service, it should be treated differently to run‐of‐the‐mill pay TV channels.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABA took the view that, because it was late night—11 to four, I think—and because it required the use of a pin number, that would mean that those watching it would not accidentally come across it; that they would have to exercise a choice and, in so doing, there would be the capacity for adults to effectively ensure that children were not able to access the pin number. Even though adults might have difficulty in forcing children to go to bed early, the later the hour of night the less likely it is that young people will be up watching any form of television. So on that basis, the ABA gave that opinion.

As I understand the course of events, the Senate select committee then had a second inquiry. As Senator Harradine rightly points out, the members of that committee were unanimous in expressing what were in effect their personal views. The process that was followed in this regard was no different from the process followed in relation to virtually all other reports. Members of the various parties on those committees hear the evidence, form their own judgments, report back to the parties, and, in the case of the government party, a decision is finally made as to government policy, taking into account the view of the committee—not just, in this instance, the views of the Liberal and National party members but the fact that it was a unanimous committee report. That caused the government to think very hard about where the line ought to be drawn.

We have no truck, of course, with hard core pornography and there has never been any suggestion that that should be allowed on free to air or pay television of any sort. The argument is really in relation to—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is. It is.
—Only if you define R rated as hard core porn.
—I see. Are we getting into that?

—There has always been a distinction between X rated and R rated. If you want to argue that R is no better or worse than X and run the two together and say they are both hard core porn, then I will couch the argument in another way and say to you that we have never been prepared to countenance X, which we regard as a harder form. But in this instance the government took the view that you need to draw a policy balance be tween the rights of individuals to view entertainment services of their choice and the community's very understandable and commendable desire to ensure that some unacceptable material is not widely and indiscriminately available.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance, having considered the views of the Senate committee, the government has taken the view that it is possible to accommodate the concerns of all sides of the debate by effectively limiting access in the ways that the ABA endorsed. If that is the case, then those who will be watching that service will be watching it because they choose to watch it; because they pay to watch it—in some instances they will be paying premium prices to watch it; they will have to stay up late at night to watch it; and they will have to go through a particular process, which is clearly an informed consent. It is not simply coming across it late at night. They are making a conscious and deliberate choice to actually get up and key in their PIN number and subscribe specifically. It is like a pay per view service. On that basis the government has taken the view that the balance is correctly struck in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very interested in what the minister just said. It is quite significant that he made that comment in respect of R and X ratings. The simple fact of the matter is that, as the joint committee on video materials observed, the R‐rated porn material is the same in many of the videos. It is the same title, the same content, the same intent, generating the same callous and manipulative orientation towards women as the X‐rated equivalent, save only that they have been taken from different camera angles. That is interesting, isn't it?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the minister knew that. If he had been properly informed and advised as to what is contained in the reports, he would have known that. If he is suggesting that the distinction between hard core and soft core is just the camera angle and does not go to the heart of the matter, that is, is the intent of the material and the content, then he is not the sort of straightforward minister and thinking person that I thought. The joint committee found that all of the material was likely to have an effect on the habitual viewer. It is all there.

Senator Alston indicates that these are personal views expressed by members of the committee. Perhaps we ought to go to who the committee members were who recommended that this type of R‐rated material, as well as violent R‐rated material that is available, should not be on pay television and specifically said that it should not be on the narrowcast, because they had already said that it should not be on the broadcast.

Let us hear who the people concerned are. Senator Tierney was the chairman. The deputy chair was Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds from the Labor Party. The members were Senator Denman, Senator Harradine, Senator Knowles, Senator McGauran, Senator Troeth and Senator Woodley. Those recommendations were made after hearings undertaken by the committee. Let me make it clear that the government, the opposition and, it appears now, the Democrats are opposed to that unanimous recommendation.

I will deal with my next point by going to the legislation that is before us. Schedule 1 part 6 of the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) proposes to amend clause 11 of schedule 2 in the following terms:
. . . an open narrowcasting television service under a class licence is also subject to the following conditions:
(a) the licensee will not broadcast a program that has been refused classification, or has been classified as "X", by the Office of Film and Literature Classification . . .
As I understand it, the government is proposing to ban X and replace it with an NVE category. Am I correct in assuming that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is correct on the last point. When the state attorneys‐general have concluded their discussions on the new regime proposed by the Attorney‐General, it will presumably be necessary to amend that provision to ensure that the nomenclature is consistent. That is dealing simply with what in colloquial terms is called community television—in other words, the sixth channel. It is a free to air service rather than a pay TV service. It is simply extending the provisions that currently govern free to air commercial television to what is currently a free to air community service. It is saying that all free to air television ought to be subject to the same rules. That will continue to be the case even when there are changes made to the X classification.

SPEECH.PARA: I will respond to Senator Harradine's point about the distinction between X and R. I start by bowing to his superior knowledge on the subject. He has brought this point to my attention before. It may well be the case that you not only have the same titles and the same content but also have the same actors and the same non‐story line. In other words, it is the same film shoot, but you have different camera angles.

That is saying that on the supply side the difference is non-existent but on the demand side, the viewer side, the depictions are fundamentally different. They are required to be different because X is regarded as harder core than R and the different camera angles are intended to reflect that fact. The end result is that what the viewer sees is a lesser form as a result of the R restrictions. That is the intention of the act.

It is not so much directed to telling film producers and directors how they should make the film and who should be involved in it—although there may be some changes in that regard with the NVE classification—but essentially directed to restricting what is available to the viewers. That is why camera angles and other means of cutting back on the explicit nature of X material is then permitted under R. It is because there is a qualitative difference as far as the viewer is concerned.

Senator Harradine may be quite right that it does not really make any difference to the actors who are involved. They are doing the same things. They may not even know what goes to air, what ends up on the cutting room floor or what is classified X or R. Indeed, they may not even know the difference. I suspect that they have probably not even read the Broadcasting Services Act. Our task and the intention of the parliament is to protect the viewers and to limit what might be shown in various mediums and at various times and restrict that by reference to age groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is particularly edifying in this debate to be playing duelling reports, but as long as we are I point to part 3 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies. We have been talking about the other two parts. The first was signed by me. I have explained that the second was signed by Senator Woodley. The third is actually about the regulation of computer on‐line services and was signed by Senator Stott Despoja on behalf of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there are three recommendations in this third part which are relevant: firstly, that the Australian Democrats do not advocate unsuitable on‐line material being made available to minors; secondly, that we oppose the restriction of adult access to material which would generally be acceptable to reasonable adults—and that applies to narrowcast subscription television as well as to on‐line services; and, thirdly, that retailers and service providers should be encouraged to provide information to consumers about blocking and filtering devices and so on. I think that is perfectly reasonable.

I have two questions for the minister. Let me go back to what I think is the real point of this whole amendment—that is, section 123 part 3A of the Broadcasting Services Act, which deals with codes of practice. As we know it took two years for a code of practice to come in. It came in last month. It does substantially reflect what is in this bill. Section 123A states:
(1) The ABA must periodically conduct a review of the operation of subsection 123 (3A) to see whether that subsection is in accordance with prevailing community standards.
(2) If, after conducting such a review, the ABA concludes that that subsection—
that is, the codes of practice—

is not in accordance with prevailing community standards, the ABA must recommend to the Minister appropriate amendments to this Act that would ensure that that subsection is in accordance with prevailing community standards.

Those codes of practice have been in for only a month, maybe less—I am not sure. They came in last month. The point is that we are now changing the legislation to reflect that without having the review by the ABA of the operation of those codes of practice. The ABA has not reviewed it, so of course the minister has not put a report on the table. He does not have a report, so he cannot.

Why are we putting the cart before the horse? That is the question about the whole of this legislation. Why are we now changing the legislation without having the review which is actually set out in section 123A of the original Broadcasting Services Act? Secondly, is the minister aware of blocking devices which are available, or which are expected to become available in the near future, to enable people to take up that access which he says will be available if there are blocking devices on the equipment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision of section 123A simply says that `The ABA must periodically conduct a review'. The industry itself has chosen to vary its codes of practice. It is entitled to do that. It lodged them as recently as 12 September. It follows from that that the ABA will have an obligation in due course to periodically review those codes of practice. There would be little point in their setting out to review codes which the industry itself has recently junked and replaced with a new set of codes.
—I don't want them to. I want them to review the ones they have right now before you change the legislation.
—But they are obsolete. They are no longer effective.
—They just put them in.
—The industry has introduced four new codes of practice.
—Yes. That is my point.
—They have just come into effect.
—Yes.
—You cannot review them instantly.
—No, that is my point.

—I thought your point was originally that there had been a review done, I had not tabled it and I ought to release it somehow. Now you are saying that the cart is before the horse, that there ought to be a review before the new codes come into effect. But they are in effect.
—We are talking at cross purposes.

—We may well be, and I am not blaming you for that. My understanding is that the industry, through ASTRA, lodged four new codes of practice just over a month ago. They need to be given time to work, and the ABA will then review them. I do not see why that is the cart before the horse.
—It is changing the legislation before they have had time to work.

—But they are in accordance with the legislation. If the codes of practice were at odds with the amendments, your point would be valid because you would be effectively saying, `You are now overriding codes of practice which have just been introduced.' But the fact is those codes of practice have anticipated these amendments. Therefore, we are giving legislative effect, if you like, to those codes.

SPEECH.PARA: So they are absolutely consonant. There is no contradiction between the two, but in due course they will be reviewed to see whether they reflect prevailing community standards, and no doubt we will have another debate when the ABA provides a report on the matter. But at the moment the two are completely synchronous.

On the blocking technology, I think you are referring here to on-line services. We in Australia are quite well placed in terms of the standards that are available, if you compare us with the United States, for example, where they are now trying to devise what they call PICS—which I think is platform for Internet content standards. They will probably end up with something comparable to our OFLC classification. They may not be the same terminology, but the concept of having graduated standards for different groups or different times is one that they are currently addressing.

There is no doubt that it will be possible in due course to have technologies that will enable people to subscribe to service providers who effectively build PICS into their service. So, if you subscribe to OzEmail, Connect.1 or whoever, you will know that you will not get anything that is outside that classification regime. That is the ultimate intent. There are already services like Net Nanny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pay TV.

—I am not sure how blocking technologies will apply in this area, but it may well be that, if you are using current disabling devices, you can simply subscribe to a service that complies with a classification model and that will automatically provide a filter. So by operating a PIN you are effectively saying, `I know in advance what I will get access to because I am ordering it in accordance with those standards.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. I would be interested in one further explanation of the blocking devices on pay TV or narrowcasting services. Is the PIN number, or any blocking device really, available already and, therefore, is there anybody out there in Australia who, after this legislation is passed tomorrow, will be able to receive R‐rated material on their television service if that is the case?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, we are speaking at cross purposes about section 123A, I am sure. The point that the industry makes about the reviews is that it believes that it should be able to operate its codes of practice—and I hope I am not misrepresenting the industry, I do not think I am—as it has determined them, then have them reviewed by the ABA and then have the legislation changed. That is the cart before the horse order.

I take the minister's point, and it is an interesting one, but it is not the one the industry believes has a reasonable time line or a reasonable order. However, the question I would really like answered is whether tomorrow, when this legislation is passed, there will be restrictive devices on receiving narrowcast that will allow anyone in Australia to pick up the R‐rated material if they have paid for it? Is that available?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first point, I do not quite understand why you say that the industry would prefer to have had a review before any changes were made, because the industry has chosen to submit amended codes of practice.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that—if you want a pragmatic assessment—they were very grateful for the original ABA opinion. They wanted to see that upheld by the parliament—in other words, they wanted to comply with the limitations imposed by the ABA—and they therefore submitted amended codes of practice to bring themselves within that formulation. So they are effectively saying, in advance, `We accept the proposition that if we are allowed to have R‐rated material on narrowcast pay TV, it ought to be only on the basis that there are disabling devices and that it is late at night.' They have volunteered that. Having done that, the legislation will simply give statutory effect to the codes.

You asked whether it is possible, after the legislation passes, for anyone to then access R‐rated material on pay TV broadcasts. The answer is: only very much at the peril of a pay TV operator who would be acting in defiance of—

TALK.START.PARA: —On narrowcast.

—On narrowcast they are allowed to have R‐rated material, but if they tried, for example, to run X‐rated material, they would fall foul of their own code of practice and this legislation. As I understand it, Northgate Communications previously had an X‐rated program called Night Watch , and now they are going to take that off and bring in something called Spice , which is R rated, and re‐badge that as Night Watch . Effectively, the carriers themselves are accepting the limitations of the codes. But if some rogue company does not, then action can be taken. The ABA has power to give directions to bring it within the code and to punish it for non‐compliance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that, but the question I am asking is: does the minister know if a device is available, which is in use in Australia at the moment, which provides that restricting capacity which enables anybody who wants to watch R‐rated material—and who has been doing it—to do it tomorrow after this legislation is passed? Does that restricting capacity exist? Is it in somebody's home somewhere now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly in the homes of all the people who subscribe to the Galaxy Night Moves service. That is the basis on which the original ABA opinion was handed down. In other words, they were proceeding on the basis that there were effective disabling devices, involving the use of a PIN, that are and have been in operation for 12 to 18 months in this country. This will allow those to continue to be used and, indeed, require them to be used before people are able to access R‐rated material on narrowcast pay TV.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go to the question raised by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) and one raised by Senator Bourne. The minister, talking about R‐rated material some minutes ago, indicated that that was not so much determined by the actors as subjectively by the viewers. I point out that the Joint Select Committee on Video Materials, at page 45 of its report, denies completely what he says. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.52 To make the claim that the term `pornography' really refers to the subjective reactions of individuals to particular representations of sex, rather than to the representations themselves and their intent, involves a serious misuse of language. It is clear that the term `pornography' does not refer to the interior dispositions of the viewers. Both the person who experiences outrage and the person who experiences arousal of sexual desires from viewing exploitative depictions of sexual activities aimed at sexual arousal knows what kind of material is being referred to when they hear the term `pornography'.
3.53 The term refers to the nature of the materials themselves—their content and apparent or purported intention to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience.
That is that matter.

I now go to the question asked by the Democrats. I point out to the Democrats that the joint committee observed in its report that when the principle that adults be free to see, hear and read what they choose was originally stated in 1973 as public policy, the number of videos entering Australia was insignificant. The widespread availability of objectionable video publications as exists today as a result of the flood of materials into Australia did not exist then. And so it goes on.

I think it is important that we deal with these matters against the background of principle. This principle is often stated but not adhered to in practice, since adults are not free to view video material depicting, inter alia, child pornography, bestiality and sexually explicit violent pornography, as these are banned under censorship guidelines and prohibited from entry into Australia under Customs regulations.

The principle that adults be free to see, hear and read what they choose is dependent upon the pornographers' claimed right to freedom of expression and the balancing of this claimed right against requirements fundamental to the common good, which legislators are bound to uphold. The issue now is not whether there should be censorship—as was the case in 1973 when the principle was first stated as public policy—but where to draw the line. The committee considers that the current line is not appropriately drawn.

So really the test is a question of freedom of expression. What weight do you give the pornographers' right to freedom of expression as against protection of others who may be affected by that freedom of expression? As has been stated to our committee on a number of occasions, this includes children and it includes the engendering of a callous and manipulative orientation towards women, which much of this material establishes.

BREAK.PARA: I want to now come back to the question of NVE, which I raised earlier. The minister said, in response to my question about the NVE category, that the legislation may need to be amended later on. The government said at the last election that it intended to abolish the X category. That was a promise by the government at the last election. The government said that it would abolish the X category and establish a new NVE category. Minister, if and when it does that, are we to understand that the Broadcasting Services Act will be amended to exclude the X classification and replace it with the NVE classification?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Hopefully I will deal with all of Senator Harradine's points. As far as the subjective aspect is concerned, I do not for a moment take the view that pornography is in the eye of the beholder any more than I accept the proposition that there is an absolute freedom of expression. We all know the classic exception to that—Oliver Wendell Holmes saying that you do not have a right to cry fire in a crowded theatre any more than you have the right to trample on community standards and values.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficult task is always where to draw the line. I myself would attach very little weight to any so-called pornographer's right to freedom of expression. I have no doubt at all that they are not in the business because somehow they want to give cultural expression to their artistic instincts. They are there to make a big fat quid and to do it as efficiently and productively as possible in commercial terms.

So we are not in any shape or form looking at this through the eyes of the supplier of the service. What we are doing is looking at what actually gets to screen. That is why I say that it is not a matter of saying, `As long as you look at hard core pornography and you are not affected by it, it is not hard core pornography.' It is still hard pornography; it is just having a different effect on A as opposed to B.

What we try to do is to limit what is actually available to anyone, whether they are susceptible or not. When we have an R classification restricted, then we are deliberately decreeing—whether it be by way of camera angles or cuts or anything else—that in the scheme of things only less offensive material can go to air irrespective of the predilections or sensitivities of the viewers themselves. So that is an objective judgment about what is able to go to air, and how viewers react to that subjectively is a matter for them.

The reason that we are changing this classification in terms of the Attorney-General's discussions with state colleagues is that otherwise the status quo would have continued until such time as they had reached agreement and that would have permitted open free‐to‐air narrowcast services to be effectively unregulated. We do not think that is proper. It would probably also have encouraged people like Northgate to maintain X‐rated pay TV services when we do not think that is appropriate either. So it was necessary to act as quickly as we could to close off those areas of concern. But we recognise that there will need to be consequential amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act if a new classification regime emerges from the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

So all I can say to Senator Harradine is, in the scheme of things, it might have been preferable if they had already made their decisions and we could have made all these changes in one go. But given that we could not do that, I think we are moving with the necessary expedition to close off areas that we think need to be closed off. We are not going as far as Senator Harradine would prefer us to go, but that does not really affect the way in which consequential amendments will need to be dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really was not a question of as far as I want to go. I raised a question about the government's undertaking to the public before the last election. If you want to know where I want to go, I will be happy to have that discussion on a basis of principle at any time. But I am raising with the minister the question that arises from his legislation here as to what he means by the X category. Does he mean that the legislation will be amended to prohibit the showing of X‐classified material by those described in new subclause (3) of clause 11 of schedule 2?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that will need to be made to the Broadcasting Services Act are classically consequential in the sense that they will flow from changes that are precipitated by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) in relation to X‐rated videos and which are not the subject of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certainly aware of Senator Harradine's views about the classification of non-violent erotic videos announced by the Attorney-General and in particular Senator Harradine's view that the establishment of a NVE category is not necessary to exclude demeaning material as the national classification code already states that classification decisions should exclude material which portrays people in a demeaning manner. So I think the argument is not so much whether this is for the first time putting a ban or a limitation on demeaning material; it is whether it goes further.

The Attorney-General has indicated that, as far as the content of the new NVE classification is concerned, the details are still to be worked out with the states and the territories, but the Commonwealth will be proposing that that category would differ from the existing X category in that certain fetishes, sexually assaultive language, the portrayal of adults as minors and violence outside the sexual context would also be excluded. So it does go beyond the current definition of the X category. To the extent that it impacts upon the Broadcasting Services Act, any changes that are made will need to flow through to the BSA and affect both free to air and pay TV services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a simple question and I have not got an answer to it. Minister Alston raised what the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) raised. Minister Alston and the Attorney-General made a joint statement on 8 April, which inter alia said in the key part of the first part of that statement—and that referred to the government's stated intention before the election to prohibit the X category:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has decided to ban X-Rated videos and create a new category for non-violent sexually explicit videos which will contain tighter guidelines in order to exclude demeaning material.
Minister, is there demeaning material in the current X category?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps it might be clearer to express that as being `in order to further exclude demeaning material'. There is a ban on demeaning material already. As I have indicated, the national classification code states that classification decisions should exclude material which portrays people in a demeaning manner. The Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has made clear that the government also believes that the current arrangements still allow material which we would regard as demeaning to be portrayed and that that additional material ought to be banned as well. I have specified some examples of that which would then ensure that that material was no longer able to be broadcast as well. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that I called the quorum was so that at least government members would be able to know that the Attorney‐General (Mr Daryl Williams)—the first law officer of the crown—has made a demonstrably false statement about a very important matter on which the government made certain decisions. Those decisions related to what is known as the government's way of meeting its pre‐election promise to ban X‐rated videos.

SPEECH.PARA: The government, on the advice of the Attorney‐General, are saying that they will establish a new NVE category. The Attorney‐General, in a joint statement with the minister at the table, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), said:
The Federal Government has decided to ban
x‐Rated videos and create a new category for non‐violent sexually explicit videos which will contain tighter guidelines in order to exclude demeaning material.
At the estimates committee of 20 August 1997, I asked the OFLC Director, Mr Dickie:
I ask you a specific question: is demeaning material, under the national classification code, permissible in the current X?

The Director of the Office of Film and Literature Classification said, `No.' Who is right, Minister? Is the Attorney‐General right, or is the Director of the Office of Film and Literature Classification right?

It is no joking matter. It is a very serious matter indeed if you have the first law officer of the crown deceiving the public. I do not say he is deliberately deceiving, but being advised. Who is advising him from the Attorney‐General's Department? I ask the minister: who is right? Is the Director of the OFLC right, or is the Attorney‐General right?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that they are both right. There is no doubt that the current rules do ban demeaning material, but it will always be a matter of judgment as to what constitutes demeaning material. As it stands at the moment, the boundaries are drawn in a certain way. We are effectively extending the boundaries to include material which we now take the view is demeaning, which has not been regarded in that light to date.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the principle remains that demeaning material is not able to be shown under the X‐rated category, that does not tell you what constitutes the nature and extent of demeaning material. You can redefine that in accordance with community standards at any time. You can say that something that might have been regarded as demeaning 10 years ago is no longer demeaning and vice versa—what was not then, is now.

We are simply taking the view that, to the extent that the current rules allow fetishes, sexually assaultive language, the portrayal of adults and minors and violence outside the sexual context as effectively not demeaning—that is the effect of the current rules—we would say that they should no longer be seen in that light. They should also be regarded as demeaning and, therefore, excluded.

BREAK.PARA: I understand Senator Harradine's concerns but, in relation to that first paragraph, the intent is to exclude further demeaning material. In other words, it is not saying that until now demeaning material has been okay; it is saying that demeaning material in the broad has been banned, but that has been limited to a certain level. It might be that 80 per cent of what we now regard as demeaning has been banned. We are extending the boundaries.

We are now saying that there is additional material which hitherto has not been regarded as demeaning which should also be treated in the same way; therefore we will tighten the guidelines in order to exclude it as well. It is demeaning. It has not been treated as demeaning to date. We will treat it as demeaning. We will therefore exclude it. I think that what Mr Williams had in mind was to make it clear that he took the view that there was further demeaning material that should also be excluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the new proposal for an NVE category, what percentage of the current material that is in the X category will be transferred? On the basis of the volume of sales, what percentage of that is to be transferred to the NVE category? Is it true to say that almost all of it will be, as is the view of the OFLC?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is possible to give a quantitative assessment of what might or might not ultimately be covered by the new classification because that is a matter that will have to be determined by the Attorneys‐General, and I think their next meeting is in December. That will then, I think, determine what is acceptable, but against the background of the existing principle that demeaning material should not be permitted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth's proposal is that the current limits are inadequate and that there is additional material which should also be banned. You do that by effectively broadening the definition of `demeaning' to cover those areas that I have referred to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That is asking us to buy a pig in a poke. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and you stated that the federal government has decided to ban X‐rated videos and create a new category—an NVE category—which will contain tighter guidelines in order to exclude demeaning material. If it was the responsibility—indeed, the duty—of the OFLC to remove demeaning material in any event, why was it necessary to have a new category? Unless it is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Window‐dressing.

—Unless it is a window‐dressing job. Furthermore, I think the committee deserves to be told by the government what it expects to emerge from this. Does it expect there will be an examination of the current material in the X category to have another look at the question of what is demeaning and the definition of what is demeaning? Again, I would be very happy to have a debate on the concept of what is meant by demeaning. Will the government be having a very good look at that, apart from the matters that it has mentioned?

SPEECH.PARA: The matters that the minister mentioned are only, I understand, a very tiny percentage—perhaps one or two per cent, but no more than five per cent—of the current material that is in the X category. That would mean, in effect, that you are saying you are banning X, yet you are going to put 95 per cent of the X material into the NVE classification. That is what you are proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ninety‐nine per cent.

—Senator Bolkus says, `Ninety‐nine per cent.' But we do need to know, and I think it is reasonable that we should be asking you, the answer to that question. The Attorney‐General made a statement which at that time and now is demonstrably false. What you are saying is that you have got to change the title from X to NVE in order to remove demeaning material when, under the national classification code, that material should be out anyhow.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like the minister to tell the committee how the government will go about that particular measure. Do not just say, `SCAGS,' because I think a number of the state ministers are getting a bit sick of SCAGS. Mr Norman Reaburn from the Attorney‐General's Department is there and Mr John Dickie is there, and they try to run the place. But you are saying that they have not done the right job. You are actually telling the parliament that John Dickie has not done his job because he has not excluded what the government considers to be demeaning, as he is required to do under the national classification code. Why don't you sack him if he has not done the job?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a matter of judgment as to what satisfies standards and principles that are set by the parliament. When Senator Harradine says we are being asked to buy a pig in a poke, that is no more or less valid in this instance than it is in many other instances. The classic example that comes to my mind is when the law imposes a duty of care on a motorist. It is then a matter for judges and juries in each individual circumstance to decide whether or not reasonable care has been exercised.

SPEECH.PARA: That standard will vary over time, just as social and community standards will vary over time. People's concept of what is demeaning will vary over time. It is therefore, I think, appropriate for governments and the parliament to review the operation of a principle to see whether it is being given effect to in a way that is still regarded as consistent with community standards. You may well find in the administration of an act that those who apply it on a daily basis have a view which is not the majority view of the parliament. In those circumstances you may, indeed, change the principle or you may attach further guidelines or boundaries to make it clear that you have a different view.

As Senator Harradine is well aware, this matter is the responsibility of the Attorney‐General; therefore, I am not even in a position to have advice provided to me about the nature and extent of the current regime and what currently falls within it. But I can certainly seek that advice from the Attorney‐ General. As far as the states are concerned, they may well have views that differ quite significantly from the views of the OFLC or, indeed, the Commonwealth. If that is so, those matters will no doubt be thrashed out at the next meeting.

But, at the end of the day, it is the Commonwealth's view that there ought to be additional material excluded which is currently permissible. Others may have taken the view that this material should not be regarded as demeaning, but the Commonwealth has taken the view that it should. I would hope that, at the end of the day, the states would agree with that proposition. As a result, there would be a tighter set of guidelines that would further limit material that could be regarded as demeaning.

I am afraid I cannot go beyond that point because it is simply not a matter within my authority. But I am happy to seek further advice on the state of progress of any negotiations that might precede the next meeting of censorship ministers. If there is additional material, I would be more than happy to supply it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not so much what progress there has been or what its status is; I want to know, and I think the committee is entitled to know—since this is your legislation and since we are dealing with a matter that is clearly your legislation—the government's view on `demeaning', particularly as it relates to material that is in the current X category. After all, you went to the people with a policy to ban X. I do not think this bit of a shuffle here to `cut out three, four or five per cent and everybody will shut up', will go down at all well with those people who heard what was said before the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know, and the committee deserves to know, what the government believes—not what the Attorney‐General believes, not what Mr Norman Reaburn believes, and not what Mr John Dickie believes—the word `demeaning' means in the national classification code, particularly as it relates to material that is in the current X and the current R classifications. I ask that you take that on notice, please, and give me a response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to take that on notice. In broad terms, we know that the meaning of the term `demeaning' is to reduce in standing or reputation and to perhaps diminish the integrity of an individual. The difficult task is then to apply that to existing material in the real world. You can state the principle that we are not in favour of demeaning material, but it is a much more difficult task to decide whether any particular material comes within that category.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why this is not directly relevant to the current debate is that it will be dealt with by the Attorneys-General in the context of videos, which are not covered by the Broadcasting Services Act. All that the act will do—subject to the parliament approving consequential amendments—is simply adopt the new nomenclature. Whatever is then covered by the new classification regime will be provided for in relation to open narrowcasting television. But I repeat: the principle is that what is not allowed on free to air should not be allowed on what is currently the sixth channel, the community television channel.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth pursuing this for a bit longer. I think the point Senator Harradine makes in terms of the differentiation between NVE and X is an important one. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) says this will be developed in other places and so on, but obviously the government will have a role in developing the different type of classification. Has any work been done at the moment on criteria that will be relevant to NVE and how they differ from criteria that will be relevant to X? I know the word `demeaning' is an important aspect of it, but has an attempt been made to define `demeaning for the purposes of NVE' in any way different from `demeaning for the purposes of X'? Are criteria being developed and, if so, by whom? If not, when will they be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not so much a matter of defining the meaning of `demeaning'; it is a matter of applying it to certain categories of material. I am not sure Senator Bolkus was here at the time—and I will not go through it for the third time—but there are at least four areas in which material is currently permissible and which would not be allowed if the Commonwealth's recommendation is accepted. If there are any guidelines or further criteria being developed by the Attorney-General's Department in relation to matters that do not affect the Broadcasting Services Act other than consequentially, then I will obtain that information and make it available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not respond to my request. I repeat the request because it is an essential part of this debate and it will certainly be a part of the forthcoming debates on IT. I would like him to provide to me the view of the government on the meaning of the word `demeaning'. I am talking about `demeaning' in the context of the national classification code which requires those responsible to have regard to community concerns about the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner. The new draft guidelines state:

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of demeaning spelt out in the code applies in making decisions across all of the classification categories. It refers to depictions, directly or indirectly sexual in nature which debase or appear to debase the person or the character depicted.

So the crucial word in interpreting the meaning of `demeaning' is `debase'. For what it is worth, the Oxford English Dictionary defines `debase' as `lower in quality, value or character' and it defines `demean' as `lower the dignity or status of'. Obviously, the concept of human dignity is of great relevance and has a powerful meaning under a whole host of international conventions and human rights instruments, including the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
