To be quite frank, over the years that I have been interested in these matters I have not seen much thoughtful material from a philosophical point of view emanating from the Attorney-General's specific area on this particular matter—or from the OFLC for that matter. We have now reached a watershed. It appears that the government has no confidence in the OFLC's view of what is demeaning—that is what all this boils down to—it appears that the government has absolutely no confidence either in those responsible for this area in the Attorney-General's Department or in the OFLC in this particular area.

I again reiterate my request that I be provided with a considered view by the government on the question of where they think `demeaning' applies to the current R and X categories and what ought to go—beyond what the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has said in trying to make the best of what he presumably feels is a bad deal of the government's commitment to ban X.

I want to ask a further question about paragraph 6 of schedule 1 where it says that the licensee will not broadcast films that are classified as R—I am talking about the open narrowcasting television services—unless the films have been modified as mentioned in paragraph 123(3C)(b). That says that there have to be established codes that provide for methods of modifying films having particular classifications under that system so that the films are suitable to be broadcast or the films are suitable to be broadcast at particular times, et cetera.

We are talking about open narrowcasting television services. How do we know? Are we going to leave it up to the broadcasters themselves to decide? That is what you are proposing. In fact, that has been one of the problems in the current situation with regard to modifications to films. Are the modifications to those films going to be such that the material does not go beyond the previous AO classification criteria?There are two points there.

How is that to be determined? Who is going to make the determination? Who is going to make the modifications and under what criteria are they going to be made? Who is going to oversight it? Should this be done by the OFLC, or should we leave it in the hands of a non‐interventionist ABA?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to obtain a considered view of the government's approach to `demeaning' for Senator Harradine. But I repeat that, at the end of the day, it is not so much a matter of the definition of the term because, as we have just seen, the terms `demean' and `debase' are almost interchangeable. It is really the application of that. You could not have a better example of how views can differ on this matter than to look at the Democrats, whose position, as enunciated by Senator Bourne, seems to be that we should allow X‐rated material on narrowcast pay television whilst at the same time, presumably, arguing that it is not inherently demeaning.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clearly a matter of how you interpret the principle, and we do not resile from the principle. We think it is a fundamentally important one. There is a lot of material shown on free to air television that I would regard as being of pretty average quality. There is probably a lot of material that many of us would argue has very little redeeming social content, but it is a matter of applying your principle to what is currently available and drawing the line at an appropriate point. I will certainly come back to Senator Harradine on that matter.

The effect of paragraph 6 of schedule 1 is simply to apply the existing codes of practice and an R modification regime that applies to commercial free to air television stations to what is, I think, very unhelpfully defined as `open narrowcast television' but which in fact means `non‐commercial free to air television'. Licensees and operators will be required to have the same standards—in other words, to not draw that distinction, if you like, and to treat the whole free to air sector in the same manner. They will be required to have codes of conduct which will be essentially self‐regulating in the first instance. But, to the extent that the ABA regards the codes of conduct as not coming within the proper definition, or if there are particular operators or licensees who do not adhere to a code of practice, it will have the power to punish them for that.

It has worked fairly well in the free to air sector. We expect the same approach to apply to what is currently the community sector. To the extent that you want to argue across the board that there ought to be a tightening of that regime, that is a separate debate. At the moment, there is a very big loophole that allows so‐called open narrowcasting or, to put it another way, non‐commercial free to air to have carte blanche. We do not think that is acceptable. We want to treat all free to air in the same manner, and that is the effect of this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, I understand that. I am asking what sort of supervision is to be exercised over those who are modifying the R material. How often has the ABA examined R‐rated films modified by broadcasters? How often has the ABA given consideration to matters coming from the broadcasters in respect of this question?

SPEECH.PARA: Does the ABA know how many R, MA or M films have been modified so that they do not portray material that goes beyond the previous AO classification? I think it is reasonable to ask how many films have been modified by the broadcasters in the last year. Has the ABA examined any of those films to see if the modifications have resulted in material that does not go beyond the previous AO classification criteria? That is quite specific in the legislation. My understanding of the situation is that the ABA has not examined on a regular basis the films as they have been modified by the broadcasters themselves so as to ensure that the material in the thus modified film does not exceed the previous AO classification criteria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that that is a perfectly reasonable request from Senator Harradine. I will see what information can be made available. The only recent example that springs to mind is a program called Sex/Life on Channel 10 where the ABA did intervene and take the view that it had not been sufficiently modified, but there may well be other examples that were less controversial. I would be interested to see to what extent they have monitored the situation and to what extent there are R and MA which have been modi fied which go beyond the previous AO classi fication. I will certainly make sure we get that material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say that I was not expecting this legislation to come on this morning. When I first got in this morning I attended a meeting of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which was briefed by a Sinologist, Pierre Ryckmans. You do not leave meetings that are being addressed by Pierre Ryckmans because he is a marvellous person who is able to give us the benefit of his extensive knowledge of the history and the culture of China and so on. He made an interesting remark about tragedy. He was talking about a particular tragedy, not in the sense of St Kilda losing the grand final—he did not use that particular example. He said that, in the Greek sense, tragedy is a series of events which then require the protagonists to act continually against their own interests.

SPEECH.PARA: I must apologise to the committee and the minister. The amendments that were prepared, thankfully by the clerks of the Senate, have not been put to the committee; they will be left for a later stage. I thank the minister and the committee for their patience in respect of this. I think they are important matters. I might say that the government's views on these matters are still superior to those views of the opposition and, lest it be thought that I am being one‐sided in my criticism, the Democrats. I wanted to be critical in the sense of not casting aspersions on the integrity of people but to make a critique of the matters. I hope what has gone on this morning may have gone a little way towards that.

I do also, on reflection, wish to make it clear that the persons who are public servants—whether they be in the ABA, the OFLC or the Attorney-General's Department—are very hardworking. I do not reflect at all on their integrity. I happen to believe that sometimes advice that is given is not necessarily full and complete, but no doubt that would not be deliberate.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Alston) read a third time.

TITLE.XREF: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 has been passed off by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) as merely technical amendments—legislation which is designed to correct drafting and minor errors contained in the act. Whilst the opposition concedes there a number of genuinely technical amendments that it will not oppose, also incorporated in these changes are amendments which, in our view, seek to make substantial changes to the act.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I outline our concerns over these amendments I would like to briefly review the industrial relations climate that the government has created and what is, in our view, a totally partisan approach employed by the minister in claiming to want a more flexible labour market. What the minister means by a more flexible labour market is a lowering of wages and a reduction of workers' rights and conditions. We already see that happening right across the board in this country.

As part of the government's push for flexibility comes a call for what is quite obviously a debate on US‐style minimum wages. This is the shape of things to come, as far as we are concerned, from the government: confrontation, unrest and victimisation of employees. We have an industrial relations system which is anti‐collective bargaining. We have an industrial relations minister who champions individual contracts and champions the right to choose. However, when an employee chooses to belong to a union, the right to choose a collective bargaining process is conveniently ignored by this minister. Why wouldn't he ignore the workers' rights to choose? After all, that is what the Workplace Relations Act is fundamentally about—bringing an end to collective bargaining forever. That is what this government's agenda is.

Australians elected the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) trusting his promise that no worker would be worse off. That commitment has been breached. The promise has been breached, and well and truly shattered, by direct actions by this government. In fact, the government is now not even bothering to attempt to persuade the electorate that it intends to adhere to the commitment that it gave. I will illustrate to senators just why the Australian people no longer believes this government. The reasons that I could cite would be a very lengthy list. However, I have limited time, so I will concentrate on the matter of industrial relations.

Many senators will remember that during the debate on the Workplace Relations Act we, on this side of the chamber, highlighted that the stripping back of hard‐won conditions would be high on the coalition's agenda. It was very clear to us, and it was very clear to anybody who participates within the industrial relations system that that was precisely what this government was about. The government's chance had finally arrived and the minister was champing at the bit to go rabid with regard to this. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 14 October said:
The government supports a proposal by employers to scrap more than half of the provisions of the main hospitality industry award.

Exactly what sort of employees will be affected by the government's intention to scrap these provisions? These workers are the ones covered by the hospitality award, that is, people who actually work in restaurants, hotels and so on who are at the bottom of the totem pole in terms of industrial muscle and industrial strength and are already lowly paid. They are the sort of people we are talking about. The people who are already disadvantaged will be even further disadvantaged. So much for the Howard battlers, I say.

That was not enough for the minister for industrial relations who, as I said before, is exhibiting an amazingly partisan attitude with regard to IR. In the same article he was quoted as calling for employers to:
resist moves by unions to entrench provisions removed from awards into agreements.

What happened to the right to choose? What happened to the right of an employer and an employee, or an employer and a group of employees, to decide what goes into an agreement or an award or an AWA? The fact is this is contrary to the previous commitment that he gave in his second reading speech in the original debate on the Workplace Relations Bill, in which he stated:
All matters beyond those specified should generally be determined at the enterprise or workplace level, whether in formal agreements or informally.
But now he is saying, `No, I did not really mean that. What I am about here is being partisan—this is what I want,' and desperately attempting to convince employers that this is the way to go.

Time and time again the minister has shown what we regard as his total disregard for the welfare of workers and an intense dislike for harmony between employers and employees. This disregard is exhibited by his criticism of the enterprise agreement negotiated by the Finance Sector Union and the National Australia Bank. I would have thought that he would have said that that was a good deal for the finance sector. The employer group and the union group came together and negotiated something which was acceptable to both groups. But he did not like that. He said, `Sorry that is not the way we want to go. We do not want harmony.' Wherever there are negotiations going on between employers and employees you will see the shadowy figure of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business urging employers to carry out the government's agenda on industrial relations and strip away conditions.

I will now turn to some contemporary examples of this. We have the somewhat extraordinary activities employed by the minister to extend the disputes in the Hunter Valley and on the Cairns waterfront. In the Hunter Valley dispute, the minister backed confrontation rather than acting in the best interests of Australia and supporting arbitra tion and cooperation. That is the bottom line. Who is hurting? The reality is that it is not simply the people who are employed there who are hurting but also the Australian economy that is hurting. He did not back Bob Carr's move for an arbitrated agreement. Basically, the government did not support the determination of the AIRC to move towards arbitration with regard to this matter. So what do we have? We have industrial anarchy.

What the minister did with the Cairns dispute was ludicrous. It was something akin to the antics of an Inspector Clouseau style minister for industrial relations. You can picture at the time the minister pacing up and down his office, calling the company and saying, `Hang in there. We will smash the waterfront union' and so on. When 26 Australian employees were sacked we had the unedifying spectacle of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business standing on the sidelines cheering.

We are not talking about a bunch of rabid employees. There had not been a dispute on the waterfront in Cairns for 23 years, but Minister Reith decided that that was going to be the place where his so-called micro-economic reform with regard to the waterfront was going to occur. At a time when job insecurity is one of the paramount issues we had the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business cheering on the sidelines. This creates an unstable environment for not only the Australian work force but also the Australian economy. It therefore has deleterious effects on employment creation.

This act allows, and the minister in fact encourages, an attack on wages, an attack on jobs and an attack on job security. Some employees who belong to unions will stand up and say, `Hold on, that is not fair.' What happens to employees who are not members of unions and who occupy positions of little power in the company in the individual negotiation process? These workers have no protection. These workers would need to resist these sorts of attempts to diminish their wages and conditions, alone and with no support.

It is no wonder that Australians see this Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as having no vision and no direction when all that this government is serving up to workers and their families is a more stressful and insecure workplace and diminished job opportunities. Latest statistics, which were released yesterday, with regard to wages show yet another drop in the wages of Australians.

On top of this we have a situation where a small fortune is required to access federal courts. So you cannot access justice either if you are a low paid worker in this country. That is obviously a denial of justice—not only natural but any type of justice. I remind honourable senators that we had a 500 per cent increase in filing fees in the Federal Court under this government. If they do not get you one way they will get you another.

This is in stark contrast to the industrial relations environment that the Labor Party encourages which is based on fairness. We will restore the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—the independent umpire that people had faith in in terms of arbitrated decisions. We will promote a policy where the award system will not be undermined but where it will be, in fact, strengthened. We will abolish the Office of the Employment Advocate. We will put an end to secrecy in terms of AWAs and the operations of that office. That is our commitment. Obviously, we in the Labor Party believe that we have a duty to provide remedial action with regard to what this government has done and restore fairness to a system which worked very well for many decades.

I would also like to put on the record my dismay that this government has failed to come to grips with the real shortcomings in the act—the shortcomings which, as I have said before, are all too apparent to Australian employees.

Before I move to our concerns with the bill, I reiterate that the Labor Party will be supporting those amendments which are genuinely technical. I will take the opportunity now to broadly outline some of our concerns with regard to these amendments. The amendments dealing with certified agreements relate to the period allowed to employees to consider a certified agreement. This period is to be continuous regardless of whether a new employee signs on two or 12 days after the commencement of the period. That is, a new employee may—in an extreme case only—have a day or less to peruse an agreement. We on this side of the chamber do appreciate the difficulty in catering for the various situations which may arise and we are sympathetic to the need to ensure the period is not pushed out too far. However, we are keen to ensure that there is a realistic minimum time for perusal of an agreement. That is the basis of our opposition.

Our amendment requires a minimum of seven days unless the commission, the AIRC, determines otherwise. In a situation where there is cause for the commission to believe that actions are vexatious or frivolous, the AIRC could intervene and determine that the action is not appropriate in that circumstance. We believe that this minimum is necessary and that our amendment will not create an undue burden. We believe that workers should be given time to fully understand the legally binding document which their working future will depend on.

We are concerned that there will be cases where workers will not be given a reasonable amount of time to study the agreement and to ask questions with regard to that agreement. Surely it is not too much to expect that workers will have an opportunity to fully comprehend their agreement and to be fully apprised of the impact of the agreement. After all, what we are talking about is their working future, their work environment and the wages and conditions regime under which they will be working.

The amendments regarding the Employment Advocate endeavour, in our view, to give that person even greater powers than Mr Rowe already has. It is no secret on this side of the chamber that we do not believe that the Office of the Employment Advocate should exist. That is our position. It was highlighted during the original debate that accountability requirements were woefully inadequate. We made that point again and again. Unfortunately, we have been proven to be right.

Let me account to you some of the often quite alarming incidents with regard to the Office of the Employment Advocate endeav ouring to avoid accountability, incidents which are occurring far too often. To illustrate this, it is important to advise the chamber of a most extraordinary series of events that happened in the estimates with regard to this. When the Employment Advocate was asked to give reasons for his decisions when dealing with whether or not an AWA meets the no disadvantage test, he said:

I am not obliged to give reasons for my decisions. I have explained the general way that I am approaching the no disadvantage test. I do not see any need to go to specific AWAs and give reasons for those decisions. I am not obliged to do so under the act.

Excuse me! This is a Senate estimates committee. He is actually required under law to provide that information if we, as elected representatives of the Australian people, so wish. When I asked the following question:

So it is a personal decision of yours because there is no prohibition under the act. The act does not say, `Do not provide reasons for your decisions with regard to the no disadvantage test,' does it?
he replied:
No, it does not.
He was then asked:
So you have made that decision. Why?
Then came a ruling from the chair, which I still cannot believe. Senator Ferguson was in the chair, and he said:

. . . I would rule that question out of order because it is not a fair question. He has already answered and said he is not obliged to, and if he chooses not to answer the question then that is his choice . . .
There is a lot of stuff about choice in here, I have to say. The Employment Advocate has choice, but Australian workers do not. He went on:
. . . and he does not have to give reasons as to why he is not going to answer it. He says he is not obliged to answer the question.
Apart from the fact that that is fairly contorted English, I think we pretty much get the message. The chair went on to say:
The words that Mr Rowe used were that, under the act, he is not obliged to give reasons as to why he does not give you the reasons in response to the question.
Bear with me. He continued:

BREAK.PARA: If he is not obliged to, he does not then have to answer a further question as to why he will not.
If it were not so serious, it would be funny. The protection does not end there. When I inquired:

. . . where legislation is silent and an officer determines that administrative action is not in fact encompassed by legislation, a Senate estimates committee cannot question an officer as to why that administrative action was taken.

the chair replied: `Correct.' The Clerk of the Senate had something to say about that at subsequent estimates rounds. There you have it. That is the extent to which the government will go to protect the Employment Advocate.

After several rounds of estimates and an absolute bagging in the media, Mr Rowe decided that he might start acting like an independent statutory officer, and at the last round of estimates a little bit more leeway was provided to us, we were cut a bit more slack. We were promised some information, which we still do not have. I understand it is in the minister's office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You harassed him!
—Senator McGauran, how could you?
—I am hopeful that we will get that information, I understand there is an attempt to get it to us today. We will see, though.

BREAK.PARA: Both the government and the Employment Advocate are using the act so they do not have to be held accountable to parliament. I think that incident was fairly illustrative of what is going on. They are using the act to shield themselves from scrutiny. It is not good enough to say, `I don't have to answer that because the act does not expressly say that I have to.' That is an absolute joke, and that is not the way that estimates should operate.

This shroud of secrecy surrounding the Employment Advocate should be lifted and the Employment Advocate must be held accountable. The opposition will not be supporting amendments that increase the power of the Office of the Employment Advocate, given the way the government is using it. There is a lack of accountability, a lack of transparency and a shroud of secrecy surrounding the activities of this office. The set of government amendments pertaining to the no disadvantage test is to allow the commission and the Employment Advocate to use a state award when determining whether an agreement meets the no disadvantage test if there is no appropriate federal award. We will be opposing these amendments. We believe that these changes have the potential to lower the standard of the no disadvantage test applying to the scrutiny of AWAs, which, let me remind the chamber, have primacy over any other type of industrial agreement. AWAs are indeed a very powerful little instrument.

One of the major reasons we will be opposing it is the dismal industrial relations record of various conservative state governments around Australia. It is our view that state awards will be further eroded by conservative governments and, subsequently, so will employees' wages and conditions. For this reason, we will be opposing the amendments. The effect of these amendments certainly could not be classed as technical. They have the capacity to directly, severely and detrimentally affect Australian employees.

When the government talks about changes to the termination of employment, I start to wonder what group it is trying to exclude now. I would like to take the opportunity to say that what Peter Reith has said in the media, subsequent to the Senate's decision on unfair dismissal yesterday, has been absolutely outrageous. He is again attempting to say that they are our laws that the government was attempting to amend. They are the government's laws.

The government's attempt yesterday to change its own laws to exclude small business employees from using federal unfair dismissal laws was seen for what it was. It was a con and, as we said yesterday, a stunt by a desperate government that is increasingly attempting to be part of the game and attempting to gain some relevancy with regard to the economy. The government's argument was so weak that not even one government member, other than Minister Alston, who spoke in a robotic way for about two minutes, even attempted to defend it.

I do not want to digress. The concerns we have about these amendments to the termination of employment are that the amendments seek to affect workers' rights, and the government has not offered an acceptable reason why they are necessary. I will go into more detail with regard to the amendments when we come to them. In the meantime I intend to move a second reading amendment. I move:

At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate deplores the Government's attempt to give the Employment Advocate more powers and to undermine the rights of employees under the existing Act, under the guise of so‐called `technical amendments'".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 contains a myriad of mind‐bogglingly dull technical, but essential, modifications to the Workplace Relations Act to correct various unintended and unforeseen results flowing from last year's landmark amendment bill on workplace relations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that we consider this bill 12 months after we considered the main act—or bill, as it was then—and use it as an opportunity to see how the act is operating in practice and whether further modifications might be needed. The Democrats will, like Labor, be supporting the bulk of the bill, but we do have some amendments.

I am often on the record stating my view that workplace relations reform must be an evolutionary matter and must be viewed in that light. Having said that, I believe that reform should not proceed at a pace that is beyond the capacity of employers, employees or their respective organisations to adjust to the nature of change.

Let us not underestimate the extent of insecurity and concerns being felt out there in Australian workplaces. That insecurity—caused by high unemployment, the rapid growth in casualisation of the work force, corporate downsizing and a growing gap between rich and poor—is generating job insecurity, and holding back consumer confidence and growth in the Australian economy.

We have to be very careful to ensure that, while our legislative setting on workplace relations does promote productivity and should promote fairness, it also takes into account the need to provide levels of security and stability for workers, employers and their organisations, because we know that the effects of insecurity are not just social but massively economic.

The Democrats believe that the major reforms we negotiated last year need some time yet to bed down. As I said at a major employers conference on labour market reform a few weeks ago, employers need to make full use of the bill to achieve the maximum productivity possible from it before they start to try to make out a case for further reform.

It strikes me that they are almost the picture of someone with a greedy nature who has before him some food, but already wants more. Certainly, the Democrats can see no case at this point in time for further significant federal labour market reform. In particular, we continue to see no case for stripping back or resiling from the award safety net.

The Workplace Relations Act of 1996 allows for 100 per cent flexibility on an above‐award basis, but it allows no undermining of significant award conditions and wages. I hear employers and the special media sector talking about `the need' for further labour market reform. What they are talking about, as we all know, is shorthand for 100 per cent flexibility for wages and conditions below the award level.

We have accepted the principle that it is reasonable to look at that above the award level, but below the award level it is quite unacceptable and unnecessary. The Democrats do not support such an approach. Indeed, the best research we have seen from overseas countries with significantly deregulated labour markets—such as the United States, Canada and Britain—suggest that such a course is unlikely to lead to higher employment; rather, it will push many vulnerable workers into working poverty—in other words, the working poor.

I know that people have a view that it is better to be very poor and work than to be a little better off and not work, but the fact is that our system has served Australia excep tionally well over decades and we think there are other policy mechanisms which can cope with the employment problem rather than this particular mechanism. Australia, which rightly prides itself on its fair‐go mentality and egalitarian tradition, must avoid an outcome which takes the worst of foreign models to heart.

The amending bill deals with a number of difficulties that have inevitably emerged with the operation of the new act, particularly the operation of the new Office of the Employment Advocate. As my Labor colleagues know, I remain a strong supporter of the government's right to try to make that new institution work, but it does not mean that I am not keeping a close eye on it—as I know they are.

I spent over three hours with the Employment Advocate, Alan Rowe, in his Sydney office and I received a detailed briefing on the operations of his office. I appreciated the courtesy and the openness with which the members of the OEA spoke to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lucky you!

—Mr Rowe, as Senator Mackay knows, has also made his views known to the Senate estimates committee several times. I suspect he will be asked to make those views known several more times. However, in the spirit of a fair go, it is a new institution and we must attend to the particulars of that office and how the act deals with it rather than with Mr Rowe himself, because personally he is quite accessible and helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: I was extremely impressed with the arrangements being put in place by Mr Rowe with regard to the no‐disadvantage test. It seems to me, from the way that has been described to me, that it is being done in a more rigorous and systematic way than was ever applied by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Of course, we would like to make sure that that is monitored and audited by somebody from outside. Senators are addressing themselves as to how that can best be accomplished in a way which meets the needs of the government, the Office of the Employment Advocate, employers, and employees.

BREAK.PARA: I would expect nothing less, given that the OEA is not performing its scrutiny in the public gaze as the AIRC does, and does not take public submissions from unions on agreements as does the Industrial Relations Commission. For that reason, Labor has correctly focused on a need to make sure that the processes are done well and objectively, and look after the interests of all parties concerned. By and large, I think Mr Rowe's concerns and the other problems identified by the government are largely well founded.

The Democrats will be opposing two proposals to allow the Employment Advocate to ignore technical defects in AWAs—at least as presently expressed by the government—and to take submissions from persons other than the parties. We would have no objection to ignoring the fact that somebody ticked instead of crossed something or failed to do something really minor, but the way in which the amendments have been expressed concerns us as to the enlarged discretion, which is potentially there. We think both of these provisions would allow the Employment Advocate to reduce that intense and high level of objective scrutiny, which they are attempting to apply at present and which we believe are absolutely essential.

In addressing potential amendments to this bill, we have been at pains to avoid reopening the entire debate—not least because I do not feel like a series of body blows today. We have focused on technical amendments. We will be moving minor amendments to other aspects of the bill dealing with arbitration during a bargaining period and applications for termination of employment.

In the committee stage, I also intend to move amendments sought by the Association of Professional Engineers, Scientists and Managers—I understand they have been lobbying all parties—to the disamalgamation provisions to make them more workable from their perspective. In addition, the Democrats will be moving three amendments to fix what we believe have either emerged as holes in the original legislation or arisen as problems since the new act commenced. Our amendments will seek to ensure that the level of protection for workers envisaged in the original bill does apply as was intended and as we understood it.

The first amendment is to restore the fast-track award making power for federal awards where a state government takes punitive action against a union for pursuing a federal award. I recall that that occurred in Victoria. Eventually, that had the unintended consequence of Victorian legislation being given up. The Victorians now fall under federal legislation. So maybe there are some strange things that can result from these processes.

This amendment has become necessary because of the passage of Minister Graham Keirath's second wave industrial relations legislation in Western Australia earlier this year. The most harsh provisions of that state act allow the minister to cancel the respondence of a state union to a state award and to strip that union of its membership coverage if it dares to apply for a federal award.

We hear a lot of discussion about freedom of choice. There is not much freedom of choice when you prevent someone legitimately applying for jurisdiction legally and being punished for it. This fundamentally breaches the careful balance in the federal act, where it was supposed to be up to employers and employees together to pick the jurisdiction and the type of regulation which best suited them. I would hope that, given the government's continual reference to the virtues of freedom of choice, they will, in fact, support our amendment.

Given that it may take up to three to four years to achieve a federal award, the Democrats are concerned that the Keirath bill could leave many Western Australian workers and employers without an up-to-date award because their union and their employer will be denied the right to update and enforce their state award while they are pursuing a federal award. To prevent the inevitable eroding of employment conditions within the state award, the Democrats propose that, if the state minister does take action against a state union for making a federal application, it would trigger a fast-track mechanism whereby the AIRC would be required to deal with the matter as quickly as possible, including the making of an interim award, and could there fore ignore the extra and constraining evidentiary provisions of section 111AAA.

Our second material amendment—we think it is a material technical amendment—deals with the issue of collective bargaining. When the Democrats were dealing with the amendments last year, a key threshold issue that the ACTU wished us to address was to ensure that Australia upheld its international obligations under ILO conventions to prefer collective bargaining over individual bargaining. Members will recall that one of the amendments we were able to get in was, in fact, to restore as well as we could international obligations in that act.

We had several meetings with the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, on that matter. We were finally persuaded by the minister and his staff that the bill did indeed prefer collective bargaining over individual bargaining. In particular, the minister's office pointed to the fact that under section 170LA the Industrial Relations Commission has a positive duty to facilitate the making of collective certified agreements. I received advice as follows:

It is important to appreciate that the AIRC will have extensive conciliation powers to facilitate the negation of certified agreements, which may include, for example, ordering the parties to attend compulsory conferences. Indeed, under section 170LA, the AIRC is required as far as practicable to perform its function in such a way as to facilitate the making of certified agreements.

In dealing with the situation where employers want to bargain individually and the workers want to bargain collectively—in other words, there is a difference of opinion as to how they want to be dealt with—I was further advised:

Such employees would have a number of options open to them: in particular, they could initiate a bargaining period for a CA, and they could also appoint their union as their bargaining agent. If the employer still wished to negotiate an agreement, he would have to deal with the union. The union and the employer would then have to negotiate whether any agreement was to be in the form of a collective AWA or a certified agreement. The employees would be able to act collectively, and would be able to take protective action. They could also seek the assistance of the AIRC to facilitate a CA if they wished.

I am absolutely in support of employees and employers pursuing individual agreements where both are willing and both feel that that is the best course. I doubt there is anybody in the Senate who opposes that. But I am not supportive of a situation where workers in an inferior bargaining position who wish to bargain collectively would be obliged to take up individual agreements. It is plainly their right to be able to negotiate collectively, and it is a right that has been recognised throughout the civilised world for well over a century and probably more.

That is how we understood the bill would operate—that workers could not be forced by their employers to bargain individually. But in practice there are now some doubts that it necessarily always works out that way. The disputes in the Hunter raised by Senator Mackay show that the powers of the IRC to facilitate the making of collective agreements are not as strong as we thought. They show that employers can still continue to try to undermine collective bargaining by trying to force in individual agreements even during a bargaining period. The disputes at the Commonwealth Bank as well show a similar determination by an employer to undermine collective bargaining by trying to force in individual agreements.

What we propose is a technical amendment to give the commission the power to make any orders that it deems necessary to fulfil its statutory obligations to facilitate the making of certified agreements and collective bargaining where the workers or the employers need that device activated. Such orders would not extend to stopping protected action as the act clearly intended such action to be protected. But, certainly, such orders could extend to preventing the predatory offering or approval of AWAs, for example, or other punitive action by employers against unions and workers wanting to bargain collectively. Our amendment would also allow the seeking of injunctions to enforce such orders if necessary.

Our third amendment is in relation to strike pay. The Democrats strongly support the intention of the bill to prevent employees being paid when they are on strike. But what most Australians understand as a strike and what is described as an industrial action in the act are very different. The act picks up as a strike any performance of work which is different from how it is customarily performed. So even if a worker is at work for their full contracted hours, is performing 99 per cent of the work allocated to him or her and is flat out all day, the employer under this law is obliged not to pay them. We thought there was common law protection in that area.

When we dealt with this legislation, the government placed great emphasis on the rider to the definition of industrial action in section 4 which says that an employer is not engaged in industrial action if the employees' action is agreed to by the employer. `Agreed to' you would think would mean acceptance by the employer of the work that was being performed. That was certainly our reading of it. However, the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business has since adopted a much stricter interpretation. Its guidelines sent out to all public sector managers compel managers to refuse to pay in all circumstances where the other conditions of section 4 have been met. I wrote to the minister and I met the minister to discuss this excessively provocative stance taken by his department in relation to only partial bans on work, but he stood by the department's hardline stance.

For that reason and given the act is not being interpreted as we expected it would, I will be moving a technical amendment to delete from industrial action for the purposes of strike pay, action that does not prevent employees being fully engaged in their duties during the ordinary hours of work. I should note that such a ban would continue to be regarded as industrial action for all other purposes in the bill, including the issuing of orders by the IRC and injunctions under section 127 for failing to comply with such orders. All that our amendment will mean is that workers will still be paid for the work that they are performing, especially when the employer has agreed to that practice occurring.
In summary, the Democrats will be supporting the vast bulk of this bill as a timely and technical review of the operation of the Workplace Relations Act. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) has told us that this bill on the whole represents technical amendments necessary after a period of review of the operations of the Workplace Relations Act that were supported by the peak employer group, the ACCI, and for the most part the ACTU. For that statement alone and for what the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 represents, I think we need to revisit precisely how the minister has been dealing with his portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mackay referred to the reference to the minister as Partisan Pete and in the past he has been referred to as Penthouse Pete, but I think a new term is appropriate. I would call him the Stealth Raider. `Raider' because, as Senator Mackay has already pointed out, the minister has been zoning in on industries promoting disputation and confrontation—not only the high profile industries we have heard through the media recently, such as mining and the waterfront, but also now the hospitality industry.

The minister is now encouraging employers in the hospitality industry not to put into agreements provisions that will be ripped out of awards. He was actively encouraging employers to continue disputation rather than reach agreement about what provisions previously in their awards might still be current and might still be necessary in their employment arrangements.

I refer to `stealth' because, consistent with the minister's usual style, this bill seeks to make some substantive amendments under the guise of technical changes. Senator Mackay went through several of those, but I would like to highlight a few, particularly following Senator Murray's remarks.

With respect to extending the powers of the Employment Advocate, I concur with Senator Mackay that, given the difficulties we have had to date with the issue of accountability with the Employment Advocate, I do not think it is the time for us to be looking at extending the powers of the Office of the Employment Advocate. Once we see coming out of that office the results of the more recent cooperation in terms of accountability to us here, it may be appropriate to look at some of those problems and some of the difficulties that the office has encountered. But until such time, I do not think that that is appropriate.

I understand the Democrats' support for the Office of the Employment Advocate, but I think that the Democrats should look at what this office is actually doing. For all the Australian Democrats' good intentions about the role of the Office of the Employment Advocate and how it will assist workers who do not want to be represented by unions, we only need the reminder in yesterday's Financial Review regarding the first action of this Office of the Employment Advocate to know what it is really about—that is, it is a tool for this government. Even though the Employment Advocate has the ability to provide legal representation for workers who have difficulties in relation to their employment agreements, its first action is to pursue, by alleging breach of freedom of association, the National Union of Workers.

We have sought information from the Office of the Employment Advocate about how they will actually represent workers in relation to their employment difficulties. To date, we have had no response at all. As we know from other examples, the Office of the Employment Advocate, on behalf of this government, is actively pursuing unions. That is no surprise to us, but I think the Australian Democrats should reconsider what they originally envisaged was to be the role of the Office of the Employment Advocate so as to pull it back into line and perform those functions. I do not think that extending its powers at this stage will achieve that.

Another area of substantive change is in relation to a prohibition regarding unfair termination. Frankly, I am absolutely stunned that the Australian Democrats are allowing this one to go through. Given their approach to the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill yesterday, this quite blatant attempt by the government to remove workers' entitlements to challenge unfair termination—currently, if they do not have access at a federal level, they can access the state level—astounds me.

Another substantive change relates to the disamalgamation provisions. In part, we can accept what was done when the original bill went through, but the retrospective nature of these changes is another very substantive concern. The most significant change signifying what I believe represents the minister's stealth in relation to this bill relates to the state override. Senator Murray and all of the other senators involved in the inquiry regarding the Workplace Relations Bill will remember, at least on being reminded, that the state override issue was perhaps one of the most fundamental of the issues originally raised. We heard evidence on it day after day after day, and that evidence was successful in convincing the Australian Democrats and the government—we were already convinced—that they had to amend the legislation to ensure that workers would not lose entitlements by having state provisions override their entitlements under the federal jurisdiction.

But the minister is seeking to have another bite at the cherry. He has come back again and has said, under the guise of a technical amendment, `We will now look at state awards in relation to the no disadvantage test being applied in relation to agreements—not federal, but state.'

In the past, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, when looking at an agreement, would have had to have looked at a relevant federal award. An employee may currently be covered by a federal award, but they could be confronted with an agreement, so the no disadvantage test will be compared with a state award that they are not under now. As I said, it stuns me that, after going through the lengthy evidence that we had when we considered the original Workplace Relations Bill, the Democrats have not seen that Minister Reith is coming back for a second bite at the cherry on this matter.

Yesterday Senator Murray said that he was disappointed that the government had not honoured their agreement. I think this is another example of the government not honouring their agreement. But, for some reason or another, the Democrats are falling for it. Peter Reith is coming back for a second bite at the cherry but the Democrats do not see it.

I was pleased to hear, in relation to the Office of the Employment Advocate, that the Democrats will not be supporting the amendment in relation to technical defects because, hopefully, they have reached the same conclusion that we have, that the office is not up to making those sorts of decisions at this stage.

Also, in relation to submissions from other than the parties, I was pleased to hear that the Democrats—probably on behalf of employers, rather than the workers themselves—will not be supporting this attempt to perhaps legalise the process. It will make the process far more difficult for workers who, if they are with the Office of the Employment Advocate, probably do not have the assistance of unions and are most unlikely to be able to afford the legal representation that their employer would be able to afford.

I also note with interest that the Democrats have used this opportunity to revisit the Workplace Relations Act. I think it is interesting to note some of the issues that they are now highlighting, and particularly the one with respect to collective bargaining. I was reminded, I suppose you could say, of the line that was fed to the Democrats in relation to this legislation—that it actually promotes collective bargaining. I should say, perhaps, that it was claimed that it promoted collective bargaining; at no stage were we anywhere near convinced of that line. But I think it is important to note that the Democrats are reconsidering the lines that were fed them back when they did this deal. They are now struggling with amendments to try and rectify the harm that was done to Australia's industrial relations system through the deal that was done between the minister and the Democrats.

I think it is important to highlight what this bill is not about. This bill is not about doing anything about the decline in employment security for Australian workers. Nothing in any of these proposals will result in the Workplace Relations Act doing anything for those battlers, those workers out there strug gling to find employment security. If anything, what is in the bill takes away a few more of their entitlements—particularly with Peter Reith's second bite at the cherry on the state override issue and particularly with removing access, if the bill is successful, to state jurisdictions in relation to unfair termination.

In conclusion, we again highlight that, while a fair number of these amendments are technical, there are other things cloaked in this bill. That is fairly typical of the minister's approach to workplace relations in Australia—hiding what he is really about and promoting confrontation and disputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today on the government's dismal and increasingly embarrassing public record on industrial relations. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 —which we have been told requires amendment due to drafting errors and the fact that there will be some unintended consequences arising out of that—is a bill with which I have a number of concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes some substantive amendments which favour employers at the expense of workers. Although there has been some watering down of the government's grand plan to deregulate the labour market and to treat workers like any other commodity or inanimate object used in the production process, we remain fundamentally opposed to its ideologically driven principles.

The reduction in the powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, at the same time as the introduction of AWAs and the creation of the Office of the Employment Advocate, supposedly to vet the new AWAs, is certainly having some interesting results. AWAs, as provided for in the legislation, are clearly just a mechanism for eroding current working conditions and pay.

An AWA operating at the Coominya meatworks in Queensland demonstrates all too clearly that the Office of the Employment Advocate is merely a rubber stamp. The Coominya meatworks, in a small town about 100 kilometres north‐west of Brisbane, put about 100 workers on AWAs around June. Although the AWAs left workers between $100 and $150 a week worse off than they were under the award—so much for the no disadvantage test!—and although the union made a submission on their behalf to the employment advocate, that AWA was subsequently approved. This is in spite of the fact that 20 workers rang the employment advocate on the 1‐800 number to explain, prior to the AWAs being approved, that they had been coerced into signing the AWA on the threat of losing their jobs.

The AWA was so bad that, when a unionised meatworks at Grantham opened about 60 kilometres away, key boning and slicing personnel left and sought employment at the Grantham meatworks. The manager of the Coominya meatworks then went to New Zealand to hire a work force. In true high farce style, these workers subsequently went to Coominya but quit after three weeks work. If the playwright Joe Orton were still alive, he would be having a field day with this plot. Ironically, the Coominya meatworks is owned by the US multinational Keystone, as in—wait for it—Keystone Cops. They seem to have brought their employment practices over here with them.

Proposed changes to this bill will allow a person authorised in writing by a party to an AWA to explain that party's understanding of the effect of the AWA or ancillary document to the Employment Advocate, but that will be limited to situations where the Employment Advocate feels this is appropriate. Even when the Employment Advocate does allow that representative to appear, that representative will still be limited only to explaining the party's understanding of the effect of the agreement and are expressly prohibited from making submissions or from being heard for any other purpose. Members of groups in society who have been traditionally disadvantaged in the workplace—young people, women and workers from non-English speaking backgrounds—will be doubly disadvantaged under this process.

This bill does not address the fundamental problems of this government's ideological obsession with so-called reform of industrial relations. More specifically, there is growing evidence that the so-called reforms are un necessary and unfair. They are also a major breach of pre-election commitments given by this government. I guess the breaking of this commitment must be just another one of those `non-core' promises that the Prime Minister, John Howard, is so fond of telling us about.

In my home state of Queensland, we have already seen the consequences of this government's obsession with so-called industrial reform in the mining industry. A couple of key issues have arisen out of some of the industrial disputes occurring in Queensland. The first is that the legislation leads to messy, protracted disputes which are not good for workers, their families or the companies involved.

Recent provocative actions by management at the Gordonstone coalmine in Queensland are exacerbating this dispute. The company has now moved to increase rent on the homes of sacked workers fivefold. The company, as has been widely reported in the media, has also hired 25 security guards who are carrying guns and who have been reported as intimidating workers and their families.

At the Curragh mine, Arco decided to dramatically reduce their number of staff by 50 per cent—which amounted to 200 workers—in order to increase productivity right in the middle of their enterprise bargaining negotiations. This does make me somewhat suspicious about whether they are really bargaining in good faith.

The attempts by this company to override the award in relation to mutually agreed provisions for retrenchments led to a strike which lasted 15 weeks. The Minister for Industrial Relations in Queensland, Mr Santo Santoro, has stated in parliament that the cost to the Queensland economy has been $10 million a week.
Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution today in the matters of public interest debate I wish to celebrate the tenacity and courage of Miss Karen Dare. Miss Dare is a student at the University of Tasmania. She is aged 19 years, is a first‐year science student from the isolated west coast of Tasmania and is in receipt of Abstudy.

SPEECH.PARA: Miss Dare has a principled objection to joining the student union. As a result, she has refused to pay the fee. Whilst some student union sanction might be expected, it is appalling to find that the university administration is applying the sanction on behalf of the student union by debarring Miss Dare from enrolment for 1998. In my home state of Tasmania there has been some suggestion that she has, in fact, not been debarred. But let me simply put on the record that I have documentation issued by the University of Tasmania which is headed `Application for Enrolment 1998'. It is addressed to Miss Karen Dare and it has on it `DEBARRED: Outstanding 1997 fee $253.00'.

The University of Tasmania was embroiled in a similar unedifying situation some three years ago when they tried to ban a prize‐winning student, Daniel Muggeridge, for exactly the same reasons that Miss Dare finds herself debarred today. At the time, the university agreed to alter its rules. Now, sure, you do not have to join the student union, but you have to pay the fee, and in full. We have a piece of somewhat tortured logic when the university administration says, `We will respect your right not to join the union, but we will force you to pay the money to the student union. By the fact that you are not a member, you will, of course, be denied the right to have a say over how that money is spent.' `Pay up and do not join; pay and be denied the right to say how your money is spent,' is basically the line that Professor Lidl, the Deputy Vice‐Chancellor of the University, has stated publicly.

Let me say to the University of Tasmania administration that this is an ongoing fight. Students in my day, some 20 years ago, were concerned about the compulsory aspect of student unionism. I note in the public gallery today a former president of the Tasmania University Union who is of a similar view that student unionism ought be voluntary. Daniel Muggeridge took up the fight some three years ago; Miss Karen Dare is taking up the fight again today. So, I say to the university administration: this issue will not go away until you address it and give students their fundamental rights.

The fundamental question is: what is more important? The enforcement of compulsory student unionism or a student's right to an education? Student unions, quite simply, ought to survive on their own merit. If they provide the services and facilities that they claim are of great benefit to the students, one would anticipate that the students, in their wisdom, would realise that and voluntarily join up. The fact that the university acknowledges, and the student union acknowledges, that the fee has to be levied on a compulsory basis is, of course, an admission by the university and the student union that they could not survive in an open marketplace where students are given a choice as to whether or not they want those alleged services and whether or not they want to belong to the student union.
The matter is a matter of great concern, as a result of which I wrote to Vice‐Chancellor McNicol on 20 October. I will read my letter to him:
Dear Professor McNicol
I was horrified to read about Miss Dare's draconian debarment from the University by your administration for refusing to pay the student union fee.
The principled stand taken by Miss Dare is fully supported by myself. Her courage is to be applauded.
Whilst the University continues to operate as a second rate shop steward for the student union it will be, quite justifiably, held up to public ridicule.
I urge you to assure the public that freedom of association is alive on your campus by providing Miss Dare her full entitlements as a student who has incurred a $4,500 HECS debt with your University.
Any actions short of abolishing compulsory student unionism will ensure that the University's reputation is not rehabilitated.
I await your urgent response.
Yours sincerely
The only thing Vice‐Chancellor McNicol did, in fact, was provide a quick response. I want to canvass aspects of that response with the Senate this afternoon. Part of the letter reads as follows:

I trust that we are not about to see a publicity campaign of the sort which was run previously on this matter, but if that turns out to be the case may I assure you that the University of Tasmania will put clearly and plainly the reasons for students paying the Services and Amenities Fee. If those amenities were not provided and I see no government in the offing which would underwrite their funding, students in Tasmania would be deprived of services and facilities enjoyed by their mainland counterparts.

Can I just interpose there and ask the vice‐chancellor: why does he think those services are enjoyed by student counterparts on the mainland? If they are so enjoyed, as the vice‐chancellor would assert, why does it have to be a compulsory levy? I would have thought the students would be lining up for the enjoyment and paying the money over voluntarily.

The question is: what is so fundamentally important about the student union fee that, if you do not pay it, you should not be allowed to continue your education? What are these facilities? They include a bit of beer drinking and a bit of subsidised coffee in the refectory. You are allowed to pay $5 a year up-front so you can then drink subsidised coffee all year. It does not make much sense to most people. You can have the benefit of the student newspaper, which most people realise is just a rag and do not want to be part of, or you can join the chocolate appreciation society—another one of those worthy causes which the vice‐chancellor undoubtedly is referring to. The vice‐chancellor's correspondence continues:

The University is keenly aware that mainland universities compete with us for Tasmanian and international students. A loss of students to more attractive mainland campuses would not only result in decreased Commonwealth funding to the University but would have a negative impact on the state's economy. I would urge you to think very carefully before precipitating action which may be injurious to this University and to the State.

It is pretty good sounding stuff until you actually analyse it. It was a good throwaway line but it does not stand up to analysis. These days the private paying student who wants to go to university will make an assessment of the cost. The University of Tasmania now charges an up-front fee of about $760 for students in a three‐year degree and $1,265 for a five-year course, courtesy of the student union compulsory fee. What a disincentive that is if you are trying to attract students.

As for the vice‐chancellor's allegation about facilities and student numbers, let me remind him that, in Western Australia as a result of legislation passed in December 1994, there is complete voluntary student unionism in that state. And guess what, Vice‐Chancellor? Shock, horror! Students are still graduating from those campuses; they are still getting an education; they are still getting quality degrees that are still getting recognised; and they are still getting jobs. It has not in any shape or form impacted on the academic life or on the student numbers at the campuses in Western Australia.

As to the suggestion by the vice‐chancellor on what might happen with overseas students, let us have a look at the figures in Western Australia—I never thought of looking up these figures, might I add, until I received the vice‐chancellor's letter last night. In Western Australia, in 1995, the first year of voluntary student unionism, the commencing overseas student numbers increased by 28.7 per cent, and in 1996 they increased by 19.35 per cent. If we compare that with Tasmania, in 1995 the commencing overseas student numbers went up by 15.5 per cent, and in 1996 they went down 21.9 per cent. I wonder why.

If the vice‐chancellor honestly invites us to believe that overseas students are making a choice of campus on the basis of compulsory student unionism, I would have thought the comparison between Western Australia and Tasmania would be a stark reminder to him that his assertions in the last paragraph of his letter are completely and utterly unsustainable. I am sure that the vice‐chancellor did not intend to mislead in relation to his assertions and that his suggestions were simply made out of ignorance.
I also wrote to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr David Kemp) about the plight of Miss Dare. The letter read as follows:
The plight of Karen Dare is unacceptable.
To think a student's academic career can be cut off because of her refusal to join the student union is both anachronistic and draconian.
Miss Dare has been debarred from the University of Tasmania because of her principled refusal to pay the student union fee of $253.00.

This student (an Abstudy recipient) worked last year to help her through University. Rather than finding her enterprise and initiative being rewarded she finds she must submit her conscience to the all powerful University administration or be denied her rights to study.
I urge that you take urgent action to deny the University administration the power to levy compulsory student union fees.
I await your urgent response.
And I wrote in similar terms to the state Minister for Education and Vocational Training. I have received a response from the federal minister for education and I wish to read that to the Senate:
Dear Senator Abetz
Thank you for your letter of 20 October 1997 concerning the plight of Karen Dare and compulsory student unionism at the University of Tasmania.

I am sympathetic with Ms Dare's situation and the situation of all those who are forced to pay compulsory student union fees. I am considering the Commonwealth's options on voluntary student unionism as I share your concerns. I have already sought legal advice on this issue.
I will write to you again once I have received further advice.

Let me say that thousands of students around this country would welcome that letter from Dr Kemp. We must wait and see what that further legal advice might be. But to have the sympathetic ear of the minister is something that I am sure Miss Dare is very appreciative of and something which thousands of students around this country would also appreciate.

Compulsory student unionism is a blot on tertiary life in this country. It is enforced by second‐rate shop stewards of university administrations—a comment which, I might add, the vice‐chancellor in his letter to me found both gratuitous and insulting. Let me say to him in return: if the hat fits, wear it. There is no alleged service or amenity provided by a student union in this country that is of such great moment that it requires the compulsory fee to be elevated to a claim higher than that of the student's right to obtain a tertiary education.

Miss Dare deserves our support; the university deserves our disdain. Miss Dare's courage is commendable; the university's draconian debarment of her is condemnable. Miss Dare's principles are honourable; the university's stance and action are devoid of any principle. I wish Miss Dare all the best in her fight with the university and I trust that, very shortly, we will see true voluntary student unionism and the right to freedom of association enshrined in this country for all tertiary students.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move on from student politics to an issue of concern to a lot of people—that is, the issue of drugs; not illegal drugs but legal drugs. I draw people's attention to a throwaway line in the press clippings of the most recent budget in May of this year. Fact sheet No. 7 from the Department of Health and Family Services states:

SPEECH.PARA: Two other drugs to be deleted are prescription drugs to treat minor nail infections. Their deletion from the Schedule will make up $75 million of an overall $112 in savings.
The drugs in question are terbinafine and amorolfine. Both are used for the treatment of tinea type conditions, dermatophytes, and particularly a disease called onychomycosis.

Some questions about this issue were raised in the first round of estimates after the budget. Not a great deal of information was forthcoming and a number of questions were placed on notice. But the reaction that I received from asking those questions and stirring up the issue was quite interesting. I was contacted by the Australasian College of Dermatologists, dermatologists and professors of dermatology from major teaching universities in this country—people of that ilk.

The department and Senator Herron, who was the minister at the table in the estimates committee at the time, were unable to tell me the incidence of this disease. I had been given evidence from research from the UK which indicated that the incidence of this disease in the UK was about 2.7 per cent. But I was told that we were not able to be told what the incidence of this disease was in Australia. I have since learnt from the Australasian College of Dermatologists that about half a million Australians suffer from this disease. So, depending on what you take Australia's population to be, we are fairly close to that 2.5 per cent rate of incidence. That means that about 2½ people in every 100 have this disease.

Onychomycosis is a disease that is more prevalent in the elderly. It is a disease that may or may not cause problems and is often associated with whitish‐yellow discolouring and disfigurement of either fingers or toenails. The group that I have a great deal of concern about in relation to this disease are those people who have an impairment in their peripheral vascular circulation and those people who have an immune problem. Certainly from the evidence that I have been provided with by various experts around this country, my concerns are more than well founded. The experts tell me that it can cause considerable problems for patients with diabetes, for people with peripheral vascular disease, and also for people with HIV and other immuno‐depressant conditions.

When we talk about immuno‐depressant conditions we are not just making the assumption that everybody who has that condition has something like HIV, as people may want to put all sorts of very negative and incorrect value judgments on that. We are talking about people who have had renal transplants, people who have had heart transplants, people with leukaemia, people who have a disease that is affecting their immune system and also people who are having their immune system depressed as part of their medical treatment for another problem.

We do not want these people to have a reservoir or potential reservoir of infection. That is what can cause onychomycosis. It can cause fissures and cracking in the skin in the toes. The first thing that I was taught when I was nursing was to be careful with diabetic patients and that only a podiatrist should attend to their toenail cutting and feet care. It had to be done by professionals because of the risk of getting an infection or breach of the integrity of the skin.

In the last couple of days we have seen a lot of coverage of the amputations that have been caused by the meningococcal septicaemia outbreak. They are traumatic. It is very sad and I feel very sorry for the children and families involved and affected by that, but it affects only a small number. There would be hundreds of diabetics in this country who each year lose toes, feet or legs because they have had an infection in their foot and they have ended up with dry gangrene, and the only way to treat that is to amputate. I do not have the figures but I would suggest to everybody listening—and I am sure the professionals would back me up—that a number of these amputations could have been avoided if the patients had been cured of onychomycosis because that disease would have contributed to their problem.

The treatment that the department and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has said should be used is griseofulvin, not terbinafine which is taken orally. The research that I have been provided with indicates that griseofulvin has a maximum efficacy rate, a cure rate, of 40 per cent and the length of treatment time required is between 18 months and two years. The efficacy of terbinafine, depending on which source you read, can be as high as 80 or 90 per cent for a three‐month course.

One of the problems that people face with the prescription and the use of medication is patient compliance. If you asked somebody to comply to regularly take medication every day for two years you would have a much greater risk of non-compliance than if you asked somebody to take medication for only three months. Any woman who has had to take the oral contraceptive pill will certainly be aware that it is not a hard thing to do to forget the damn thing. But we are not talking about the risk of pregnancy here; we are talking about the risk of losing a limb if this disease cannot be cured.

BREAK.PARA: I have grave concerns that terbinafine will be off the PBS list from 1 November this year. It will make it impossible for anybody, except the very wealthy, to be able to afford to undertake a three‐month course. It has certainly been put to me by the experts in the field that by far, whilst terbinafine might be more expensive, it is certainly more cost‐effective than griseofulvin. It has less side effects than griseofulvin. It has less drug interactions than griseofulvin. It is the side effects and drug interactions of griseofulvin that will cause less patient compliance and reduce the potential 40 per cent cure rate.

From one of my sources at the Royal Perth Hospital, we also know that onychomycosis is endemic in the Aboriginal population. If it is not cleared up it is also a source of constant reinfection. This is of course a major concern.

From questioning the department about this we have been told that the cost-effectiveness was not the reason for the decision. Financial considerations was the reason for the decision. In answer to a question I put on notice at the Community Affairs Legislation Committee hearing on 19 August at page 114 of the Hansard, the department responded:

The differences between terbinafine and griseofulvin, in terms of efficacy and safety, were taken into account when terbinafine was listed on the PBS and provided justification for the higher price for terbinafine.
I take that as an admission from the department that the efficacy and safety of terbinafine is superior to that of griseofulvin. The department then went on to say:

The relative merits of the two drugs was not a factor in the decision to delist terbinafine. It is recognised that griseofulvin is a less effective drug, however, the issue is the appropriateness of the public sector expenditure resulting from the inappropriate use of terbinafine and its use for minor cases.

Every one of the doctors and professors, and most of them are professors, who have written to me have all pleaded and requested that this drug remain on the PBS. They are quite happy for the authorisation of laboratory confirmation of fungal infection to be necessary before the drug is prescribed. That is what the profession would like. That is what the profession wants. This is from the group of people who are involved in treating this disease.
