I think it ill behoves this government to go out there and talk about being caring, sharing and warm and fuzzy because in this situation it is not.

It strikes me as being very interesting that the minister has determined that he has a very major interest in diabetes. That is commendable because it is a major disease. It is a disease that is increasing in prevalence, particularly amongst the older age group. The minister has made the following commitments: he has identified diabetes as a national health priority. He has committed the Commonwealth government to the establishment of a diabetes register. He has given a commitment to the development of specific programs for high risk groups. Through his Ministerial Advisory Committee on Diabetes, $7.7 million has been made available for a national diabetes strategy. He has agreed to the Commonwealth entering into a $5 million joint venture with the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation of Australia for IDDM research.

They are very worthy commitments but when you compare them with the removal of terbinafine in particular from the PBS then I have grave concerns. That is a public show of `Yes, I am interested, but my actions are not the same as my words'. The actions are of trying to save money and hang the consequences.

As I said, we know that maintaining skin integrity of feet, particularly for diabetics, is of major concern. Two drugs are being removed from the PBS that will help to maintain skin integrity and remove the potential for fungal infections. The Australian Podiatry Council is also concerned. They state:
Individuals with diabetes commonly present with chronic fungal skin and nail conditions and often do not respond to conservative topical treatments.

Terbinafine is an oral preparation. That drug is able to get into the system as opposed to topical treatment, which is when the treatment is placed on the surface of the skin. Topical applications are not able to get underneath the nail and into the nail bed where the infection may well be. The systemic drug, the oral drug, is able to do that. The council is con cerned that the fungal infections do not respond to conservative topical treatments. They also state:

There is a greater risk of bacterial supra‐infection and in the presence of peripheral complications, could be a potential trigger for ulceration, hospitalisation or amputation. The presence of chronic infection is known to contribute to persistently elevated blood glucose levels.
That means more instability for the person's diabetic condition.
Furthermore, ongoing fungal foot and nail infections may impede mobility and activity level, further impacting on diabetes control.

I have outlined today a number of reasons why this drug should not be removed from the PBS. From the information I have received, the experts were not consulted by the department or the government about the treatment and control of this disease. It was a decision made purely for money reasons alone. I think for that reason the government stands condemned.

This is a further attack upon Australians and obviously older Australians. The government does not care about the conditions that they dismiss as being peripheral, simple and of no major consequence. But the medical profession across Australia obviously identifies this issue as a significant concern and of major importance. It is an issue that I will continue to highlight to this government until we get something done about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent announcement of the government's response to the fair trading report `New Deal—Fair Deal' has met with tremendous, in fact unprecedented support from small business organisations around the country. Even the opposition have given it a tick. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, is to be congratulated for putting together a package that responds so timely and comprehensively to the needs of small business in their dealings with big business.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to raise the matter of a separate small business issue which relates to a taxation obstacle to competitiveness. Simply put, if you are a small retailer, you pay more sales tax per item than big business. So you either charge more or you have smaller margins. Either way, it is hard to compete. It is killing our independent retail sector, which is losing market share at the rate of two to three per cent every year. In June 1975, the independent sector had 60 per cent of the retail grocery market. Last year, they had 23 per cent. I am told by reliable sources that that could even have slipped two to three per cent this year. No other comparable country in the world allows so much market share to end up in the hands of so few. The fair trading report stated:
United States antitrust laws limit the market share of the three largest food retailers to 17% of the market.
The top three food retailers in the United States have some 12.1% of the retail market.
The big three food retailers in the United Kingdom share 28% of the market.

Unless this discrimination in the way sales tax is applied is addressed, small business runs the risk of losing the critical mass level of market share needed to survive. This issue tilts the field in favour of big retailers simply because they are big business. It helps them acquire more market power every year, not because they are more efficient or use economies of scale, but simply because they have their own warehouses and can apply sales tax prior to freight and service fees, and so on.

The impact of this discrimination is widely felt. Australia's independent warehouse wholesaler, Davids, had a share price of $1.15 in June and it is now 69c. Davids is crucial to the operation of independent retailers, yet this sales tax issue is crippling the ability of their customers to maintain a viable market share against the large retail chains.

The National Association of Retail Grocers of Australia says that the effect of the way sales tax is applied virtually hands the big retailers a $120 million subsidy every year. This is a huge free kick in front of the competition goal posts and results in the average small business grocer paying an extra $12,000 to $15,000 per year in tax, which makes it very difficult to compete with the big stores from the outset.

BREAK.PARA: The way it works is that independent retailers buy through a wholesaler while the major supermarkets buy into their own warehouses. This results in the chains paying tax on the manufacturer's selling price without taking into account freight and warehouse costs. However, independents must pay tax on the wholesaler's selling price which includes freight charged by the manufacturer and the warehouse margin. In addition, the large chains are able to base their tax calculations on the manufacturer's price net of all rebates. They can strip out discounts, allowances, rebates and settlements. But independents are unable to take into account their rebates when calculating the tax they must pay. They have to pay on the full price, not the discounted or net price. This can amount to a very substantial amount of money. In this way, major supermarket chains are receiving a competitive advantage of some $120 million a year over their small independent competitors.

Independents in rural and far flung areas are likely to be the worst affected by the impact of sales tax on freight. We must remember that there are thousands of independent stores throughout country Australia. Many towns are too small for large retailers like Coles, Woolworths and Franklins. So country people have to bear the brunt of these increased costs. This encourages the demise of smaller towns as people decide to make the trip to larger regional centres to get the price advantages.

It is important to point out that the inequity does not arise as a result of any superior efficiency by the chains. It has nothing to do with buying power or market power. The independent warehouses have the negotiating strength to buy from manufacturers at a similar price to the chains. They also have similar warehousing and distribution costs and provide similar retail services such as advertising, retail counselling, space management and IT support. But because sales tax is applied at the last wholesale price, the independent retailer ends up paying 13 per cent or more in extra sales tax on a wide range of items. Independent retailers pay around 2.5c more for a can of Pal and around 3c more on a bottle of Coke, compared to the chains.

For every $100 worth of groceries sold, an average independent grocer will pay 75 cents more in sales tax than the big chains. If the average weekly grocery turnover is $30,000—and that would be a very small grocery shop—the small business operator is paying $225 more in tax per week and $12,000 more sales tax per year than the big business competitor pays on the same volume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say $225 a week?

—That is right. I know that surprises Senator O'Chee who is very interested in small business. Where net profit margins are in the order of two, three or four per cent, as they tend to be in this industry, it is extremely difficult for small business to compete successfully. If average weekly grocery sales are $80,000, then the independent is paying an extra $31,200 per year in tax above what the big chain competition is required to pay.

BREAK.PARA: The way sales tax is applied it effectively discriminates against small business and plays a significant role in the steady decline of the market share of independents every year. Furthermore, as pointed out by the national association of retail grocers, the cost to government has reached more than $40 million a year from sales tax no longer paid due to the increase in market share of the chains from 40 per cent to more than 75 per cent over the last 20 years.

The association makes the observation that for every one per cent of market share that shifts from the independents to the big chains, sales tax revenue actually drops by $1.5 million. The way that sales tax is being applied serves only to help the chains grow at the expense of the independents.

Competition in Australia's retail sector is stifled by the market power held in just three hands. Coles, Myers and Woolworths now share between them around 63 per cent of the market. Yesterday, the Managing Director of Woolworths said that by the year 2000, the top two food retailers will have 70 per cent of the market. Right now, small business in the food sector runs the risk of losing its critical mass level. They simply cannot afford to give up any more market share if their distribution system is to remain viable.

An annual handicap of $12,000 makes it extraordinarily difficult for small business operators to compete—and that would be only a very small store. Imagine the alternative uses for that $12,000, or $31,200 if the grocer has weekly sales of $80,000, especially in terms of increasing employment. It is not just happening in the food sector. Hardware stores, newsagents and pharmacies are all affected by this inequitable way of applying sales tax.

This government has pledged to support newsagents and pharmacies in the Hilmer review process. But if government submissions are overridden by the competition tribunal and large chains are able to move further in on these retailers, then there will be a totally unacceptable increase in market power to the retail giants, aided and abetted by this inequitable application of sales tax.

Woolworths has just posted a 10.66 per cent increase in first quarter sales. The Financial Review reported yesterday that Managing Director of Woolworths, Reg Clairs, said that Big W grew partly because it had successfully competed against chemists in the cosmetics market and against stationery suppliers in the office supply sector.

Wherever sales tax is applied, these big chains have an in‐built advantage which helps them take market share off independent family owned businesses. The whole situation discriminates against small business and their ability to compete, through no fault of their own. The discrimination results in more small businesses going to the wall, less competition in an already highly concentrated market and ties up valuable capital which could be used to improve competitiveness and boost employment.

The situation has reached a critical stage which must be addressed before the continued viability of the independent sector is compromised. With the present rate of market share shifting to the chains, the independent sector cannot afford to wait for major tax reform several years down the track. By then they would have lost another six to eight per cent of market share and their viability would be unsustainable.

This issue must be addressed now. Australia has allowed these retail giants to accumulate all this market power. The current system of sales tax is helping them get more and is handing more market share to the big retailers on a platter. Now comes the crunch. Do we let them take over everything or do we give small business an even break by making both big and small pay sales tax at the same point in the retail chain? What could be fairer and more equitable than that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise as a matter of public interest and importance today the vexed question of youth unemployment and the government's work for the dole pilot scheme, particularly as it affects New South Wales. When the government first announced its plans to establish this scheme, it had intended to select just 70 groups to provide work for 10,000 young recipients on a trial basis. After applications for sponsors opened, in the first week alone almost 100 organisations had already applied to participate in the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: This overwhelming response and demand led the government to announce last week that the number of work for the dole projects would be expanded to 178. A total of 10,434 places will be available for participants, of whom at least 80 per cent will be young people between 18 and 24 years old.

As it stands, 630 applications for funding have been received. Hundreds of additional projects will be considered next year. This leads to the question as to why the government has implemented work for the dole in the first place and why it has generated such a positive community response.

The Sydney Morning Herald reported recently that 3.3 million full-time retrenchments had occurred since 1986. With the teenage full-time unemployment trend rate at around 29 per cent when the coalition took government in 1996, there is no doubt that a proportion of these jobs were those of young people in industries which are now all but obsolete.

It is clear that after 13 years in power Labor failed to adequately address one of the great est serious challenges facing our nation—that of youth unemployment. When the coalition came to office, youth unemployment was as high as 30 per cent in some regional areas of Australia.

The Working Nation program, which was Labor's response to the unemployment crisis, was—I think it is fair to say—a dismal failure. Between July 1990 and March 1996, Labor's policies added only an additional 7,100 full‐time jobs. Many Working Nation programs simply did not lead to real jobs. For example, only 22 per cent of participants in the new work opportunities program ended up in unsubsidised employment, despite it costing over $10,000 per person to participate in the program.

Work for the dole is therefore a necessary scheme, in abroader range of initiatives, to tackle youth unemployment. Communities are prepared to financially support people who do not have a job. In return, it is fair and reasonable to ask those receiving this support to put something back into their community for a couple of days a week.

The federal government provided $21.6 million in the May 1997 budget for the work for the dole initiative. More than $15 million is provided to fund projects and participant allowances. The remaining funds are for monitoring, assessment and administration. Twenty to 30 pilots will take place in regional and rural areas with high levels of unemployment. It is expected that several thousand young people will work on projects under these pilots. Participants will work for two six‐hour days if aged 18 to 20, and 2½ six‐hour days if 20 or over. Participants will be paid an extra $10 a week in recognition of the unavoidable costs of working.

Projects will be for a minimum of three and a maximum of 12 months. Organisations selected to participate in the scheme and future participants have been or will be selected on the basis of criteria which include: the capacity of the sponsor to monitor and maintain the project; the extent of contribution and support for the particular project that comes from the local community; the quality of community involvement; and the willing ness to support the participants after completion of placement.

All projects must directly benefit the community and not a private business. A condition of each project is that it does not replace or substitute for paid jobs. A person may be required to participate in a work for the dole project only if they are in receipt of the full unemployment allowance and there is no risk to personal health or any other contravention of occupational health and safety standards.

Projects must provide participants with a variety of tasks, challenges and responsibility, opportunities to work in teams and mix with people and, perhaps most importantly, a sense of pride in their work and achievements. While some projects may include a training element, theobjective is to instil the discipline of the workplace and to help break the cycle of unproductive activity and isolation that many young people experience and which is so soul destroying. The work for the dole initiative is based on a principle of mutual obligation.

I turn to some examples in NSW of some of these valuable projects. New South Wales has a total of 54 projects with 4021 participants. The variety and nature of the work offered to the young unemployed are truly encouraging. Whilst developing skills in various fields and being exposed to a work ethic, young people are also able to make a positive contribution to many worthwhile projects.

The following are some prime examples in New South Wales. The Penrith 2000 Olympics regatta project in Sydney is to be carried out in conjunction with the Penrith Lakes Development Corporation, the Olympic Coordination Authority and Penrith council. Work includes the planting of wetland plants in the practice and catchment lakes of the Sydney International Regatta Centre, which will improve rowing conditions and rejuvenation of the Nepean River adjacent to the regatta centre.

It is expected that the Nepean River site will be visited by thousands of local and overseas tourists before and during the 2000 Olympics. A walkway along the Nepean River from Penrith station to the regatta centre has been proposed. In addition to gaining job skills, the participants working on the project will be making a rewarding contribution to both the environment and the staging of the all‐important 2000 Olympic Games.

The early migrant oral history project involves the publishing of oral history of migrants in the historic St George community in the Hurstville area. Participants will interview selected residents, and document and publish their stories. They will also collect and reproduce historic photographs.

The participants will learn a variety of interview and communication techniques and gain some practical experience in using recording devices, dictaphones, photographic replication equipment, computers, and desktop publishing software. Besides gaining practical skills, participants will gain an appreciation of the experiences of local migrants and help preserve local community heritage. It is making the links in a community that is going to be so important in that project.

Other projects include Mission Australia at Cabramatta Multicultural Employment Services and the restoration of community sites. A very important one is the CSA Training Services' Royal National Park preservation of sites, which aims to involve indigenous young people in midden stabilisation, campsite revegetation, track restoration and nursery establishment.

The Liverpool Regional Museum project at Liverpool involves renovation of the Liverpool Regional Museum. The Bankstown Aviation Museum project provides work experience for participants in conjunction with the development of the Bankstown Aviation Museum.

The Blue Mountains community work for the dole project will be work experience with community organisations, involving office work, building and grounds maintenance, and personal care. Leichhardt Uniting Church recreation and socialisation in aged care project will assist in providing care and support for the elderly. The Salvation Army build a boat project involves construction of a boat in inner Sydney.

BREAK.PARA: In regional NSW the variety and importance of projects are again apparent. The Cootamundra Workskills project at West Wyalong includes entry beautification, the West Wyalong green corridor extension and the painting of heritage shop facades. The Barmedman main street and mineral pool projects will beautify shopfronts and street‐scapes.

The Tamworth Training Services will provide work experience in the all‐important tourism and hospitality sector. In Shoalhaven, the employment and training group will provide work experience in hospitals, aged care centres, golf club and churches. The Lions Club of Hunter Wallsend and the Shortland Wetlands Centre at Maryland project will include: construction of a new entry and walkway to the main visitors centre; construction of an exhibition centre; a sensory trail; improvement and extension of the existing walking trail; and rehabilitation of the wetland. In my home town of Wagga Wagga, Mission Australia will be involved in the establishment of a shopfront where collected clothing is recycled and sold to the public.

But the scheme must be viewed as part of a whole-of-government approach and cannot be looked at in isolation. It is part of an overall package to deal with one of the biggest issues facing our nation—youth unemployment. In conjunction with work for the dole, the government is delivering on its promise to increase genuine job opportunities for young Australians. The new national apprenticeship system will provide trainees with world-class skills, giving Australian businesses a competitive edge in the global economy.

The federal government will provide a total of more than $1.3 billion for vocational education and training in 1997‐98. It includes $265 million for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in 1997-98. The new apprenticeships and traineeships will be in high-growth industries, such as technology, finance, tourism and hospitality, sport and the traditional trades. In 1996-97 there was a record level of traineeship commencements—more than 51,000 commencements—representing a 44 per cent increase on the previous year.

For the first time, under the new apprenticeship system the skills and qualifications of all new apprentices and trainees will be recognised in all states and territories, greatly expanding job and career options. Employers can choose who will deliver the off-the-job training for their apprentices and trainees—either a private provider or a public TAFE provider. It will be easier for employers to hire an apprentice or a trainee. One-stop apprenticeship shops will combine Commonwealth and state services under one roof. Students will be able to earn while they learn by combining a paid new apprenticeship with their secondary education.

A package of measures totalling more than $187 million over four years has been established to expand vocational education and training in schools. This will expand career options and opportunities for the 60 per cent of students not going to full-time university or TAFE.

In its first term, the government has committed almost four times as much funding for vocational education training in schools as the Labor Party provided over 13 years. In calendar year 1998, $891 million will be provided for TAFE and other training providers through the Australian National Training Authority. This will build on the additional 43,000 student places forecast to be available this year through Commonwealth growth funding.

Community interest in the scheme shows that the scheme has popular support. Whilst unemployment continues, unfortunately, to be one of the greatest challenges facing Australia, it is pleasing to note that under the coalition government the situation is improving slowly. DSS figures showed that more that 11,000 jobseekers got off the dole queue in September. The 1.7 per cent drop caused the total number of jobseekers to fall to 660,167 from the previous month. The 11,244—or 3.5 per cent—decrease in the number of short-term jobseekers was indeed welcome news.

Work for the dole is but one initiative, but it is an important initiative in combating youth unemployment together with the other initiatives. There were so many suitable projects around the country and, as this is a pilot initiative, an attempt is now being made to select the widest range of project types possible as well as to achieve a broad geographical spread of projects. It is very good news for those young people who will be able to access the undoubted benefits of this initiative and break the cycle of despair of youth unemployment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Western Reds Rugby League Football Club

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the matters of public interest debate today to take an unusual tack. I want to raise a Western Australian concern, which is the announcement of the closure of the Western Reds Rugby League Football Club. While it is a sporting issue in one sense, I want to reflect on a few issues that emanate from that decision that I think ought to be of concern in the community generally, because it does raise questions about the impact of professional sport and the values of professional sport that we are teaching our children. There are issues there that we must address.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons that I join the debate today is to give voice to the disappointment of those members and supporters of the Western Reds Rugby League Football Club, who were shocked and extremely disappointed when an announcement was made at a press conference that the club had closed.

On the following day, the members received—as I did—a letter from the club, indicating that the decision had been taken to close the club, because they were not to be invited into the 1998 competition. That one‐page letter from the club was effectively the end of the members' and supporters' involvement with a club that had been in existence for three years and of which many people, myself included, had been members for those three years.

I think it is a very sad aspect of professional sport that members and supporters can be treated in this way—that the overriding concerns of professional sport concentrate on TV coverage, on the interests of television companies and of the major sponsors. I am no Luddite; I do not fail to recognise the changes that have occurred in sport and the need for sponsorship and the impact of modern commercial realities. But it is extremely disappointing and worrying when these sorts of things occur without any membership involvement, without any participation or consultation with the people who are drawn into the life of the club and drawn into supporting and being involved in a team in whatever code of sport.

On this occasion, members were not consulted or involved and were merely informed suddenly that the club they had supported for three years had closed. People had developed an emotional and financial involvement with that enterprise. People had been members for up to three years. They had bought game seats. They had bought the merchandise—the caps, the shirts, the badges. They had shown loyalty; it had become part of their lives in the way that many of us who belong to sporting clubs do let a team become part of our lives. But, because of the dispute between Super League and the ARL and the associated developments in rugby league, the decision to close the only Western Australian based club was taken.

There are some real implications there for the future of sport, the values we are teaching our children and the values which we hold as a community. I do not think it is acceptable to say, `That's professional sport, that's the way it is. You have to cop it.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You Western Australians won't have a decent football code anymore!

—Senator Macdonald, as a rugby union man, I was a late convert to rugby league. But this experience has certainly soured my view of the game, as it has soured the view of a lot of supporters. I will come to that in a moment, because I think it does have implications for the level of support the sport will enjoy in Western Australia in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that lots of other clubs and people have been through this before, and this is not a new experience. I know the supporters of Fitzroy in the AFL and obviously Hunter in the Super League competition are currently going through similar sorts of experiences, so I do not claim there is anything unique about the experience of the Western Reds. But it was brought home to me when I had to explain it to my six‐year‐old son, whom I had taken along to the games in the last year or so, together with my father.

My six‐year‐old son has become quite an enthusiastic supporter—although he seems to enjoy the marching girls as much as he does the rugby, I must say! He is learning to read and he noticed the story on the back of the West Australian newspaper and asked me about it. I had a great deal of difficulty explaining to him what had occurred and what was going on here. I said, `Well, the club's closed. They're not playing next year. No, we won't be going next year.' This is at the same time as I am trying to teach him about the proper values of sport—that sport is for enjoyment, it is about taking part. I am trying to teach him not to be too competitive, to teach him about loyalty to the team and the club, and playing sport for all the positive values that it can encourage in young people. I was very hard‐pressed to explain what seemed to be a very cynical decision in terms of the future of the club that he had come to support.

A couple of days later he noticed another aspect of professional sport which was a report, again in the West Australian, which referred to the fact that a prominent member of the Fremantle Dockers Australian Rules football team—Mr Matthew—better known as `Spider'—Burton, might not be on their playing list next year. Spider Burton is a bit of a cult figure in Western Australia, and small boys in particular seem to like and admire him greatly. I do not know whether it is because he is almost seven feet tall, but he has this sort of appeal to both young and old. He is a very committed footballer and, by all reports, is a very genuine and well respected young man. But this report was about how, because of injury problems and the issues of the salary cap, he may not be invited to play with the team again next year.

Again, I had to try to explain to my son why Spider Burton perhaps would not be playing with the Fremantle Dockers next season. What do I say to him about the values involved in that? It is very hard to explain about the salary cap and the commercial pressures on the club. The fact that the player had given loyal service and was a committed and skilful player were not really considerations that were going to be prominent in decisions about his future.

As Western Australians will know, there has been a similar debate about Peter Sumich from the West Coast Eagles, who is a very well regarded Western Australian footballer and, obviously, there are a number of footballers who have been traded in the draft recently and have gone to other states and clubs.

I found all these things very hard to explain to my son. I think they raise serious issues about the values we are teaching young people and what they can learn from professional sport in this country and internationally. I do not have the answers to these concerns. I raise them because I think it is important that we start to debate some of these issues.

It is also my intention to place on the record the disappointment of supporters and to give voice to their concerns, a number of which have been raised with me by fellow members of the club. I indicate also that this is not a criticism of the club's administrators or its chairman, Mr Stephen Edwards, who I think have done a good job in all the circumstances. It is not their fault. It is a question of the commercial realities and the decisions of the owners of the competition, but it is a very disappointing development.

I also place on record our thanks to the players. Despite not being in the finals, the Western Reds always gave good entertainment and wholehearted commitment. They were a good team to follow. We had full commitment from the players, who earned the respect of the supporters and the Western Australian public generally. But I do think that this development has seriously harmed the future of rugby league in Western Australia. It has made people far more cynical about sport and rugby league. I do not want to enter into the debate about Super League versus the ARL—I have failed to be impressed by either side in this dispute, because I do not think it has ever been about sport or the interests of rugby league—but the decision in relation to the Western Reds has set rugby league back a long way in Western Australia. There are a number of supporters and members who will be far more reluctant next time to commit themselves to joining and supporting a rugby league club in Western Australia. That is a sad thing, but people have been burnt by the experience, and I think they are now more cynical.

It is of more importance to really ask questions about this sort of decision and activity in professional sport—that is, the closing of clubs for financial reasons or for purposes driven by television needs, the transfer of players and the buying and selling of players. All these things really send out messages that run contrary to what we all profess to want to teach our children, and what we want to encourage in sport. I think we are giving a very mixed message about sport in this country. I do not pretend to have the answers. I think we do have to look at the development of professional sport and some of the values that surround it and ask ourselves whether those are really the examples and the values that we want to be encouraging, and have our children observe and mimic, as undoubtedly they will.

The sorts of values I described earlier—that is, encouraging sport for enjoyment, the taking part, the friendships, the physical activity, the learning of positive interaction with others and loyalty—are far more important values and I think they are threatened by some of the developments in professional sport. They are certainly not values one would learn from observing professional sport or some of the developments that accompany professional sport in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, can you explain what precisely are the consequences for the government's IT outsourcing strategy of your as yet unexplained decision to dismantle the former Department of Administrative Services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question from Senator Murphy on IT. It is nice to see a new face on this issue. A number of senators have raised this issue. IT outsourcing is an important policy which this government has further developed from the previous government. An interesting report on IT outsourcing was brought down by the Labor Party which recognised the importance of IT outsourcing.

ANSWER.PARA: I have here a brief from the Minister for Finance and Administration on the issue of the implications for IT outsourcing of the merger of DAS and Finance. You will be aware, Senator Murphy, that on 5 October 1997 the government announced that the Department of Administrative Services would be abolished and its functions transferred to other agencies, including the new Department of Finance and Administration.

The change will have a minimal impact on the OGIT cluster 3 outsourcing initiative, which will now comprise the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Australian Industrial Property Organisation, the Australian Electoral Commission and the former DAS customer base now being managed by the Department of Finance and Administration.IT support for DAS functions transferred to the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism will remain in cluster 3. I am advised by the minister that cluster 3 remains a very viable and attractive cluster. It will be one of the largest IT outsourcing contracts to the private sector to date. So IT outsourcing is a very important initiative.

Outsourcing is a policy which the Labor Party has long supported. After all, it was the Labor Party which outsourced the development of most of its ideas to the ACTU. So outsourcing is not a problem for the Labor Party, as I said.
Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —George Campbell agrees with me. You are absolutely right, George. That is the brief which has been supplied to me by the Minister for Finance and Adminis tration and I think it fully answers the question that Senator Murphy raised.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. The minister's attention would undoubtedly have been drawn to today's demonstration outside Parliament House and the mischievous and totally inaccurate claims about the government's 10‐point plan, including claims that the 10‐ point plan extinguishes native title. Will the minister explain the true position regarding the 10‐point plan and also how the current Native Title Act is unable to deal with the possibility of co‐existing titles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for his question. Senator Abetz is one of the few members of parliament who really does understand native title and he has developed quite an expertise on the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: The Native Title Act amendments have clearly been subject to quite a sustained campaign of misinformation. There are a lot of well‐meaning Australians, including the defenders of native title who we saw outside Parliament House today, who have been misled and who do not really understand the nature of the act, the Mabo decision, the Wik decision and its inter‐relationship with the Native Title Act amendments, and what the Native Title Act amendments are designed to achieve.

It must be remembered that the Native Title Act is clearly deficient. My good friends in the opposition understand the deficiencies in the Native Title Act and accept that the Native Title Act clearly is not designed to deal with the consequences of the Wik decision. We must remember that the Wik decision has more than doubled the area of Australia that is potentially claimable as native title land. The most important point to remember—and I wish the opposition would listen to this—is that the bill does not extinguish native title on pastoral leases.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish! That's a lie.
—There is no extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases.
—That is a lie.
—That was a position urged on us by many in the community. Many in the community preferred that the government go to the point of extinguishing native title on pastoral leases.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Firstly, I think it is disgraceful that the minister is not allowed to answer a question that is so important to the nation. Secondly, I heard on two separate occasions the senator opposite say that that was a lie. It is clearly unparliamentary and ought to be withdrawn.
—Senator Bolkus, I think you should withdraw.
—Madam President, the Deputy Prime Minister talked about bucket loads of extinguishment. Senator Minchin says something else. One of them must not be telling the truth, but I withdraw.
—Senator Bolkus, there is an opportunity later to debate these issues.

—As I said, the Native Title Act amendments do not involve the extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases. We have accepted the Wik decision in full. The Wik decision said that native title may not necessarily have been extinguished on pastoral leases.

BREAK.PARA: I draw the attention of the parliament to the deficiencies in the current act. It was not designed to deal with the possibility of native title surviving on pastoral leases. It is like a model‐T Ford that you put on the racetrack in Melbourne for the Grand Prix—it is simply not up to the job. The Native Title Act has to be redesigned to accommodate the fact that we must now deal with the co‐existence of native title on pastoral leases—something which the Native Title Act was not intended to do, and the ALP well knows that.

It was passed on the presumption that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases. As a reflection of the failing of the current act and the current arrangements, we now have in the native title system over 600 claims covering nearly 50 per cent of the Australian mainland, and we have had only one determination. After five years of native title, four years of the Native Title Act, we have had one determination, and that was by agreement. The only Australians who are exercising determined native title rights are in fact the Murray Islanders. They are the only people in Australia who actually are exercising today determined native title rights.

The current act has virtually no threshold test, and you know that. We have the real and manifest problem of multiple and overlapping claims right around Australia. These are causing conflict within Aboriginal communities as well as between Aborigines and other Australians. We have absolutely no workable agreements provisions in the current act. It is a major deficiency in the current act, one that we will fix. The current system is collapsing under the weight of the system which it was not designed to cope with. The current act is simply not delivering for any Australians, including Aboriginal Australians.

What we will do in the Native Title Amendment Bill is fix up those problems. We will incorporate the Wik decision into the Native Title Act to ensure that we have a workable system of coexistence on pastoral leases and one which reflects the native title decision found in Wik—that is, that, where native title has survived on a pastoral lease, the pastoralists' rights will prevail. The effect of the current Native Title Act is actually to reverse that decision and means that pastoralists may well be finding themselves acting illegally in exercising legal rights under their lease, and that was made clear in the Attorney-General's advice which was released in January. I think that is the issue which most Australians fail to accommodate. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I refer to last night's rejection by Labor, and the other minor parties, of the small business exemption from unfair dismissal laws. What impact will this have on job prospects, particularly for Australia's young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for that question because she is absolutely right. It will have a very serious and negative impact on all Australians who are looking for jobs.
—Demonstrate that, Dick!

—I will and I will quote some very useful supporting evidence. The fact is that very many young Australians were looking forward to a decent Christmas present—the opportunity to get a full‐time job. What we have seen as a result of this negative, short‐sighted, opportunistic decision, simply pandering to your trade union masters, is once again a cruel blow, not only to those young people looking for work but also for small businesses which are desperately keen to expand.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been described as a confidence building initiative and it would have been just that. It would have provided the opportunity to allow them to be free from the very onerous obligations that could be imposed from long drawn‐out litigation that small business is particularly ill‐equipped to cope with. We are not the first ones to recognise this. You can go back to 1982 when the Wran government actually introduced an employment protection act which recognised special considerations for firms with less than 15 employees. So this is very bad news indeed for the work force and particularly the small business sector.

Cheryl Kernot, of course, recognised this when she told Mr Reith in November 1996 that the Democrats would support exempting small business from the harsh, unjust and unreasonable section of the Workplace Relations Act in relation to unfair dismissals. Of course, the Labor Party itself knows that this would be good news for small business but they are simply not allowed by their trade union masters to go down this path. They are utterly beholden.

The tragedy of Labor's approach on this and a whole range of issues is that they somehow think they can reinvent themselves by looking offshore and pointing to Tony Blair. The fact is that Tony Blair happens to be the political son that Margaret Thatcher never had. You continue to demonise Tony Blair when, in fact, as Paul Kelly said in today's Australian, Blair has accepted Thatcher's `reforms of deregulation, privatisation and laws that weaken union power.'

What has happened, of course, is that both Cheryl Kernot and Kim Beazley have fallen for the blur rather than the Blair. They think that somehow a few stage‐managed soft events will substitute for the hard yard. They think politics is the land of the photo opportunity; that a few hand‐wringing gestures to interest groups and a couple of doe‐eyed smiles for the TV cameras will get you across the line. The fact is, of course, that if you really want to take notice of Blair you will look at his policies and you will understand what he is about. Let me tell you what he told the trade union movement only last month. He said, `You should remember in everything you do that fairness at work starts with the chance of a job in the first place.' Absolutely right!

Make no mistake about it, Tony Blair would have supported this legislation. Tony Blair knows that small business is the engine of growth. Small business is where people look to for job opportunities. But you lot, because you are locked in the mire, because you are not allowed to do anything the trade union movement does not approve of, you put the interest of young Australians last. It is a great tragedy. I suggest you use the Christmas period to go off and study Tony Blair in action. Look at what he really stands for.

Don't just look at a few television grabs and think he looks like a nice bloke. You have a got a decent bloke leading you and he is taking you nowhere; that is your problem. Even Cheryl Kernot recognised that the other day. Asked if he would inspire, after a preg nant pause she said, `Well, you know, he is a decent bloke.' What a devastating indictment of your leader. You will have to do a lot better than that for small business. (Time expired)

You would think that, after 13 years of Labor government, if they were so concerned about aged care and the future of elderly people in this country, they would have done something about this long ago. They are proposing death duties now I notice, so that is their answer for the future. Let the elderly Australians beware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister blames the Labor Party apparently for this government policy. The minister says that the Labor Party is disgraceful. Minister, why should the Labor Party and members of the Australian community not consider that your government is disgraceful and cruel if a minister of the Crown cannot come into this parliament and answer simple questions like: how many service pensioners will have to go into debt to meet the government's entry fees; how many war widows will have to sell their home to access suitable care? You criticised Labor. You criticised the government's critics. These people are entitled to answers.

—Once again, that is a disgraceful campaign to frighten elderly people. I would like to put a few more facts on the record. I have spent some time putting some on, now I will put on some more. In the 10‐year history of the hostels reform project that the previous government introduced for hostels but was not prepared to move on for nursing homes, the average bond was $26½ thousand. That was the average bond over 10 years in the hostels. In the view of the government, there is no reason why the bonds for nursing homes will be substantially different from that. In addition, only two per cent of hostel bonds were over $80,000. So that gives you some idea of the magnitude of this issue. Let us not forget that older people have a number of choices as to how they meet the accommodation bond if they are liable for an accommodation bond, which many will not be. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Rod Kemp. I refer to today's excellent result on the consumer price index which shows that the Howard government is continuing to keep inflation at record low levels. Will the minister please inform the Senate of the impact on inflation, interest rates and, more importantly, job prospects if the government's policies were to be abandoned in favour of Labor's increased deficit, high income tax and big spending proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Ferris, for that important question. The truth of the matter is that today's CPI result is excellent news. Underlying inflation rose just 0.3 per cent in the September quarter and just 1.5 per cent in the year to September. This is the lowest underlying rate of inflation in the 25-year history of the series. Reflecting the very significant falls in mortgage rates achieved since the coalition's election victory, headline inflation fell 0.3 per cent in the year to September and, as we already know, there were substantial falls in mortgage interest charges. This is great news for the Australian economy, and it is one of the many achievements of this government.

ANSWER.PARA: I was reminded that, prior to the last election, the former Prime Minister—we called him `Mr Keating', but apparently the Labor Party called him `Captain Whacky', and for good reason—said:
They—
that is, the coalition—
won't have an accord. They won't have a consensual wage model in the economy. They won't have that cooperation. They won't have low inflation and they won't, therefore, have low interest rates.

How absolutely wrong can you get. That was the platform and the sorts of scare tactics that the Labor Party tried to run with before the last election. We are seeing in other areas the typical Labor attempt at scare tactics, but that was a classic case of where the former Prime Minister was dead, dead wrong. The consumer price index confirms that inflation is entrenched at very low levels. Regrettably, Mrs Cheryl `Left of Labor' Kernot recently said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ho, ho, ho.

—You would be interested in this. This is your latest recruit. Apparently all those people in your party were not good enough to get an advanced track to the front bench, but your latest recruit said, `Low inflation means high unemployment.' That is what she said.
—What?
—Yes, former Senator Kernot said, `Low inflation means high unemployment.' I am delighted to see Senator Woodley shaking his head in disbelief.

ANSWER.PARA: Nothing could be further from the truth. History shows that those countries which keep inflation under control tend to enjoy more quickly growing economies. Low inflation is critical to achieving sustained growth, and what all Australians want is sustained growth. Perhaps Mrs Kernot will change her mind now that 74,000 jobs were created in the last month, with 19,000 jobs created on average in each of the last three months.

With the appalling record of the Labor Party on inflation, their appalling record on interest rates, the recession that we had to have and the catastrophic effects that that had on families and small business, it is incredible that there are so many Labor failed Keating ministers still on that front bench. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can you please further detail proposals which have been put forward which would increase spending and put pressure on interest rates?

—Thank you for that very good question. Mrs Kernot recently put forward a suggestion that the government spend an extra $2 billion—I do not know whether that is Labor Party policy, Senator Faulkner, is it? Senator Faulkner will not give any sign that that is Labor Party policy.
—Senator Kemp, it would be disorderly for him to do so, and I ask you to direct your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. The most devastating question asked in this parliamentary session came from Senator Crowley when she asked, `What does the Labor Party stand for?' I could not answer that. No‐one over there could answer that. Seeing George Campbell over there, and Senator Quirke and Senator Lundy, we know what the Labor Party stands for—getting trade union leaders into parliament, with the odd defector from the Australian Democrats. That is what the Labor Party stands for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Moran is providing high quality nursing home beds in this country and more power to him. If he charges wealthy people more, even more power to him, because so he should. I was interested to see the statement of Francis Sullivan, a very respectable man who is in charge of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are two many interjections.

—I have got it here. Frances Sullivan said yesterday that it should be based on personal responsibility and capacity to contribute. That is what the government is about. That is what the Labor Party was about when they introduced hostel bonds.

—I refer to the letter which said that the Catholic Social Welfare Commission should call itself the `Labor Supporters Catholic Social Welfare Commission'—that is what Father R. —On the point of order, Madam President: I appreciate that Senator Hill has taken a point of order to allow Senator Herron to have a bit of a breather in the middle of that tirade, but I do think, Madam President, that you could draw to Senator Herron's attention the fact that he ought to address his remarks in a sensible way through the chair. He really ought to get control of himself.

—There has been far too much noise in the chamber during this question and at other times during question time, which is totally disorderly and totally unhelpful to anybody getting information out of it. Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the question and invite you to continue.

—Madam President, the hypocrisy of that point of order is a reflection of the hypocrisy of the Labor Party on this very matter that we are discussing. —In reply to the personal attack on Mr Moran, I do not think there is any benefit by personal vilification of any individual in this country. That the national debate over a matter as critical as the future care of our ageing population should descend to such a level is frankly a disgrace. The Labor opposition should take a good hard look at itself and ask itself—(Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you agree with Mr Arthur Brotherhood, who is from the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, that people who can pay around $88,000 ought to get harbour views from their bedrooms and those who cannot get the factory views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —We are descending to farce now with this sort of supplementary question. What the Labor Party has been attacking is a farce. There is the whole farce of having to recruit Cheryl Kernot. Are they so bereft of talent over on the other side? Senator Mackay is younger; she is blond; she is attractive. Why go for Cheryl Kernot?
