Senator Quirke, I have quotes from other people, if you would like to hear them, who are very supportive of the policy. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to the widespread devastation and starvation in Papua New Guinea, Irian Jaya and other countries to our north as a result of the failed rainfalls. What urgent action is being taken by the government to respond fully and generously to this crisis? What steps are being taken to ensure that the assistance actually goes directly to those who are most in need? What bilateral discussions have been taking place with other developed countries and donors to assist in relieving this crisis? What bilateral discussions have been taking place with, for example, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank for the same purpose? I put that last point in the context of matters that I raised at the last estimates committee hearings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for the question. Circumstances certainly are serious, as Senator Harradine has indicated. Senator Harradine might recall that Australia was asked for expert assistance to support the PNG National Disaster Committee. As a result of that, we sent two teams to PNG: one to undertake a rapid assessment of urgent food, water and health needs and the other to develop a longer term agricultural recovery strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand the first of those teams produced a preliminary assessment report on the situation last week which, in fact, found it to be much more serious than first envisaged. In particular, they have found that in excess of 500,000 people required immediate food relief assistance—there is a view that this number could grow rapidly over the next few weeks if seasonal rains due in early November do not eventuate—and have found that the most affected provinces were in the eastern and southern highlands, followed by Enga and Madang. However, results were nevertheless patchy.

There is also the serious threat of deterioration in the supply of staple food crops and water supplies in many areas. In fact, the water shortage problems in PNG are described as serious. This leads to, of course, concerns about dysentery outbreaks, the closing down of health clinics and the halt in processing of staple foods in some areas.

Last week, we sought to supply air transport to deliver relief supplies to the worst affected areas. An RAAF Caribou arrived in PNG on Monday the 20th. We are currently mobilising aircraft in response to PNG's request for additional assistance with the delivery of emergency relief supplies. AusAID has made the first delivery under a $1.2 million package of medical aid, which was delivered last week. I understand that the second delivery is due to arrive in PNG today, Senator Harradine. An officer of Emergency Management Australia is continuing his work with the National Disaster Emergency Service to help coordinate the relief exercise.

The Australian government does reaffirm its willingness to assist the government of PNG where required. As I have said, we have provided $1.7 million of assistance to date. Additional assistance will be determined by the government of PNG in response to the assessment report to which I referred. Therefore, we are keeping in very close contact with the PNG government and wish to be supportive in every way we can in these very difficult circumstances for a very near and close neighbour.
My notes do not tell me what work we are doing in relation to the multilateral aid agencies. I will take that part of the question on notice and get an answer for Senator Harradine tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, when nursing home proprietors charge the bond against an estate, what interest rate will apply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —They have brought the altar boy in now. It is about time they gave the altar boy a question. I have not heard from him for a long time. It is very good that they draw him in and give him a chance to have his say. They are so short of talent over that side, they have to go to the lady who was at the bottom of the garden.

ANSWER.PARA: In answering this question I will take the opportunity to take Senator Conroy through it step by step. There is so much disinformation. I would like to take this opportunity to spell out the facts so that Senator Conroy will get an answer to his question. Firstly, the arrangement to pay a bond is an arrangement between a person receiving the care and the provider of that care. Have you got that written down, Senator Conroy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Good. While the government has established the safety net for these arrangements in the Aged Care Act, the payment of an accommodation bond is an agreement between a resident and the care provider. So that is point No. 1.

ANSWER.PARA: Point No. 2 is that residents who agree to pay an accommodation bond have up to six months to pay—or longer by agreement. Under section 57‐16 of the Aged Care Act 1997—and I hope Senator Conroy has that written down—they cannot be required to pay earlier. It is as simple as that—they cannot be required to pay earlier. If we find that providers are acting illegally, the sanctions contained in the act will be used to their full effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that.

—It is good that Senator Bolkus interjects. There was no such protection under the Labor Party's hostel bonds—none at all. On the other hand, if the Labor Party were concerned about providers asking for up-front bonds and if they were concerned that residents would be exploited at a point of vulnerability, why didn't they act when they had the chance? Senator Bolkus has the hide to interject. When he was in government he put no provisions of that kind into effect. They just did not act because they did not care. That is the real issue. Labor has never cared about the aged.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the third point, Senator Conroy, as you keep writing, that residents who agree to pay an accommodation bond can choose when to pay and they can choose how to pay. Have you got that, Senator Conroy?
—Senator Herron, your answer must be directed to the chair, not to Senator Conroy.
—I apologise once again, Madam President. I have to shout because of the interjections.
—Just direct your remarks to me, Senator.

—Madam President, I will ignore them as they need to be ignored. I will direct my answer to you, Madam President. The point I just made, which you probably did not hear, was that residents who agree to pay an accommodation bond can choose when to pay and they can choose how to pay. The Aged Care Act says that it is their choice and nobody else's.

BREAK.PARA: They can pay the bond as a lump sum or as an equivalent weekly or fortnightly periodic payment made up of the retention of up to $2,600 a year and a component for interest. They can pay part as a lump sum and part as a periodic payment, whichever option suits them. They could agree to have the retention and interest taken from their estate if that is what they want. That happens in effect both now and under the Labor Party's entry bond in relation to hostels. Under their contribution scheme, where people agree to a bond but die before they paid, the estate becomes responsible. The whole notion that bonds are an up-front fee is blatant dishonesty on the Labor Party's part, and they know it. It is not up-front and it is not a fee. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I appreciate your assistance in taking notes, but the question was: when nursing home proprietors charge the bond against an estate, what interest rate will apply? That was the question.
—That was the question, remember? It is a simple question.
—Try answering it.
—Order! Cease interjecting. There have been far too many interjections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President—
—Do you know where you are?
—Yes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Herron is trying to answer a question.
—The interest rate was agreed to in discussions between all the nursing home proprietors and the industry. As you know, Senator Conroy, they had enormous input and consultation in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —An interest rate on the bonds was agreed at 8.6 per cent, Senator Bob Collins. So that was agreed to. The point I made in answer to the previous question was that it is an agreement between the person going into the nursing home and the proprietor. They do not have to accept that if the agreement is not suitable to them. They do not have to accept that. There is a safety net, as you know—well Senator Conroy probably doesn't know.
—He is now an acolyte.
—One of my colleagues said that he is now an acolyte. He has been promoted from being an altar boy. The point that I am making is that there is a safety net. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, it has been reported today that the Queensland government has tossed aside the requirement for an environmental impact statement, in effect giving Keith Williams the go‐ahead to expand his Port Hinchinbrook resort by up to 25 per cent. Can you and will you stop this expansion? Minister, are you concerned that Mr Williams has been given the green light to expand by 12 hectares on to land not included in the previous agreement to accommodate 1,800 rather than 1,500 people and to build waterfront accommodation and industrial developments such as slipways, boat repair facilities, radar and marine electronic equipment facilities and an outboard shop? Minister, isn't this proof that you have failed as an environment minister to protect the world heritage values of Hinchinbrook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that was a touch unkind, if I might say so. Madam President, I think Senator Woodley is referring to a development proposal that I gather Mr Williams, or some company with which he is associated, put to the Queensland government on land adjoining what is commonly referred to as the Hinchinbrook development. I think Senator Woodley is correct, certainly as I have heard it reported, that the Queensland government—which had an option, I understand, under Queensland legislation to require an environmental impact assessment of some type—has decided to exercise that option in a way that it would not be required.

ANSWER.PARA: I am seeking further information on that to find out why Queensland did not think that was necessary. Perhaps they believe that previous studies that have been done in relation to the region gave sufficient information upon which they based their development approval. I am not sure of that but, when I find out, I will react to it appropriately.

What Senator Woodley should appreciate, of course, Madam President, is that this is land on Queensland soil, under Queensland jurisdiction. This is a Queensland planning approval. The only issue that would affect me would be if, as a result of that planning approval, it had some detrimental effect, or potential for some detrimental effect upon adjoining world heritage values. I have not heard or seen anything to suggest that would be the case. As I indicated a moment ago, I am seeking further information on that and, if it is necessary for me to act, then I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, were you informed of the Queensland government's decision to ignore the environment of Hinchinbrook, or were you kept in the dark, as you often are—as are the rest of us sometimes—by the Queensland government? Minister, what are you going to do to protect the world class heritage of the area and stop this mockery of an environmental process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that has been phrased in a way that suits Senator Woodley's political position, but in fact—
—Have you had one win on the environment since you have been minister, Hilly?

—Yes, the next question was going to be about whales but, unfortunately we have not got to that. Senator Woodley, there are development approvals being granted all the time down the Queensland coast by the Queensland government pursuant to its constitutional responsibilities. They only become relevant to me if they fall within an area, obviously, of Commonwealth responsibility. The one that is mentioned in relation to developments along the Hinchinbrook Channel—although this one is not immediately on the channel; this is further inland, as I think you know—would be relevant if it was to have some detrimental consequence upon world heritage values.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said to you, there has been no suggestion put to me so far that this approval will have any detrimental effect. But I am seeking further advice from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and, if that causes me to change my mind, I will let you know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, yesterday Senator Jacinta Collins asked me a question dealing with the new McDonald's training agreement in Victoria. I would seek to have incorporated in Hansard the further detail that I have.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

. McDonalds operates a formal enterprise based traineeship involving 12 months full time employment under a contract of training (with State Training Authorities) in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. The Commonwealth pays subsidies and incentives to McDonald's in respect of their full time trainees, as the Commonwealth does to all eligible employers engaging in a trainee or apprentice under a contract of training registered with a State Training Authority.

. The McDonald's enterprise traineeship was developed in 1993/94 at a total cost of $98,594 of which the Commonwealth contributed $63,694 and McDonald's contributed $34,900. The traineeship was piloted in Victoria in 1994 and now extends to New South Wales and Queensland operations.

. The school based initiative, announced by the Victorian Board of Studies on 14 October 1997, enables selected students to gain credits towards their Victorian Certificate of Education from vocational training undertaken whilst working as a casual employee at McDonald's. Whilst these students may complete many of the accredited training modules from the McDonald's traineeship while in casual employment, as there is no contract of training registered with the State Training Authority, no Commonwealth incentives are paid for training undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Lundy today, relating to information techology outsourcing proposals.

Today we heard from Senator Kemp that this government expects to save around $230 million from the outsourcing of government IT. The issue that this highlights is that the original cabinet submission prepared by the Department of Finance highlighted savings far beyond what the current government are now advocating will be returned from their proposals.

What is of concern is that this government are persisting with the model that they put in place that allegedly would return $960 million worth of savings, but they have now re‐adjusted that figure down to $250 million. So what we have is a cluster model that this government are persisting with that is not able to deliver the savings that they originally advocated. As a result of that, the government have embarked upon a false course of action—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Madam Deputy President? The sorts of issues that are currently being discussed by the opposition are the subject of a report that will shortly, in the next day or two, be presented to the parliament. I am concerned about an infringement of the standing orders because lots of the matters being raised appear to me to be very central to some of the issues that may well be canvassed in that report. I seek your indulgence on the matter.

—On the point of order: all the matters Senator Lundy is raising have been published in most of the press, certainly in the Canberra Times . I do not believe that a senator seeking to discuss and/or question matters that are already in the public arena would be in contravention of the standing orders, as what she is talking about relates to committee business.

—On the point of order: I understand that Senator Lundy is also a member of the committee whose report is yet to be tabled. Therefore, I think it is even more inappropriate that the issues that are canvassed in that report be discussed here in the chamber in advance of the tabling of the report.

—On the point of order: I have not heard a word from Senator Lundy that would in any way breach the confidentiality of the committee. There is not one iota of evidence to support the allegation that government senators are making. There is nothing in the standing orders, I would submit to you, Madam Deputy President, that would allow you to uphold this spurious point of order.
—As Senator Carr has said, there is nothing in the standing orders that would prevent Senator Lundy taking note of the answer in the way she is doing. I ask Senator Lundy to continue.

—I do note with concern that perhaps the government does not want some of this to be said. Going back to the point I was making before I was interrupted with these points of order, we have a government that is embarking upon a process to outsource government IT services. That was based on a submission to cabinet and was subsequently embodied in this year's budget statements, and those processes have been given effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The questions asked of Senator Kemp today went directly to the issue of piggybacking of contracts. The issue of piggybacking of contracts is one that has haunted the government right through the IT outsourcing process because, regardless of the merits or otherwise of IT outsourcing—and I suspect that will be in the report that members of the government have alluded to in their points of order—the issue of piggybacking is quite specific to the way the government has conducted itself and its practices throughout this process. I want to spend a few minutes stepping through some of that process.

The first contract that was tied into the government's outsourcing process was let to the then ISSC—now IBM Global Services—with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In the intervening period, the government prepared the cabinet submission that was ultimately to become part of the budget decision for this year. But, subsequent to that whole proposal being implemented in the budget, discussions took place with the Department of Finance and IBM Global Services—then ISSC—to extend the application of the contract with the Department of Veterans' Affairs to cover the Department of Finance.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FERGUSON

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order. The issue was raised about a committee report that is to be presented to the Senate in the near future, and I draw your attention to standing order 72(2)(b), which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the question shall not attempt to interfere with the committee's work or anticipate its report—

Madam Deputy President, I am just wondering whether you could clarify for me the interpretation of that. If Senator Lundy is raising matters that may be contained in that report, surely that is anticipating a report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson, I am advised that the standing order you are quoting from relates to a question about a committee report put to a committee chair at question time. It relates to a question put to a committee chair, not a committee member. Senator Lundy is in order.

—The issue goes to the Department of Finance's decision to piggyback that contract. That caused great consternation within the private sector, which was seeking to express interest and involve itself in government IT outsourcing.
—Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order on your ruling. From what you have said, I understand that a member of a committee can canvass the issues but not the chair. Is that correct?
—The point of order that Senator Ferguson quoted relates to a question put to a committee chair. If you want further clarification, I will see that you get it in writing. I call Senator Lundy.

—The issue of the piggybacking of that contract with the Department of Finance caused great consternation within the private sector. It caused the industry to lobby the government quite strongly about what their role was and the fairness or unfairness of the competitive tendering process. At that time—and I quoted this in my question to Senator Kemp—there was acknowledgment on the part of the department involved, the Department of Finance, and the Office of Government Information Technology that they had some regret about the timing of the piggybacking and that it had had a negative impact upon their whole IT outsourcing proposals.

BREAK.PARA: This puts into context the extraordinary nature of the government's decision to further piggyback on the Department of Finance IT outsourcing contract in the way they have. Indeed, $25 million‐plus worth of work has now been built into the Department of Finance contract—again, bypassing the competitive tendering process as outlined in the interim procurement guidelines issued by DAS, which all of the departments acknowledged they were obliged to follow. I think it is quite extraordinary that a ministerial discretionary power was used under those guidelines to effect this piggyback. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a feeling of deja vu about this debate because I recall Senator Lundy coming up with this issue several weeks ago, and she seems to be running through the same issues again. I find it rather incredible that she is doing it at this time, given that this report is, I believe, coming down tomorrow. There has been considerable consternation on this side as to whether her taking note of the answer today was really in order because the matter is before a committee—
—You don't like hearing some things, do you? You don't like hearing the truth; that's your problem.
—I don't quite know what Senator Carr is on about.
—What about the truth?

—We have considered this matter before; Senator Lundy has brought it up in the Senate before. She previously went through the points about what she calls the `piggybacking' of contracts. But the whole point, Senator Lundy, is that this government has undertaken a proper program of outsourcing, despite what you say about the procedures involved. This government is opening up this whole area so that Australian industry can come in.
—You're opening it up all right. It's very open.

—Of course the whole process is. What Senator Lundy has done, in a rather disjointed presentation, is focus on one particular contract relating to IBM Global and Veterans' Affairs without giving us the broad picture of what is happening with this government's IT outsourcing program.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast with the previous government, this government is committed to an extensive program of IT outsourcing—an outsourcing of many things from the Public Service. As a result of this movement of work from the public sector to the private sector, we will have a much more dynamic approach to government in this country, a much more efficient delivery of services and growth of an industry which is the leading edge industry as we move into the 21st century. This sort of process, this outsourcing that we are involved in here, will develop the great growth industry of the 21st century, which is growing at a rate of 18 per cent a year.
I am quite surprised that Senator Lundy has brought this up again. We have been through this issue previously. Senator Lundy has mentioned this case previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have piggybacked another contract.

—Yes, you brought that up before, Senator Lundy, when you spoke about it two weeks ago. If a Senate committee has looked at this matter and if this Senate committee brings down a major report on it tomorrow, I would have thought the most appropriate course of action would be to wait for the report to come down tomorrow so that we can all read the report, and then we can have a sensible debate in the Senate about it. Those of us who are not on the committee do not have your inside information on this, Senator Lundy. I think you are about one day too soon on this matter, Senator. I would suggest it would be better for us to adjourn this debate. Tomorrow, when we have all read the report, we can come back and have a much more sensible debate about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course this issue is in the public domain—and very much in the public domain—because of the concern that so many small to medium sized enterprises have about the government's action in respect of the IT outsourcing proposals that they have put on the table and the actions that they have taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to hear from the government how they intend to implement what they say is 15 per cent of the contracts to be let. We should remember that there probably are only three companies—all multinationals—that have the capacity to deal with the IT outsourcing contracts that will be let by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I have a point of order. In asking you to rule on a point of order when Senator Lundy was speaking I referred to standing order 72(2)(b). I wonder whether you could perhaps give me a ruling on standing order 73(l), which refers to questions? It says that questions shall not refer to proceedings in committee not reported to the Senate.
—Senator Ferguson, we are not in committee. Question time is not in committee. It is question time—that is referring to committee. Question time is not committee.

—Read all the standing orders. For Senator Tierney's benefit, the government said at the outset that this would be the panacea for small to medium enterprises in the information technology area in this country; that this would be the generator of employment that Senator Tierney spoke about. I would be very interested to know, and I know there are a lot of small to medium enterprise industries which also would like to know, how the government will bring that about. At this point in time all the government has done is let contracts worth significant amounts of money without the slightest competitive tendering process—there has not been one iota of a competitive tendering process.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that this is the position that has been publicly conveyed both by this government and by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and yet the only decisions put into practice are those that exclude the rights of companies to competitively tender for these contracts. As I said, probably only three major multinational companies have the capacity to tender for these contracts.

Coming back to the small to medium enterprises that will generate all the jobs for Australian workers, we ask: how do they get into the game? That is something that they have been asking also: `How do we get into the game?' Look at the circumstances in the case of IBM‐GSA. They have small enterprises around the world that they subcontract to. I put it to the government that it is quite conceivable that they will use the companies that they have an association with.

There are many companies which have relied for a considerable period of time on government business in the IT area, some of them based here in Canberra. I want to hear from the government what they intend to do to ensure that these companies get a fair crack at the IT outsourcing contract. Despite the fact that the government has said, `We want to see 15 per cent of the contract subcontracted to small to medium enterprises,' I have not seen anything that indicates that they necessarily have to be Australian enterprises, that they have to be Australian companies.

That is what I think is causing a significant amount of concern, but even more so is that we have not even had a competitive tender yet—not one has been called. You have this situation where first the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) says, `Okay, we're going to go down this proper process.' The government is all about competition—fairness and equity. So next we put together the clusters. Perhaps John Fahey should be called the `cluster buster', because we have not had a cluster yet that has held together.

The other question that must be raised with the government is what happens when you change your mind like you did with the Department of Administrative Services, when you all of a sudden bowled them out and chucked them in with Finance. We have seen an announcement, as Senator Lundy pointed out, that now they are part of the piggyback on the DVA contract—no competitive tender again.

Senator Gibson, I can see you sitting over there with a wry smile on your face. I do not think you for one would support this process where there is no competition. I have heard you get up in this place many times and talk about competition, particularly when you were a parliamentary secretary. So far as the growth industry—this IT area—is concerned, this government has a lot to answer for and many questions remain unanswered. Senator Gibson, you might answer some of them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President.
—Welcome back.

—Thank you. I rise to respond to Senator Lundy's question earlier about the IT outsourcing. Let us look at the history of all this: why is the government endeavouring to improve efficiency of the operation of the administration of government? Because the Labor Party left us with a mess. The other side were the group that raised taxes by 30 per cent in the last four years of their government, sold off $9 billion worth of silver, increased borrowings by $70 billion and left us with a mess. We are cleaning up the mess and part of that is by greatly improving the efficiency of the operations of the Australian Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of that, we are continuing a process which the Labor government started of outsourcing the IT works within the government, except that we are doing it in a more comprehensive way, but the design was basically set in your day. Tenders were called for the first group of contracts for the veterans' affairs department. As Senator Lundy knows, this matter about the history of what happened and how there was nothing improper done has been well and truly canvassed during Senate estimates—over and over again.

As Senator Murphy knows, I am in favour of strong competition but, because there was an opportunity to piggyback on this particular contract with the Department of Finance, the government decided to go ahead with it and save many millions of dollars rather than wait for a considerable period before the next opportunity to go with another cluster. In the interests of the poor battling taxpayers of Australia, the government made a decision to go ahead with this particular contract and to add Finance into the contract—it was in the original design of the contract to allow that to happen. But that really is only a minor affair. The greater affair is the design for the rest of the Commonwealth IT work.

I am sure Senator Lundy would agree with me that the design of calling competitive tenders for those clusters—and, as Minister Fahey said, including encouraging Australian firms to be part of the tender process—is the right way for us to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily.

—Because they are large jobs. Firms have been encouraged to get together and to put in competitive tenders for that process. I am certain that the taxpayers are getting good value for their money. The government is heading down the correct path for this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard Senator Gibson, I think the other side has lost the plot on this one. I indicate that I am not on any committee considering any report that is coming before this chamber. Senator Gibson really raised the issue about the poor battling taxpayer when he said that what has been done has been for the poor battling taxpayer. The one thing that this coalition promised when they were heading for government was transparency, openness, and the very thing that we do not have here today is transparency and openness. What we have is a government which has piggybacked contract upon contract.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the original DVA contract, as I understand it, it was not a cluster contract; it was a contract simply for DVA and, as a result, no other departments were taken into consideration and no other needs were taken into consideration. No-one is doubting the transparency of the process there. If one looks at the estimates process, one will find that there was lengthy questioning to the representatives of the Department of Veterans' Affairs about the DVA contract and its transparency, and I do not think anyone brought into doubt that particular issue.

What is at stake is that we now have piggybacking on piggybacking; we have DAS going into Finance going into DVA. This loses sight of all of what this government proclaimed that they stood for—openness and transparency. If the poor battling taxpayers, as Senator Gibson describes them, are to be taken into consideration, then this government should have addressed this issue in a much better manner than they have done today. It is not a minor affair; it is very important that transparency is seen in these operations. As my colleagues Senator Murphy and Senator Lundy have pointed out before, this is about competition: seeing that contracts are openly and transparently competed for.

One can already see some instances of this government's approach to IT outsourcing. What about the Russell Offices—the Department of Defence? They not only let the contract once, but had to stop the process and re‐let it because there was a mess‐up. One must have transparency at all costs. One must have the ability to see that there has been competition.

As to the furphy that the government put up, that this is about making things more dynamic and efficient, that has yet to be proven. There is no proof at this stage that that will necessarily be the case. All that we have seen so far in the tendering process is that small to medium sized enterprises, which this government so often claims to champion, have been left out on a limb. The big winners, as my colleagues have pointed out, have been the multinationals. As Senator Murphy said—and I agree—the only winners are the multinationals. So much for the creation of jobs in Australia, and that is what this is really about.

If this government were half serious about bringing forward an IT outsourcing program, they would ensure that it leads to growth in the number of jobs. But they cannot prove that that is the case anywhere. All they are doing is leaving the Australian public in the lurch and helping someone to provide a job to someone else overseas. That is beyond doubt.
With regard to savings, those are yet to be proven. There is no doubt that there may be some savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course.

—But there are losses as well, Senator McGauran, which you will find out about in the longer term. You will find that there is a loss of corporate knowledge within these departments as a result of outsourcing. You will find that there is not necessarily a net cost benefit to the department. But that has not been shown to date because some of these contracts have not had time to run. So, all in all, the government has got a lot to answer for in this area. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —To take up Senator Hogg's last point, I do not know whether he is in favour of the principle of outsourcing or the practice of outsourcing. I ask Senator Hogg, before he leaves the chamber, whether he is in favour of the principle of outsourcing. Apparently, he is. We have barely started on the road to outsourcing and Senator Hogg is slamming its operation. I will bet Senator Hogg that within six months, or even 12 months, when we look back at this major structural reform and change by the government, it will be shown to be cost efficient and to have a cost benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know who is running the Labor Party tactics committee but I think it needs a few new members. Senator Cook, you have probably just joined that committee, given your new status. I congratulate you on your new status. I think that committee needs a real shake‐up. The time for debating motions to take note of answers should be a time during which the opposition excels, especially seeing that today's proceedings are being broadcast. All that the opposition has done is to allow Senator Lundy, the local representative for the public service union, to utterly indulge herself by debating a fringe issue.

You could not even sustain your genuineness on the aged care issue. I would have thought that you would have picked up today's Daily Telegraph. I was all geared up for it; I was happy to defend the government's policy on aged care. I would have thought you would have been able to sustain an attempt at genuineness on this issue and raise it during the time for debating motions to take note of answers. Instead, you have reverted to a fringe, Canberra‐ised issue on information technology. It is a total re‐run, as was stated by the previous government speaker, of an issue that does not seem to be getting anywhere, other than the fact that it allows Senator Lundy to send out copies of her speeches in Hansard.

Addressing the issue itself, there have been major changes within the Public Service in Canberra, and outsourcing is one of them. They were necessary changes which were forced upon the government because of the legacy we inherited from the previous government—a legacy of a $10.5 billion budget deficit and a $100 billion government debt. Given that legacy, we had to introduce efficiencies across the board.

Did Senator Lundy, who represents the public service union in Canberra—or at least part of it—really think that one of the most inefficient areas of government could not be tackled? We have tackled it. We have brought about these changes which are designed to put the Public Service on a competitive, efficient footing. But they in no way reduce the services offered by the federal government. All of these changes are feeding into the budget process.

The point is that outsourcing, as distasteful as it may be to the public service union, means that the private sector will now get a chance to tender for some jobs. The fact is it is a cost‐efficient operation. I challenge Senator Hogg to look back at it after six to 12 months and he will see that I am right.

I do not know why you are all attacking the finance department for making one of the first moves in this area, because they have saved over $25 million over a five‐year period. That is a stunning saving.

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't saved it yet.

—It will happen, Senator Lundy. I will take a bet with you that these savings will come about. They have saved it, given that they have set the contracts in place. They are able to match one cost against the other. They are dealing with major firms—IBM‐GSA. I believe they are in good hands. They are very reputable firms. Why wouldn't you go to them, given that their operating costs are far lower than if it were done internally? I do not know whether we will hear about this issue again from Senator Lundy—whether she will be indulged by the Labor Party tactics committee and allowed to raise it once more. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —We know that Senator McGauran is a great judge, because, after all, he is on the record saying not so long ago on a very momentous weekend, the finals weekend, that he was backing St Kilda on Saturday, Manly on Sunday and his brother on Monday. He got the trifecta wrong. He has come in here today and attacked Senator Lundy for being irrelevant. I would have thought that he has the credentials—the runs on the board—for being the most irrelevant judge in here of the realities of life.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this government's performance in relation to contracts. We have had the DDB Needham contract under scrutiny in here—a really shady deal. We have had the South Pacific Cruise Lines contract, where frittering away a couple of million dollars was not seen as important enough for the then minister to give a hand and have a good look at things. The department had to take legal action to try to recover the money.

The problem we have here is that, instead of the government seeking a proper tendering process for outsourcing—a proper process that is transparent, a process where you can see that the amount of money to be saved is the maximum available—we have the piggybacking of a contract upon a contract. In other words, there is no testing as to whether this is the best possible deal that we can do. We put one department on top of another. We end up with the position which the government says saves money but we do not know whether that is the best possible position. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to ask you a question in relation to privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, would it be possible for you to ask the secretary of the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee whether the issues canvassed, and the manner in which they were canvassed, by the chair of that committee and a member of that committee were the subject of the report? At the present time, I understand that the chairman has prepared that report with the assistance of the secretary and it has not been available to the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, it appears to me that a great deal of the issues that were raised were certainly raised in that report. I think it does raise the question of whether members of the opposition were actually anticipating that report. I think it does tend to make something of a mockery of subsequently talking on committee reports somewhat down the track if we allow people the privilege of debating those sorts of issues in the manner in which they have been debated here when they are subject to a report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We gave leave for a question to be asked. Senator Watson has asked the question, and that is my point of order. He has asked his question and he is now debating the question.
—And I am about to answer it.
—The debating of the question is out of order. We gave leave for a question to be asked. I think the question has been put.
—On the point of order: I thought the question needed to be put in the correct context. I feel I have done that and I have concluded my remarks.

—There is nothing in the standing orders that prevents a member of the Senate from canvassing issues that may have also been canvassed in committee hearings. If the senator purported to be quoting from the draft report, that would be a different story.
—We don't know. That is what I am asking, because we do not know.
—I am not in a position to know either. I will take your question on notice and see what the appropriate answer is.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 216 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 790 citizens)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern, the continuing failure of the Australian Government to develop a comprehensive industry policy, as demonstrated by:

PARA.TAB: (i) its failure to respond effectively to key reports, such as the Mortimer report, the Goldsworthy report and the Metal Trades Industry Association report, Make or Break ,

(ii) its failure to come up with any initiatives on industry policy apart from those elements of the Australian Labor Party's policy which it has been forced to accept, including the responses on the automotive and textile, clothing and footwear industries and on ship and book bounties,
(iii) its inability to respond decisively to the BHP announcement on Newcastle in order to ensure that Australia continues to have a viable steelmaking capacity,
(iv) its gross mishandling of the anti-dumping issue and its failure to keep its election promise to cut the maximum time for an anti-dumping case to 155 days,
(v) its mishandling of the pharmaceutical industry issue, which has put at risk millions of dollars of investment and hundreds of new jobs, and

(vi) its failure to act upon the recommendations relating to strategies to develop an Australian information industry contained in the Information Industries Taskforce (Goldsworthy) and the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (Cutler) reports, including its failure to recognise the critical role government procurement plays in this sector in terms of establishing export credentials amongst small-to medium-sized enterprises;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) condemns the Government's $4 billion cuts to industry programs, noting that overall budget cuts have:

PARA.TAB: (i) taken approximately half a percentage point off gross domestic product,
(ii) slashed industrial research and development from $820 million in the 1995-96 financial year to a projected $286 million in the 1997-98 financial year, and
(iii) reduced the attractiveness of Australia as a destination for major new industrial investment;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) deplores the Government's failure to respond to growing job insecurity, particularly amongst workers in the manufacturing sector, and its failure to take any steps to deliver on its election commitment to create 200 000 new manufacturing jobs by the year 2000; and
(d) calls on the Government, as a matter of urgency, to:

PARA.TAB: (i) respond positively and comprehensively to the Mortimer blueprint on industry policy, including the approach to growth targets, strategic action plans for key industries, and the 5-year funding model,
(ii) reverse its cuts to industry programs, and
(iii) recommit to the 200 000 manufacturing jobs target.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the recent Australian Council for Research (ACER) study of literacy, which identifies a strong link between poor literacy outcomes and students whose family backgrounds are non-English speaking, low income and lower education,

(ii) that spending on education, as a percentage of gross domestic product, has fallen to the point where, depending on the figures used, Australia is either third lowest ranking, or ranks 14 out of 27, of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) urges the Government to:

(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the expanding role of the Internet, with potential benefits for all Australians for education, entertainment and business,
(ii) Australian Internet users worldwide subsidise their United States of America (US) counterparts to the sum of US$300 million a year, with Telstra paying US$15 million of this amount,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 813 standing in my name relating to comments by the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir Mohamad, be taken as formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 813.

The Senate will be able to distinguish between this motion and the one that was just passed. The difference is that the motion that was just passed is a general motion which repudiates the idea of racial intolerance. Mine is very specific. It refers to comments made by the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Dr Mahathir Mohamad, a week ago. He indicated that Jews were responsible for the economic problems that Malaysia faces at the moment. In those comments he went to the extent of noting the differences between the Jewish people and the predominantly Muslim population of Malaysia.

There has been worldwide reaction to those comments. There has been an extraordinarily strong reaction from the United States, in particular. The matter is important and urgent because the Australian government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. For the purposes of facilitating this debate, I indicate that my friends in the Labor Party are going to support the suspension of standing orders. I think it might save the time of the Senate if we allowed Senator Brown to move to his substantive motion because we are going to hear the same speech repeated in a few minutes.
—I agree.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Brown) agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That general business notice of motion No. 813 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate calls on the Prime Minister of Malaysia (Dr Mahathir Mohamad) to withdraw his racially-loaded remarks that Jews are to be blamed for his country's financial problems.

This matter is important not only because the Malaysian Prime Minister made racially slurred remarks but also because he did so in a context which was full of potential to lead other people to feel that their livelihoods were being affected by a particular group of people, in this case the Jewish people. It was an irresponsible remark to make. It was an intolerant remark to make. For a head of state at the end of this century to make such a remark is unforgivable.

We must expect that it was premeditated. Certainly there has been no move by Dr Mahathir to withdraw the comments even under a hail of international condemnation. What concerns me is that there has been no response from the Australian government—certainly no response that is analogous to that which came from the United States. We must respond to that sort of comment because to not do so is to legitimise it and to allow worse comments to be made. It is important that when comments like that are made which are destructive of particular groups of people anywhere that the perpetrator be called to order.

There will be those who argue—and I have no doubt the government is amongst them—that we do not need to interfere in the affairs of other countries. Dr Mahathir was interfering in our affairs when he made that comment. He was damaging the Jewish community in this country when he made that comment. He was fostering racial division when he made that comment.

The Australian government has to accept its responsibility and face up to that sort of racism and object to it. It is not good enough to argue that this could have some economic ramifications, that we may see some other contractual arrangements endangered by Dr Mahathir if he is confronted on racist statements like this. But that is no way for a government to behave. Ethics demand a strong repudiation of racist comments like those from Dr Mahathir when they are made. We cannot allow hypothetical considerations to do with economic interest to get in the way of standing up against such unwarranted and potentially destructive comments.

I would have thought it would be easy for the government to back this motion. On the face of it, it is a very restrained motion. It is simply asking that we send a message to Dr Mahathir calling on him to withdraw his comments—a very mild rebuke, indeed, a very mild course of action. If this government cannot at least reach that point of response to Dr Mahathir, they are failing the Australian feeling of a fair go—that we should stand up for minorities, that we should have the gumption to face up to bullies and that we cannot tolerate racist and racially dividing comments, not least those coming from heads of state. We should be keeping an eye, as I said, on the history of this century in ensuring that there is some government reaction.

I find it appalling that there has been silence from the government on this issue. It should not be left to a Green senator to move a motion like this in the Senate. It ought to have been a matter of instant government reaction, a responsibility that the government felt it had to at least respond to Dr Mahathir on this occasion.

But, instead of that, it appears as though the government is feeling very fragile, to say the least. It is willing to allow itself be bullied by this head of state. The tragedy of that is it is allowing a minority within our community as well as within communities elsewhere around to world to be not only bullied but inherently threatened by that sort of comment because it is hurtful, because it does upset people, because it does change their state of mind, their ambience of life.

So we should pass this motion. Dr Mahathir should know that Australians do not easily accept intolerant racial slurs such as the one he has made. Who is to make that response? Of course it should be the government. If the government had done the right thing last week and made an immediate response, there would be no need for us to be considering this very mild rejoinder coming from the Greens on behalf of the Australian people who feel that Dr Mahathir should not get away with his racially loaded statement of last week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motive of Senator Brown in moving this motion was thinly veiled, to put it in its most generous terms. In actual fact, his debating points were an attack on the Australian government. He has little concern or interest in what Dr Mahathir may have said; all he is interested in is trying to score a political point against the government.
—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I believe that comment impugns Senator Brown. I ask that Senator Hill be asked to withdraw.
—Order! There is no point of order. I did not think the comment impugned Senator Brown.

—I am impugning Senator Brown's domestic, political motive, from which he must think he can gain some political benefit. He in fact said that he moved this motion because he did not believe he had heard an adequate response from the Australian government. Therefore, the motion is a thinly veiled version of the motion he should have moved to direct his criticism against us.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic circumstances in Malaysia of recent times have been unfortunate. There is no doubt about that. I also feel that in many ways there have been unfortunate statements made in relation to it. The issue now is what can be gained by a motion such as this. Is this motion in any way going to assist Malaysia in its economic difficulties? The answer, obviously, is no. Is it going to influence Dr Mahathir in his attitudes or any future comment that he would make? The answer is, obviously, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is not designed to do that, Senator Hill. It is designed to get Brown a run in the media.

—We know that. How best should this issue be approached? It is the position of the government that the best way to approach an issue such as this is to unambiguously reaffirm the position that we hold on issues of racial intolerance, issues of anti-Semitism. That, I am pleased to say, was done by Senator MacGibbon in the motion that he moved a few moments ago that was unanimously adopted by this place. The resolution of this place this day was:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate reaffirms its often stated condemnation of anti‐semitism and all other forms of racial discrimination and, in particular, reaffirms its support for the joint parliamentary motion on racial tolerance, agreed to on 30 October 1996.

There is no ambiguity in that statement. Those who are interested in this issue and in where the Australian people might stand on the issue of racial discrimination need go no further than to take note of that unanimously adopted resolution; or, I say humbly, they need go no further than my answer to Senator Cooney of yesterday, which reaffirmed the government's position on this issue in very similar terms to those of the motion moved by Senator MacGibbon and adopted by the Senate this day.

In other words, we think that when these occasions arise—and they do from time to time—often the best response is to reaffirm our commitment to a racially tolerant society. I would say, Senator Brown, not only reaffirm it—because words are often cheap—but perhaps each one of us should look at our actions and ensure that as individuals we take all possible actions to demonstrate in practical terms our abhorrence of racial intolerance.

Unfortunately, even in this country we know that in times of economic stress, rapid structural change and tension, statements are made and individuals or races are sometimes blamed. Those statements are often made out of frustration or because of some other incapacity to address the issues. We find that, in relation to times of high unemployment, often it is the migrants who are blamed. It is those who are suffering in a situation of tension who are lashing out. It does not mean that they are necessary racially intolerant, but their words are hurtful, and when they are under stress they react by passing the blame to others.

I am not sure exactly what Dr Mahathir was seeking to do, but I did note that, contrary to what Senator Brown has said, following the early reports Dr Mahathir seemed to modify what had been said. I have taken a few print‐outs from the news reports as they have come off the computer. A report of 11 October, at 21.22, reporting from Kuala Lumpur, stated that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said that he did not accuse the Jews of undermining the economy of Malaysia and other Muslim countries.

On the following day, 12 October, it was reported, again from Kuala Lumpur, that Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad toned down an opinion he had previously voiced about a possible Jewish plot behind the country's recent currency turbulence. The report said: `"I did not attack the Jews", the leader said in remarks quoted in local newspapers.'

The following day, some of his ministerial colleagues were saying similar things. On 13 October, the Malaysian tourism minister, in a response to it being put to him that Dr Mahathir was quoted as saying that Jews do not wish to see Muslim countries such as Malaysia succeed, Datuk Sabaruddin, said that this was not the case. He is reported as saying, `I do not think Dr Mahathir would say this'—that is, that the currency crisis is a result of the Jews—`I am sure he wouldn't blame the Jews. I don't think we are against Jews as a whole.' There was, in the circumstances leading up to these statements, an attempt to lash out at one individual, and I think that is what that last reference was to.

It does seem that, on reflection, Dr Mahathir very significantly toned down the remarks he made. That tends to confirm for me that to adopt this motion in its current terms, which is clearly designed by Senator Brown for what he sees as short‐term domestic political gain, is not going to be helpful.
A much more responsible attitude would be to adopt a resolution in similar terms to that which Senator MacGibbon moved and the Senate as a whole adopted a few minutes ago. I therefore move:

Omit all words after "Senate", substitute "reaffirms its often stated condemnation of anti‐semitism and all other forms of racial discrimination and, in particular, reaffirms its support for the joint parliamentary motion on racial tolerance".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had some discussion today on what happens under the difficulties associated with—and I quote the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill)—`economic stress and rapid structural change'. This has happened not only in Malaysia but simultaneously in a number of countries in South‐East Asia, some of which were considered to be the tiger economies.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also, in other forms, occurred in Australia. We know that the economic stress that has occurred, resulting in high and persistent levels of unemployment and rapid structural change, has resulted—within government, within bureaucracy and within some elements of industry—in frustration due to the inability to impact on this situation. Giving over the ability to take a number of different actions on the economy to the international World Trade Organisation has left a lot of people frustrated. So we can see a parallel in Malaysia with what has happened and is happening in Australia.

It might well be difficult for this government to take firmer action in relation to the statements of Dr Mahathir because it may well make them very vulnerable to charges of a similar kind. As mentioned by Senator Hill—and I thank him for bringing out these points—in times of high unemployment, migrants are often blamed.

Let us look at those parallels in Australia. Migrants, refugees, Aboriginal people, young unemployed people and almost anyone on welfare have been blamed. How have they been blamed? They have been blamed by the actions of government. The government have specifically targeted those groups and fed on this particular very ripe opportunity for scapegoat politics in Australia. They have cut those programs. They have targeted groups for specific cuts, tried to close them down, tried to shut them up and basically continued to form a political attack on those groups because this is the right time to do that.

This is the right time when, politically, Australia and other countries in the region are experiencing both economic stress in various ways and rapid structural change associated with the massive changes in international free trade. In Australia we can add to that the massive changes associated with the leap to competition policy. So you can see why the government would accept hosing down or toning down of the statements that were made instead of taking a more ethical response.

So I indicate that I will be supporting the motion. I do not support the government generally going along with scapegoat politics, because that is what has happened. In my opinion, they have tried to cash in on scapegoat politics in Australia in many different ways. They are continuing to do that with the disgraceful response to the High Court's Wik decision. The government are culpable and they are vulnerable to counterclaims. In my opinion, that is why they are not taking a stronger position. Even if they are vulnerable, I support the stronger position, and I will not be supporting the amendment put forward by the government to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) gets up and says that Dr Mahathir toned down his remarks. He did nothing of the sort. He said he did not say them. He said, `I didn't attack the Jews,' but he did. We are getting doubletalk here from the government on a matter that is very clear. Dr Mahathir made an abhorrent statement blaming the Jews for Malaysia's financial problems, in part or in whole, and indicating that this small group of people were to be singled out as responsible for a matter affecting all Malaysians. That is very racially loaded, damaging, dangerous, unacceptable stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the government says, `Well, we'll move an amendment to the motion,' which removes all reference to Dr Mahathir himself. What game is the government playing here? Why can't they eyeball Dr Mahathir on this one? I suppose we get something of a clue from a comment made by Ian Sinclair in an interview on PM on 17 October, last Friday. He said:
. . . after all Paul Keating made remarks about Dr Mahathir being recalcitrant and look at the difficulties that created.
So Dr Mahathir can say what he likes—very damaging, dangerous, racially slurring stuff—but we dare not respond because it may create some difficulties from Dr Mahathir.

That is the wrong way for the government to go. The government should know that, if you do not stand up to comments like those that Dr Mahathir has made, you end up aiding and abetting the next lot. Silence is not just consent. There is no consent in this place to what Dr Mahathir said—his track record in these matters is pretty crook—but there is encouragement.

I think the government should have the gumption to support this motion and call on Dr Mahathir to withdraw his remarks. The amendment that the government moved, which removes all reference to Dr Mahathir, is the amendment of an apologist. I ask the government to reconsider. It is not good enough; it is unacceptable; it is weak. It is letting down those people who are most hurt by the statements that Dr Mahathir made. I know Senator Hill has taken this up because he wants to score some political points. They are very demeaning remarks from Senator Hill.

These comments were made by Dr Mahathir almost a week ago. It would have been reasonable to expect a response from the Australian government. Instead of that, we have letters going to the nation's newspapers and people commenting in the streets. They are saying, `What is happening? What is the diversion that is big enough for the government to fail to make any response to these totally unacceptable statements by another head of state?'

You cannot help feeling that Ian Sinclair is exposing the government's timidity. The government does not want to have difficulties from Dr Mahathir. It is scared of responding to this man. This bully has got this government on the back foot. I say get that back foot forward, get on the front foot and stand up to this man. Stand up for the rights of those people affected by what he has said. Stand up against racial slurs—not least when they come from a head of state but particularly because they have come from a head of state of a country that we hold as being very valuable.

We have a very valuable relationship with Malaysia and the people of Malaysia in so many ways. But that does not excuse this head of state, who has had plenty of time to reflect on what he has said, for failing to withdraw in any way at all those comments. Senator Hill is really acting as a cover for Dr Mahathir when he comes in and says, `He has moderated them.' Dr Mahathir has done nothing of the sort. He simply denied that he made the statement.
It is not good enough. It is on the record; it has gone right around the world and it needs standing up to. I will certainly be opposing Senator Hill's amendment.

That the amendment (Senator Hill's ) be agreed to.
