SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) with sadness, the death of Professor Douglas Whalan AM, who served for 15 years as the legal adviser to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and

(ii) that in that period of time Professor Whalan scrutinised 18 000 items of delegated legislation and provided invaluable advice to the committee on numerous matters concerning the rights and liberties of individuals;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) records its appreciation of the erudition and good humour brought by Professor Whalan to the work of the committee, as well as for his role in strengthening parliamentary scrutiny of executive government and thereby protecting untold numbers of Australians; and
(c) expresses its profound sympathy to his widow and family at their tragic loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave for senators to make statements in relation to the motion for a total of 10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in relation to this motion because I was particularly saddened by the passing of Professor Whalan. I had known Doug for, I think, some 23 years. Doug actually taught me property law at the Australian National University back in 1975. He managed to get even me through property law.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of those opposite who may have a different view to me about native title may regret that Doug ever taught me property law. He was a very popular lecturer at ANU, and I certainly enjoyed the period I spent with him. He made what is otherwise a very dry subject one that I particularly enjoyed, and he made law school—and my law degree—a much more enjoyable experience.

I was grateful to be able to renew my acquaintance with Doug when I joined the Regulations and Ordinances Committee just after I came into the Senate in 1993. Joining the Regulations and Ordinances Committee was a sort of night watch for all the new boys and girls and I thought, `This is going to be a lot of fun, isn't it?' To my great pleasure and delight, Doug Whalan made it a most enjoyable committee. He taught me the importance of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. His unfailing sense of humour made each meeting of that committee a great pleasure and a great delight. It was terrific for me, as someone who had known him for that period of time, to renew that acquaintance.

Doug was a really delightful human being, a man whom it was a great pleasure and a privilege to know, an eminent lawyer and one who served in the position of legal adviser to that committee with enormous distinction. I miss him and I pass on my commiserations to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with an enormous amount of personal sadness and regret that I noted the death of Doug Whalan. I did not have the experience of Senator Minchin in having that perspective as a student, and I must say that I was very pleased to hear that perspective from Senator Minchin.

SPEECH.PARA: I had my first contact with Doug Whalan as chair of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee when I first came into this place. I recall only too well going to see a certain senior party figure when I came down here to nominate the committees that I wanted to be on. I actually wanted to be on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee because I had an interest in delegated legislation. I can recall saying that to the certain person who delegated these functions, and his response was, `Well, you won't have much competition for that.' Indeed, I ended up on the committee and I was delighted that I did. I was particularly interested to hear Senator Minchin's reference to the fact that Doug Whalan could make property law entertaining. He made regulations and ordinances entertaining, too.

With all of the thunder and lightning that obviously dominates the proceedings of this parliament, what is often overlooked here is the work of the committees and the public service they perform. No committee of this parliament performs a more important and consistent public service than the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Its job is to oversee the personal rights of citizens and to ensure they are not infringed upon by the mass of delegated legislation which is now the order of the day in government.

The work of that committee can be very painstaking but the results, in terms of preserving people's rights, are extremely important. One only has to note the succession of notices of motions of disallowance that the chairman of the committee, Senator O'Chee, now brings into this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, can you make your last comment very quickly because you are into the next two minutes.

—I do apologise for that. I will conclude by saying that Doug was a constant delight both in terms of making that committee work and in terms of it being entertaining. There are two things that stick in my mind that I recall Doug Whalan discovering. In 1989, prior to the ACT becoming a self‐governing state, he discovered that a law still operated in the ACT requiring wine merchants to sell wine at reasonable prices. And I will never forget the regulation in the Telecommunications Act which Doug Whalan discovered actually made a legal offence out of telling a lie during a telephone conversation, which I am sure was not an intended consequence. It is with those concluding remarks that I commend the enormous public service that Doug Whalan gave through that committee. I deeply regret his passing.

—Professor Douglas Whalan was a true member of the community. His integrity was of the highest. His intelligence was of the keenest. His love of family was boundless. His communication with others was loose and eloquent—or perhaps elegant is a better word. His humour was wonderful. He served his profession, his university, parliament and this country mightily. He was the most gracious of men.

BREAK.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President Crowley, I think you might find that it is unfortunate that you are in the chair because I have often heard you speak of Professor Whalan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, can I just intrude. I understand that there are four speakers, not five. So if there were two minutes going begging and somebody could replace me in the chair for those two minutes, I would be very pleased to speak on my own behalf.

—That may be appropriate. Perhaps an event that ought be mentioned is when a delegated legislation conference took place in London. Our delegation was Senator Crowley, Senator Pat Giles, Senator Bronwyn Bishop and Senator Kay Patterson—the first all‐women delegation. May I say that the secretary of that committee was perhaps one of the most outstanding figures who has come through this parliament—a true parliamentarian, Anne Lynch. That was a group that has flourished and, I am sure, has flourished because of the influence of Doug Whalan.
—Senator Cooney, that is very kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOURNE
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I first met Professor Doug Whalan very early in my parliamentary career when I was on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. He came to assist us when the person who regularly assisted us was unable to be there. I must say that Doug Whalan was one of the most charming and delightful people I think I have ever met. He was a very eminent scholar and lawyer and very impressive in that he treated everyone with the same charm and ease. He was terribly easy to get on with.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, I am in the very fortunate position of being invited to breakfast once a year near Christmas with all current and many former members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Doug Whalan always came to those breakfasts and he was always just the most charming, delightful, good humoured and lovely man to speak to. I will miss him a great deal at those breakfasts.

BREAK.PARA: I am sure that not only this parliament but also the ANU will miss him. He is, in fact, a loss to Australia as a whole. In a lot of little ways that people would not have realised, his passing is a loss to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleagues for their assistance in giving me this opportunity to speak. I knew Doug Whalan when he was the adviser to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never had the pleasure, privilege or perhaps burden of serving on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. But, at the time I mention, Doug Whalan was actually providing legal counsel to both the Regulations and Ordinances committee and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Very few people except those of us here would know what a monumental task that was. It was an extraordinary demand. Always and for ever Doug Whalan, as all of you have said—a person who brings a smile to my face just thinking of him—was civilised, interested and interesting.

I went to those committees as a person with a medical degree, not a legal degree. I was always delighted with the way Doug made non‐legally qualified people feel perfectly able to contribute. But, even more, he had a wonderful capacity to take seriously just about any proposal and comment put to him. It was as though he was in a state of perpetual learning. He was open to anything we said should be taken seriously, should be evaluated, but he was able to gently bring to one's attention an error in logic or the prospect of difficulty in how the matter might be concluded. He was never critical, he never put people down. He always invited people to open their minds and to express their ideas. He led brilliantly by his example in that way.

He was an adviser to the aforementioned committee, and I thank Senator Cooney for mentioning that because I did not know whether I would be able to speak. I would also like to place on the record—I am sure she would not mind my doing this on her behalf—Senator Kay Patterson's sympathy. Senator Patterson equally participated in working closely with Doug Whalan.

BREAK.PARA: We cannot in this place tell all the stories of that absolutely wonderful delegation to London. I think it was probably a committee that stood out. Doug Whalan himself said that, of the many things he had served on, he thoroughly enjoyed travelling with us. To his wife and to his family, whom he loved dearly, my sympathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I present a paper entitled A Breach of the Committee's Principles , and seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard . In so doing, I point out that a statement of this nature is not within the ordinary occurrence of the workings of the committee. The committee's patience was sorely tested with regard to these matters and it thought very carefully about making the statement. But the committee has done so because we believe there are very important principles which need to be enunciated and that it is important that both the executive and the parliament as a whole take careful consideration of these matters, because if we do not take care of these matters people's rights will be affected.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A Breach of the Committee's Principles

SPEECH.PARA: One of the terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is to ensure that delegated legislation does not make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal. Administrative discretions have an immediate impact upon individuals and business firms and it is essential that these decisions made by Ministers and departmental bureaucrats should be subject to external review. Such review improves the quality of administration by concentrating the minds of decision makers on the fact that their actions are subject to review of their merits by an independent external body.

Every year the Committee raises with Ministers many instances where delegated legislation provides for administrative decisions with no apparent merits review provided for either in the enabling Act or in the legislative instrument itself. The Committee is gratified that it usually receives good cooperation from Ministers in this scrutiny. For instance, the last Annual Report of the Committee reported that Ministers had undertaken to amend one Act and 12 legislative instruments to provide for Administrative Appeals Tribunal review and to review the operations of another legislative instrument in the light of our concerns. The importance which the Committee attaches to external review of administrative decisions is illustrated by the same Report advising that the Committee had resolved formally to recommend disallowance of a regulation unless the Committee received on that day an undertaking to amend to provide for AAT review. The Committee then received such an undertaking.

Given the general high level of cooperation from Ministers it is disappointing for the Committee to have to report an instance where the Committee has not received a satisfactory response in respect of its concerns about external review.

This matter, which has had a long gestation period, originated in the Committee's scrutiny of the Trade Practices Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1993 No.21 , which provided for fees payable for applications under the enabling Act for authorisation of agreements and covenants affecting competition, privacy and secondary boycotts, exclusive dealing conduct and mergers and for the notification of exclusive dealing conduct. The regulations also provided that the then Trade Practices Commission may decide that a concessional fee was payable in certain circumstances. Five of the fees were $7,500 reduced with a concession to $1,500 and one fee was $2,500 reduced with a concession to $500. There was no apparent AAT or other external review of this commercially valuable discretion and the Committee wrote to the Minister. In reply, the Assistant Treasurer advised the Committee that external review was inappropriate because the decision was a technical one, the Trade Practices Commission was the best body to determine those technical issues and the costs and delay of independent review would outweigh any benefit. This was not a particularly satisfactory reply, because many technical decisions are subject to AAT or other independent external review. Indeed, technical decisions in many cases are particularly suited to review. Nevertheless the Committee accepted the advice but decided to include the matter in the Annual Report.

The President of the Administrative Review Council, quoting the Committee's Annual Report, then wrote to the Minister for Justice advising that, in the view of the ARC, the decisions relating to concessional fees should be subject to review. The Committee also wrote again to the Assistant Treasurer, referring to the ARC advice, asking that the regulations be amended to provide for external review. The Minister for Justice also wrote to the Assistant Treasurer suggesting merits review of the decisions by the Trade Practices Tribunal. The Assistant Treasurer replied to the Minister, with a copy to the Committee, advising that he did not favour merits review by either the AAT or the TPT.

By this time the 1996 Federal election had been held and the government had changed. Scrutiny of the regulations, however, continued. The Committee operates in a strictly non‐partisan way and addresses only personal rights and parliamentary propriety, avoiding policy issues. For these reasons its work continues despite changes in governments. In the present case there were also major changes to the enabling legislation, with the Trade Practices Commission becoming the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the Trade Practices Tribunal replaced by the Australian Competition Tribunal. The Committee, however, continued to pursue the matter.

The Committee then wrote to the Attorney‐General, with copies to the Assistant Treasurer and the President of the ARC, noting that the ARC is a statutory agency with the function, among other things, of making recommendations to the Minister on review of administrative decisions, and asking for confirmation that the Attorney‐General accepted the present recommendation of the ARC. The Attorney‐General replied that he favoured review by the ACT. The Committee then wrote again to the Assistant Treasurer asking that the regulations be amended to provide for review.

The Assistant Treasurer advised that, while he appreciated the importance of external merits review in improving the transparency and scrutiny of Commonwealth administrative decisions, merits review can increase the cost and complexity of regulation. These considerations need to be balanced against each other. The Assistant Treasurer further advised that in this case review would not be simple or trivial, with normally more than a week of hearings with decisions taking at least two months. Also, the right of review could provide an opportunity for applicants to use the fee decision in order to challenge the ACCC view on market definition for strategic purposes unrelated to the application in question. Further, external review involves costs to the government as well as to the applicant and the total costs would be greater than the differential between the concessional fee and the full fee. Finally, preparing an amendment of the regulations would be time consuming and involve significant resources.

The Committee then wrote to the Assistant Treasurer indicating that it was disappointed that he did not propose to amend the regulations. The Committee suggested that, given the unanimity of view between the Committee, the ARC and the Attorney‐General, there was a strong case to provide for review. The Assistant Treasurer replied that he could assure the Committee that he had taken careful account of its concerns but remained of the view that those particular decisions should not be subject to external merits review. The Assistant Treasurer further advised that, should circumstances change and a need for merits review arise, he would be happy to reconsider the matter. The Attorney‐General also wrote to the Assistant Treasurer, noting that the matters which he raised in opposition to external review were individually and cumulatively matters of significance. However, the Attorney‐General could not agree that these factors weighed heavily against external merits review. The Attorney‐General advised that similar agreements could be advanced for avoiding external review of many other administrative decisions, including ones of greater economic or political significance. The Attorney‐General advised that he regretted that the Assistant Treasurer had not accepted his advice on this occasion.

The matter must now stand for the time being. It is, as I say, disappointing that the regulations cannot be amended and that the Committee must report to the Senate that the regulations are deficient in respect of independent external merits review. Nevertheless, the Committee notes that its concerns were endorsed by the President of the Administrative Review Council and by the Attorney‐General and the Committee is grateful for this. The Committee will continue to monitor any amendments of the principal Regulations with a view to correcting this breach of its principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Calvert and the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present report No. 11 of 1997 entitled Extension of the National Film and Sound Archive, Acton ACT . I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows—
Madam President, the report which I have tabled concerns the proposed extension of the National Film and Sound Archive, Acton, ACT.

The Archive is housed in a historic building, formerly the Australian Institute of Anatomy. In passing, I should mention that this building was the subject of an inquiry by a previous Public Works Committee, in 1929. It cost just over 96,000 Pounds.

The proposal is substantially similar to one examined by the Committee in December 1995. Although a public hearing was held into the proposal, the Committee was unable to report on the reference due to the calling of the election. The proposal was re‐referred to the Committee in August and because of the substantial body of evidence taken by the previous Committee it was not considered necessary to conduct further hearings.
The scope of the proposal examined by the Committee examined by the involved the construction of:

. a new two‐storey building to house the Archive's administrative and technical functions, refurbishment of the existing Headquarters (including public galleries) to house the public functions of the National Film and Sound Archive;
. refurbishment of the existing Residence Building to house corporate affairs staff;
. demolition or removal for sale of the existing demountable buildings, metal‐clad storage structures and nitrate vaults;
. redevelopment of the character of the site and buildings within a landscape setting; and
. retention of the existing permanent carpark with minor modifications. Additional on‐site parking will be provided for approximately 25 cars and five tourist coaches.
When referred to the Committee the estimated out turn cost of the proposal was $14.85 million.
The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The National Film and Sound Archive was established in 1984 and has as its charter the development, preservation and promotion of the national collection of recorded moving images and sound materials.

The Archive's collection consists of more than one million items including discs, audio and video tapes, films, phonograph cylinders, piano rolls and artefacts and a further million items of documentation such as photographs, scripts, publicity items and newspaper clippings.

After inspecting the buildings housing the Archive at Acton, the Committee found that the main historic headquarters building is suitable for the public functions of the Archive but is inadequate for its administrative and specialist technical functions. Existing deficiencies are:

. basement specialist technical facilities are inefficient and do not satisfy current occupational health and safety standards, including in particular fire safety, the Building Code of Australia and Australian Standards relating to current use;
. the use of gallery space for office and specialist technical accommodation is at odds with the building's heritage significance and limits the space available for public exhibitions; and
. the construction of demountable buildings has substantially compromised the site's heritage significance and is not consistent with the intentions of the National Capital Plan.

After inspecting the specialist technical facilities in the basement and registration and accession areas housed in demountable buildings, the Committee came away with a strong perception that the Archive is indeed served by a dedicated staff. The staff have displayed stoic forbearance in very difficult working conditions. It was obvious that the major concern of staff has been to keep the facilities operating despite potential safety risks.

The Committee concluded that the Archive's administrative and technical accommodation is of very low quality, functionally unsuitable, inefficient and does not comply with current fire safety and occupational health and safety standards.

After examining a range of options which would overcome these problems, the Committee concluded that the construction of a new administrative and technical support building contiguous with the existing Headquarters building at Acton would be the least expensive and more practical solution.

The major element of the proposal examined by the Committee will involve the construction of a new two storey building of 4230 square metres along the north‐west of the existing Headquarters building to house the Archive's administrative and technical functions.

The site occupied by the Archive's buildings is within designated areas of the National Capital Plan. As well, the site and the Headquarters building are listed on the Register of the National Estate. For these reasons, planning and design of the extensions required a sensitive approach. The extension has been designed to respect, but not to mimic, the existing building.

The Committee concluded that the heritage importance of the site and the existing Headquarters building are reflected in planning principles adopted for the design. The materials and finishes to be used will complement the existing Headquarters building.

In terms of the scope of the proposal, the Committee concluded that the extent of the proposed new building will meet the requirements of the National Film and Sound Archive for at least the next ten years, it will improve efficiency, enable display areas to be increased and will attract more visitors.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Quesetion resolved in the affirmative.

SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX (MEMBERS OF CONSTITUTIONALLY PROTECTED SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION BILL 1997

This bill ensures that the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge for High Income Earners (as announced by the Treasurer in the 1996‐97 Budget on 20 August 1996) will apply to members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds.

This bill complements the surcharge legislation already passed by the Parliament. The existing superannuation contribution surcharge legislation imposes surcharge on superannuation providers. The legislation cannot apply to certain State superannuation funds because they are protected from revenue measures under the Constitution.
This bill strengthens the equity of the surcharge measure by ensuring that the surcharge will apply to all high income earners.

The collection mechanism under the bill is similar to that which applies to members of unfunded defined benefits superannuation funds under the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997. The only difference is that the liability to pay the surcharge will rest with the member rather than the superannuation fund. The surcharge liability for a member for a year will be accumulated in a surcharge debt account (maintained by the Commissioner of Taxation) for the member and will be payable by the member when the member's superannuation benefit becomes payable. The member will have the option of paying off the debt as it arises once an amount of surcharge has been assessed.

This bill forms part of the total legislative package to introduce the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge for High Income Earners. The estimated revenue impact for the whole surcharge measure is $480 million in 1997-98, $470 million in 1998-99 and $530 million in 1999-2000.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX (MEMBERS OF CONSTITUTIONALLY PROTECTED SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) IMPOSITION BILL 1997

This bill ensures that the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge for High Income Earners (as announced by the Treasurer in the 1996-97 Budget on 20 August 1996) will apply to members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds.

This bill imposes the superannuation contributions tax and declares the rate of superannuation contributions surcharge. The assessment of the superannuation contributions surcharge is dealt with in the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997.

The estimated revenue impact of the surcharge legislation is set out in the Second Reading Speech to the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS AND TERMINATION PAYMENTS TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill makes a number of consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997, the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1997, the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997, the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Consequential Amendments) Act 1997, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments and Early Payments) Act 1983 and the Termination Payments Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997.

The amendments to these acts are required as a consequence of the introduction of the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997 and the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Funds) Imposition Bill 1997. Other amendments clarify the operation of the surcharge and make technical corrections to the acts.

The financial impact of this bill is considered to be negligible. The estimated revenue impact of the package of surcharge legislation is set out in the Second Reading Speech to the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX IMPOSITION AMENDMENT BILL 1997
This bill amends the Superannuation Contributions Tax Imposition Act 1997 to round the rate of superannuation contributions surcharge imposed under that act to 5 decimal places.
This bill also makes technical amendments to the provisions in that act concerning the actions the Commissioner must take where a member has not provided his or her tax file number.
This bill is estimated to have negligible financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TERMINATION PAYMENTS TAX IMPOSITION AMENDMENT BILL 1997
This bill amends the Termination Payments Tax Imposition Act 1997 to round the rate of termination payments surcharge imposed under that act to 5 decimal places.
This bill is estimated to have negligible financial impact.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill amends the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Application to the Commonwealth—Reduction of Benefits) Act 1997 and nine acts dealing with superannuation for Federal Parliamentarians, new federal Judges and certain tribunal members with the status of a Judge, Commonwealth sector civilian employees, Defence Force personnel and the Governor‐General. These acts are the Defence Act 1903, the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991, the Judges Pensions Act 1968, and the Governor‐General Act 1974.

The amendments will ensure that the superannuation contributions surcharge, which is designed to make superannuation arrangements more equitable by addressing the concessional tax treatment for superannuation contributions in respect of high income earners, applies to people entitled to superannuation benefits under the acts to be amended by the bill. However, serving federal Judges are constitutionally protected from the application of the surcharge. As is the case for all other employees whose superannuation contributions are subject to the surcharge, members of these schemes will be able to pay the surcharge as it falls due instead of having the amounts deducted from their superannuation entitlements.

The schemes under the acts to be amended by the bill are either unfunded or largely unfunded defined benefits schemes. Except where the surcharge is pre‐paid by a scheme member, it is notionally accumulated during a member's service and paid by the scheme trustee or administrator when the member's benefits become payable. The bill will ensure that trustees are able to meet their surcharge liability.

The bill ensures that reductions in benefits in respect of the surcharge are made in a manner which is fair and equitable taking into account the complexities of defined benefits schemes. However, any reduction must not be more than fifteen per cent of the employer‐financed component of the benefit that accrued after 20 August 1996.
The surcharge is a revenue measure. This bill ensures that the impact is passed on to the high income earners in the superannuation schemes provided under the acts to be amended by the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in relation to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill 1997. Like so many of the government's bills, this bill is an amalgamation of some parts which are beneficial to the community, and other parts which are quite harsh and which the opposition does not support. I want to say at the outset that, despite our reservations about some components of the bill, we do not seek either to amend or to oppose the bill. However, I will be moving a second reading amendment which outlines some of our concerns.
—Can we have a copy of it?

—That second reading amendment is being circulated at this time. I want to make it clear that the reason the opposition is not opposing this bill is not that we support all aspects of it but that we would not like to see the beneficial aspects of the bill for our veterans deferred for some considerable amount of time while amendments are debated. So we will be allowing the bill passage today in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill has three major elements: the first element relates to the clarification of the advance payment of veterans' pensions; the second element deals with the Commonwealth's liability being extinguished for the medical consequences of smoking by veterans in the future; and the third element deals with changes to repatriation benefits and a clarification of defence declarations. The opposition supports the first two elements.

The first element relating to advance payments stems from the 1995 legislation—passed when Labor was in government—that allows pensioners of modest means to have advance payments on their pension of up to $500, or 13 times the person's fortnightly rate. This amount must be repaid within six months. These payments can be used for things such as home repairs or equipment and travel where their fortnightly pension cannot meet these expenses. It allows veterans some flexibility with their income and expenditure. This measure is now being liberalised to also allow disability pensioners and war widows to have access to these payments. This further extension of the previous Labor government's initiative is, of course, supported.

As I have said, the second element relates to the extinguishment of the Commonwealth's liability for the medical consequences of future smoking. As of 31 December this year, the taking up of smoking in the future or an increase in smoking will not be compensatable by the Commonwealth. Of course, this will only apply where illnesses relate to that tobacco use, and not through some other cause. It will not affect veterans who acquired a service‐related smoking habit before 1 January 1998. So if a veteran took up smoking as a result of their war service, continued to smoke and, as a result, developed some sort of disease, they are still covered despite this amendment. The opposition thinks that this date is reasonable and will be supporting this portion of the bill.

We have difficulty with the third element of the bill because we believe that it is inequitable and is quite harsh in relation to some members of our veterans community. The 1996 election platform of this government promised to review all overseas service anomalies in respect of both medals and repatriation benefits.

A joint Department of Veterans' Affairs and Department of Defence review was established and changes to repatriation were announced in the 1997 budget. There were no community representatives on this review committee and there was no public consultation. That is unfortunate, because some of the oversights possibly may not have occurred if in fact there had been community input, in particular from the veterans community.

BREAK.PARA: The report produced by this joint committee was never released to the public. It seems to me quite contrary to general principles of open government that seem to be accepted not only by the opposition but also, for the most part, by the government and minority parties. In this day and age, I would have thought that that was quite a normal procedure.
The evidence considered or the method used by the committee to draw its conclusions have never been released either.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was tabled in the Reps.

—As I understand it, the actual conclusions that were reached by the committee were tabled but not the complete report, including the reasoning behind those conclusions, which is quite a different thing. The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, Mrs Bishop, has even gone so far as to refuse to allow an overall departmental briefing. Again, in relation to principles of open government that most members of the Australian parliament would support, that is quite unfortunate. All of this is in contrast to the former Labor government's Committee of Inquiry into Defence and Defence‐related Awards. For that inquiry, community members with service experience were consulted, there was consultation with ex‐service organisations and the full report was published and made public.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition believes that the government has been inconsistent in its treatment of anomalies. Even though some changes are welcomed, there are other anomalies that this bill fails to pick up. The opposition welcomes the extension of service pension entitlements to some categories, primarily to the United Nations peacekeeping categories and to embassy guards and evacuation personnel who remained in Vietnam after January 1973. The opposition also welcomes the extension of recognition for operational service to a number of areas, including the Far East Strategic Reserve and RAAF servicemen in Thailand. While we recognise these extensions, they do not cover all the anomalies. Specifically, the qualifying service status for RAAF personnel who served in Ubon, Thailand from June 1965 to August 1968 should be further extended, and there should also be a further extension for those who served on RAN ships in the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency.

The second area of concern set out in our second reading amendment is that qualifying service status should be extended to personnel who served at RAAF Ubon in Thailand between those two dates that I mentioned. We believe the fact that this bill has not dealt with that issue is a major oversight. The government argues that RAAF personnel who served in Thailand from 1962 until 1968 pursuant to Australia's South‐East Asia Treaty Organisation obligations were there merely to guard Thai airspace, and that their activities were entirely separate from Australia's Vietnam involvement. On 13 February, Mrs Bishop said:

There was a RAAF contingent based at Ubon in Thailand on the borders of Laos and Cambodia between 1962 and 1968. They were there pursuant to our arrangements and our obligations under SEATO and it was separate from our involvement with the Vietnam war.

RAAF personnel despatched to Ubon in May 1962 were involved in Australia's first bilateral military engagement in the region with the United States. This was an important strategic location 50 kilometres from the Laos border, 80 kilometres from the Cambodian border, 200 kilometres from the Ho Chi Minh trail and close to the Mekong River. Until 1965 the personnel at Ubon were basically engaged in a schedule of routine training.

The opposition does not accept that personnel at Ubon were not engaged in activities worthy of qualifying service from June 1965 until August 1968. The reasons for this are: following apparent Chinese air assistance to North Vietnam, the United States decided in 1965 to escalate operations at Ubon. A fully integrated Royal Thai Air Force and United States Air Force defence system was established under effective US control. RAAF personnel No. 79 Squadron came under effective control of the US 2nd Air Division Task Operations Centre.
The document Air Defence: Thailand Involving the Royal Australian Air Force No. 79 Squadron outlined new rules of engage ment. I will quote them, at the risk of consuming too much of my time:

Applicability: Applies to all RTAF units and all other units, including the RAAF, responsive to CINCRTAF for Air Defence of Thailand . . . An aircraft commits a hostile act when it conducts unauthorised aerial reconnaissance or combat tactics within the national boundary of Thailand.

The rules of engagement operated under from June 1965 were warlike in nature and were not restricted to acting in self‐defence. RAAF personnel in Ubon performed similar tasks to those RAAF personnel in Vietnam. No allied air bases occurred in either Ubon or Vietnam. Statutory declarations by RAAF officers who served there confirm extensive enemy activity directed at Ubon which entailed danger to Australian personnel. These include a Thai helicopter shot down in May 1967 and a USAF C130 being hit by ground fire in its approach to land. There are various other examples that show that this was the case.

RAN ships that served in the Far East Strategic Reserve should also be covered. Again, there are three arguments that justify their inclusion. RAN personnel were allegedly never allotted—and we know the continuous debate about allotment—to duty. They were not subject to military law. They did not incur additional operational risk. This is the argument put by the government. With the budget announcement granting them access to a disability pension, the coalition has abandoned the first two arguments because, of course, to receive that pension you must have been allotted. The government maintains the argument that they did not incur sufficient additional operational risk to justify the service pension.

The operations that RAN personnel assumed in Malaya were clearly beyond peacetime demands. The primary role as is laid down in the general directive was to secure and defend the sea lanes and coastline of Malaya. The secondary role was to participate in operations against communist forces. Actual operations included escorting troops through the harbour, which was allegedly mined, enforcing a blockade of enemy positions, preventing infiltration by the enemy, bombardment of communist positions, general supportive functions for other Australian and Commonwealth personnel, and protection of merchant shipping. It seems to me that these activities being considered are conduct worthy of appropriate recognition of access to service pensions. I must say that I am not convinced by the arguments put by the government on this issue.

The final matter that we have raised in our second reading amendment requests that the government restore entitlements to Vietnam naval logistical support personnel for the journey to and from Australia and Vietnam. I was very glad to hear that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Scott, announced this measure in question time today. I have to say that I applaud the government for this measure. There are a lot of members of the veteran community who would be very grateful for that extension. I think it is a shame that the government took so long to recognise the logical error in their refusal to include that. Bearing that in mind, I will not go into that issue at any further length.

In relation to the second part of our amendment, I would like to read a letter I have received from the RAAF Ubon Reunion‐Recognition Group which I believe is quite important in expressing the views of veterans who did serve in the conflict there. It says:

Recent statements made by Cheryl Kernot, concerning the "uncaring attitude of your government" that have so moved her, ring true for our group also. Despite unequivocal and irrefutable evidence, presented to your Minister Bishop (and other members of your government) our group is still denied our rightful active service recognition regarding our service at Ubon particularly, from 1965 onward. And, this despite total support for our cause from the Opposition and from various veterans groups including the RSL of Australia.

Our group is only around 1500 strong. However, our people are spread far and wide across this land throughout many electorates and we have the support of many other veteran groups ie support from many people in many electorates.

The apolitical nature of our group to date will cease if we are not granted rightful recognition soon. Our intention will be to physically assist any candidate, other than Coalition members, in the next election. Furthermore, we have assurances from the executives of some other veteran groups that their members could be lobbied to at least vote to favour the Labor party that has so actively and publicly stated support for our cause. Moreover, we will approach the RSL to outline our case in the "RSL News" magazine, including a highlighting of the hurdles unfairly placed in our recognition path by your government.

I do not quote that letter in order to threaten you—and I suppose it will not frighten you. But I raise it to show you how strongly that particular group of people feel about this issue, how unfair and inequitable I think it is for them and how little it would cost this government to give those people the recognition I believe they so rightly deserve. I move:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:
(a) condemns the Government for its confused, secretive and inconsistent handling of repatriation benefits and awards for overseas service; and

(b) believes the Government should extend qualifying service status to personnel at RAAF Ubon Thailand from June 1965 to August 1968 and to RAN ships that served in the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan emergency.
I urge the government to reconsider its position in relation to those two matters as it has in relation to the third.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill . The bill extends eligibility for compensation and the service pension to a number of veterans who did not previously qualify for these benefits. It extinguishes Commonwealth liability for the medical consequences of future smoking and it clarifies Defence declarations.

SPEECH.PARA: It reintroduces a couple of very welcome initiatives which were contained in a previous veterans bill, which we first looked at earlier this year, including the establishment of a veterans vocational rehabilitation program to assist veterans who are re-entering the civilian work force. The Democrats strongly support extending compensation entitlements to those veterans who are listed in this bill and we strongly support the recognition that service in Vietnam between 12 January 1973 and 29 April 1975 was, in fact, war‐like service.

We also believe that the changes to compensation for smoking in this bill are positive and that they reflect the much deeper understanding we now have on the dangers of smoking. I hope that these changes to compensation for smoking will dissuade veterans who do not currently smoke from taking it up and dissuade those veterans who do currently smoke from increasing their level of smoking. I probably should declare a kind of vested interest. My uncle, who is a veteran of the Second World War, may be seeking compensation because he was advised by service doctors to take up smoking while he was serving—to calm his nerves, apparently. We have come a long way since those days.

However, I would like to make a few comments with regard to several changes which were not contained in this bill in its original form but which have been included as a result of government amendments in the House of Representatives. Once again, the Democrats welcome the substance of these changes. In particular, we welcome the establishment of the veterans vocational rehabilitation program. However, we do not welcome the government's claims that the Democrats played some kind of a role in delaying the implementation of these changes. In fact, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) made some pretty cheap shots in the House of Representatives which he knew were not true, I guess because there was no‐one there to put the contrary point of view, although I imagine the opposition did that in their own case.

I want to make clear to the Senate today that any blame for a delay in relation to the implementation of these measures must rest firmly on the government's shoulders. The government stands condemned for trying to shift the blame for the lateness of the adoption of these changes onto the shoulders of the Democrats and the opposition. This government needs to be condemned for the comments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the House of Representatives. His comments that these measures have been delayed because of `an unholy alliance' between the Democrats and the opposition are nothing short of an untruth.

The piece of legislation in which this government previously tried to introduce these very positive and welcome changes also contained some very harsh measures which, if accepted, would have hurt the very veterans this government claims to be so concerned about. One of the harshest of these measures was the inclusion in income and assets tests for the service pension of the superannuation assets held by veterans. If the Senate had passed this measure, veterans would have been forced to run down their superannuation before being eligible for the service pension.

The Democrats, with the opposition, opposed these measures because we believe that the superannuation assets should be exempt to protect the nest eggs of the many people who have worked hard and sacrificed income to provide for their retirement. It is unfair for the government to encourage people into superannuation and then penalise them for following that advice, and this move threatened public confidence and support for Australia's superannuation system—confidence and support on which our `super' system relies. The Democrats voted against these harsh measures because, unlike the government, we care about veterans. Because we care about veterans we also urged the government to separate the measures contained in this previous bill so that we could pass the rest of them.

The government then held veterans to ransom by refusing to pass the good parts of the previous bill, despite our urging them to do so, unless the Senate agreed to pass the harsh parts as well. I regard this as blackmail and the Democrats condemn the government for using Australia's veterans as a lever to push very harsh measures.
Now I would like to turn to the opposition amendments.

The Democrats will be supporting the opposition amendments today because we believe the government has failed the veterans in the areas to which these amendments relate. The first part of the opposition's amendment deals with this government's very poor performance and inconsistent handling of repatriation benefits and awards for overseas service. I would particularly like to draw the Senate's attention to the appalling way this government has handled the whole area of medalling, that is, the awarding of medals. Minister Bishop's bungling over the awarding of double medals, with the on again/off again saga of medals for a number of Australia's veterans, is one that deserves a special mention for the great deal of anguish, pain and distress it caused.

The Democrats will also be supporting the second part of the opposition's amendment. We are happy to support part 2 of this amendment because we believe there is a very strong case for extending service status to personnel at RAAF Ubon, Thailand from June 1965 to August 1968 and to RAN ships that served in the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency. After many discussions and ongoing correspondence with veterans who served in both these forces I accept that these men have been unjustly dealt with when it comes to eligibility for the benefits. We must never forget the incredible sacrifice these men made for us and for future generations of Australians. For this reason I would urge the government to reconsider the case of these two groups of veterans.

As Senator Neal pointed out, today in the House of Representatives the government did take up part of the original amendments that the opposition were moving, and we are grateful for that. That was to do, of course, with entitlements to Vietnam naval logistic support personnel for the journey to and from Australia. We are grateful the government is doing that.

There is one other issue I would like to raise. Perhaps I will seek an answer to this from the minister. I am sure his advisers are listening. In the schedule of service which is now to be regarded as operational service is the issue of the Commonwealth occupation forces in Japan. I have a question about the date mentioned. I was inclined to move an amendment to alter the date, but I would be happy to receive an explanation about this.

The dates given in the schedule are 3 January 1949 to 30 June 1951 inclusive. I am sure the government has a reason for that, but it is not clear to me. I understand that Australian servicemen served in Japan from 1946 onwards not from 1949 onwards. It seems to me that there is every reason to extend this provision to all Australian servicemen who served in Japan during that period and I am not clear why it should not be 1946—and I do not have the month—to 1951. I would appreciate an explanation from the government.

In conclusion, I say that it is important that we never forget that the expense of war does not cease with the end of hostilities. Even after peace is restored, the cost of war is still high in the lives of Australia's veterans and their families. For this reason, the Democrats do not support any policy which fails to acknowledge a special obligation to veterans or which does not recognise their special needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill 1997 . I want to talk particularly about a case that came to light which supports the opposition's resolution about the Ubon contingent. An article appeared in the Western Advocate , the Bathurst paper, on 1 October which had the story of a now civilian but former RAAF member, Joe Richards, and his time at Ubon. It is very illuminating to hear his description of what took place there.

SPEECH.PARA: He was there for six months to December 1966 working as a rescue fireman alongside US service personnel in the rescue section. Starting in 1962 they were officially charged with maintenance and with working around the air force base and classified as a peacekeeping force. It is pretty obvious from Mr Richards's comments that this was more than a peacekeeping force. He stated:
We were on duty 24 hours on and 24 hours off for six months solid.
We were 300 Australians on one side of a landing strip with 3000 Americans on the other side. A full strike base, 24 hours a day, flying operations into Vietnam.
We were part of the Vietnam War. There were planes coming in to the base all shot‐up. We were there for any emergency.
Several times we were on alert. Communis
ts fired on planes, they were either Thai‐Cong or Pathet‐Lao.

This gentleman is upset because, after six years in the RAAF, he has been unable to obtain a home loan from defence services. It is pretty clear from this gentleman's story that this was more than just a peacekeeping force. He goes on to say:
. . . Australian servicemen were passed off by Government and authorities as peace keepers at a time US Congress also claimed they had no bases in Thailand.

That was the propaganda of the time. Mr Richards knows—from the declassification of documents in the US in August of this year—that the details of this were revealed and that it was seen as service. He is one of a group of 1,000 or more RAAF personnel who spent time at Ubon.

There was a RAAF officer who lost his life when his Sabre jet crashed at Ubon and, according to some of the statutory declarations which Senator Neal referred to, the cause was not established—although insurgent action cannot be discounted. That was part of a statutory declaration made by Frederick Knudsen, RAAF Officer Commanding.

We were told that there were many false alerts, sometimes caused by meteorological phenomena which showed up on US radar, and other incidences where mysterious aircraft were detected. There are statutory declarations stating that an enemy MiG21, which identified and chased two RAAF Sabres from Ubon, was shot down by a missile from a US Air Force Phantom in January 1967. Unmarked C123s were identified on 1 December 1965. Two Sabres scrambled and shadowed a Beechcraft twin turboprop aircraft, which then turned back over the Laotian border on 21 October 1965.

Hot scrambles were made to search for suspected IL28 bombers on 7 February 1968 and on several occasions during April and May of 1968. We know that there were further alerts after the Australian troops pulled out. Three further confirmed insurgency ground attacks were reported. As I said, there was the loss of one pilot officer L. J. McGrath, who was killed in a crash close to Ubon on 3 January 1968.

It seems very strange that you have this type of activity taking place. You also now have the release of the US documents which indicate and acknowledge that they did have an air force base at Ubon, 50 kilometres inside the Thai border. According to Mr Richards, who was there at the time, they ran 24‐hour operations into Vietnam or Laos. In his own words, it was a full on thing. It was not just keeping the peace. They were said to be peacekeepers, but they were on 24-hour on, 24‐hour off, shifts. It is vitally important that this be taken into consideration and that the work these people did be recognised.

Whilst it might not have been intense pressure that they were under, they were there under the threat of being fired upon, of having active military, warlike actions taken against them. They were not to know whether the alerts or alarms were false or the real thing because there was enough of the real thing happening for them to be concerned that it could well have been live ammunition they were facing and it could have been unfriendly fire. This must have had some effect upon these gentlemen and certainly caused them stress.

It is vitally important that the opposition's motion be passed. It would be recognition of the work that these people did from 1965 to 1968. To say that it is not granted qualifying service status is to them very offensive, particularly as they know that they were under fire.

The naval personnel involved in the Malaysian emergency between 1955 and 1960 are seeking to be recognised. One of the reasons given for not having any recognition is that the enemy did not have a navy. The enemy also did not have an air force, but the RAAF personnel were given recognition.

The naval personnel had to make sorties into areas where mines may have been laid. They were there to enforce a blockade of enemy positions. They would track and intercept enemy signals. They prevented enemy infiltration. They bombarded communist positions. They provided general support for land forces, including escorting troops through the mined harbour. To say that this was not somewhat dangerous is to ignore the obvious facts of the truth of the matter.

They were also apparently exposed to danger when they were on shore leave. They were certainly fired upon when they were in harbour. During the 1957 race riot, sailors were exposed to danger while onshore, and shots are reported to have been fired at some while they were in Singapore. So it remains a bit puzzling to me as to why there has been a line drawn in the sand. This is not a large number of people but a significant number of people who have been prepared to go, fight and stand up in the face of enemy fire for what they believe in, but they are being denied this recognition that they deservedly seek.

It is vitally important that the government do what they have done already with the Vietnam naval logistical personnel entitlements. They have actually reviewed and today announced that they are prepared to grant them entitlements. Why not the rest of them? These are people who, the cream of their youth, went and worked hard and fought hard. In real terms, they were prepared to make the ultimate sacrifice if they had to, as certainly one of the RAAF personnel did near Ubon.

It behoves the government to very seriously think about this and to review this matter. The former personnel are not happy. They feel they have been neglected. They feel their contribution has not been recognised. They feel that the value of the work they did and their worth is not being considered to be the same as others who were in areas where there is no contention as to what they in fact served.

It ill behoves the government to be so miserly and to not care what happened to this group of people who at the time would have worked under stress. If you are on a 24-hour shift and have to remain alert, to conduct sorties, to maintain perimeter guards and to be ready for any emergency that might come, you are living under stress and strain. Even if they might not have seen a great deal of active fire, they would have obviously been in areas where munitions were being handled, where bombs were being handled, where planes were being loaded and, presumably, where planes were coming back that were damaged and had not been able to discharge their load. So these people were placed in danger.

It would well behove the government to go and look at the documentation that has been released now by the US department and just check and recognise that the US government, the US military, were running sorties from the Ubon air base into Laos and Cambodia at that time. It is incumbent upon the government to be cognisant of that, to recognise that, and to give these people the entitlements which they are due.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to sum up on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill 1997 . From the comments made initially by Senator Neal, there would appear to be some confusion between her and the Labor spokesmen in the House of Representatives, Mr Ferguson. I am concerned that, in the intervening period of time between when the bill was introduced in that place and here, they have not been able to get a consistent view or consistent opinion in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which was referred to entitled Review of service anomalies was tabled on 25 September 1997 by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, in the House during the summing‐up of the bill. That report looked at 15 anomalies and recommended 12 separate anomalies that have resulted in an extension of the benefits to 10,500 veterans. Contrary to what Senator Neal seemed to imply, Labor has not asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs for a full departmental briefing. We would be happy to oblige.

This bill is good news for the veteran community, and its passage is eagerly awaited. The veteran community is concerned that amendments have been moved in the Senate. I hope the opposition realises that it is causing distress to over 20,000 veterans who will be directly affected by any further delay to this bill.

I will address the amendments directly, and perhaps in reverse order to that put forward in the Labor motion. Firstly, it is a bit late for the opposition to claim now that Royal Australian Navy personnel who served in the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency should be granted qualifying service for the granting of a service pension.

The Far East Strategic Reserve Act 1956 was repealed by the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. If Labor had wanted to address the concerns of naval personnel who served in the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Malayan Emergency, it has had plenty of chances. Even when Labor went to the extent of amending the VEA in 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1995, it never bothered to address those concerns. Not only did Labor continue the exclusion for qualifying service for members of the Far East Strategic Reserve, but it also continued the exclusion of operational service.

We intend to extend operational service status to members of the FESR through this bill. The naval association has raised its objections over this matter with the government, and this matter is being looked at. If any individual members of the Far East Strategic Reserve can prove that they incurred danger from the enemy, then their case can be considered. Subject to meeting the same requirements that the army and air force veterans have to meet, they would then be eligible for full repatriation benefits and they would qualify for a service pension.

As for the service of the Royal Australian Air Force at the Ubon Air Base in Thailand, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs thanks the RAAF Ubon Recognition Group for its submission. Minister Scott has written to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop), asking for the new evidence presented by the RAAF Ubon Recognition Group to be examined and dealt with by the procedures established by this government.

Operational service will apply to all members of the Royal Australian Air Force who served at Ubon. This will entitle them to apply for disability pensions to cover any injuries they sustained during their service at Ubon. Similarly, if individual members believe they incurred danger from the enemy, they should apply to Veterans' Affairs with their evidence. The gate is always open for any member of the RAAF to put his case forward.

The information that both Senator West and Senator Neal referred to has been received by Minister Scott and has been passed to Minister Bishop for examination. It will be handled in accordance with the arrangements that they have made with the Prime Minister. Mrs Bishop will examine it and make recommendations to the Prime Minister.

This process has been shown to be a quick, equitable and comprehensive mechanism for examining any service anomalies. In line with the government's commitment to examine any new anomalies brought to the attention of the government, I am pleased to inform the Senate that the issue of port‐to‐port coverage for Vietnam navy logistics support personnel has been resolved by the government.

This issue was first brought to the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 6 August 1997. The anomaly has now been resolved. As Senator Neal referred to in her speech, this announcement was made earlier today. I refer in particular to the media release by Bruce Scott MP, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, dated today and entitled `Government removes anomaly for Vietnam navy logistics support port‐to‐port eligibility'.

That press release sets out the details and the extensions that this means to 10,000 Vietnam veterans who now have access to the disability pension and health care for conditions acquired at any stage during their journey to and from the operational area. I also refer to the fact that this fixes a problem originally created by Labor in 1986, with an instrument signed by the then defence minister, Kim Beazley, denying navy logistics support personnel eligibility for port‐to‐port coverage.

No legislation is needed to correct this anomaly. A retrospective instrument of deemed allotment will provide port‐to‐port coverage to these naval veterans. This proves two points: firstly, this government has a genuine commitment to rectify several anomalies; and, secondly, the process of review works. No such speedy mechanism existed during the 13 years of Labor government.

I also refer to the issue raised by Senator Woodley on the matter of compensation coverage of Australian BCOF personnel in Japan. I am disappointed that Senator Woodley did not acknowledge the fact that officers of the government had faxed an information sheet on this matter to both his Brisbane and Canberra offices yesterday for his attention. That matter was not addressed in the comments that he made. If he would like a further copy of that advice, I have one here.

There are other important measures in this bill. The first is the opportunity to allow aged pensioners who also receive a disability pension to choose to be paid both pensions by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. For the veterans and their eligible partners, it will mean that they need to deal with only one department. Over 10,000 veterans have already indicated that they wish to have their pensions paid by Veterans' Affairs.

The second measure is the establishment of a vocational rehabilitation scheme for veterans. This government undertook to monitor closely the long‐term care needs of Vietnam veterans. This measure has been long awaited by the Vietnam veteran community and would now be in place if the Democrats had not unfairly amended the 1996 Veterans' Affairs Budget Bill.

The scheme will be available to all eligible veterans. The legislation presented guarantees that those veterans who volunteer to take part in a rehabilitation program under the scheme will not have their pensions reduced while participating in that program and will receive at least the same income had they not participated in the rehabilitation program and entered employment.

This bill demonstrates the government's commitment to expanding and improving benefits to the veterans' community. These measures are not merely a reward for those who serve this country in war. They are benefits veterans have earned by their sacrifices.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the specific question asked by Senator Woodley with regard to the coverage of Australian BCOF personnel in Japan, I referred to the facts that had been made available to his office yesterday and to which he has now referred. Given the brevity of the briefing note, it might be best if I just read it, because it then goes into the record, and add to it. The briefing note actually reads:

SPEECH.PARA: No service in BCOF has ever been covered under repatriation legislation after 30 June 1951. The significance of this date is that it is the last possible day on which anyone could render service in connection with World War II. This is set out in section 72 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The anomaly being addressed in the bill is that at times prior to 30 June 1951 Australian defence personnel in the BCOF were covered under different compensation provisions while performing the same duties in the same places at the same times in Japan. This differing compensation coverage arose from the different terms of enlistment. Early enlistments during or approximate to World War II continue to receive the more generous coverage under the Repatriation Act or Interim Forces Benefits Act while later enlistments or re‐enlistments in the permanent forces had the standard Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act coverage.

The bill provides a generous solution to even up compensation coverage. It is not feasible to now remove earlier generosity as a solution to anomalies. No ex-service organisation has approached the department since the budget announcement to amend or challenge the appropriateness of the 30 June 1951 end date, which has now stood for five and a half decades. There is no suggestion that BCOF personnel in Japan after 30 June 1951 experienced any conditions that warranted compen sation coverage other than that provided under the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act.

The measures contained in the bill mean that ADF personnel performing the same duties in the same places at the same times are covered under the same compensation arrangements. Former members of BCOF who remained in Japan after they were transferred to British Commonwealth Forces Korea have separate eligibility or entitlements under the VEA.
Senator Woodley also asked a question with regard to service before 1949. I am advised that this is already covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act as being included in World War II service.
