SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill makes a series of amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 in relation to areas such as certified agreements, Australian workplace agreements, the Employment Advocate, the no‐disadvantage test, termination of employment, freedom of association and union disamalgamation. I will not be making detailed comments on all of these issues in my second reading contribution, but I would like to express my concern at the general trend to amend this already flawed legislation by tipping the scales even further in favour of employers.

SPEECH.PARA: In my home state of Western Australia we have seen the various waves of so-called reform being pushed through the state parlia ment by Minister Kierath, including the most recent farce when the government went to extreme lengths to pass its legislation before the new legislative councillors took their seats and the government lost control of the Legislative Council for the first time in 100 years. I suspect that this bill is just the first of a series of federal waves which will continue to erode the beachhead of already eroded worker protections.

The changing rules applying to the role and powers of the Employment Advocate are one aspect that is of great concern. I strongly opposed the creation of this position in the 1996 bill because I felt it was designed more as an Employer Advocate and I have not changed my position. I believe that those in Western Australia who have already been affected will certainly justify that.

The amendments before us in this bill in large part add to my concerns and certainly do not provide any of the protections for workers generally or special categories of workers such as migrant women, the disabled, or young people that I attempted to have inserted during the committee stage of the Workplace Relations Bill in late 1996. What the government fails to acknowledge in this bill and in the Workplace Relations Act itself is that there is a massive difference in the relative negotiating power of employers and employees, particularly as we move into Minister Reith's brand new world of individual, take‐it‐or‐leave‐it, contract negotiation.

I would like to remind the Senate of some comments that I made in this place on 30 September 1997 in relation to a ministerial statement by Minister Reith on the topic of small business. In that statement, he acknowledged the fact that I agree with him that small business operators were often disadvantaged in their dealings with big business. Accordingly, the minister was announcing that he would introduce amendments to the Trade Practices Act that would give protection to small business in its commercial dealings with big business.

I applaud that move, but I have to wonder why the minister—who, of course, also has responsibility for industrial relations—does not also consider the need for protection of employees in their contract negotiations with employers. We know that it is a take it or leave it system that the government is enforcing.

I will leave any detailed comments to the committee stage of the bill, but I will indicate here that I will oppose many of the clauses in the bill. I will most likely oppose the bill in its entirety, given the likely outcome of the voting on the amendments before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 points out that the amendments are technical. The first full paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes a number of technical amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (the WR Act) and other legislation.

Although the bill carries out some technical amendments, there is a great importance attached in the second reading speech to those technical amendments. The first page of the second reading speech also says:

The scope for our reforms to continue to bring about the productivity improvements which are necessary to underpin sustainable economic growth will be further enhanced by the technical amendments proposed in this bill.

Speeches, of course, are limited, but there is nothing in the second reading speech that goes to support that proposition. No doubt, when we come to the committee stages, some questions will be asked about evidence and evidence will be forthcoming. I notice that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Troeth) is now at the table in charge of the bill. I would like to acknowledge Senator Troeth's presence and congratulate her on her appointment.

As Senator Margetts has said, the big issue is whether the philosophy underlying the Workplace Relations Act is the proper philosophy to carry this nation forward so that it improves economically, socially, culturally and in every other way. As has been said again and again in debate in this chamber, there is considerable argument and considerable doubt as to whether the system of individual contracts will be able to underpin a better social, economic and cultural life in Australia. There is considerable doubt about that for a variety of reasons.

For example, people who come to bargain as individuals—with an individual employer on one side and an individual employee on the other side—usually find themselves at a disadvantage, and that disadvantage is usually on the employee's side. An equality of bargaining position makes for a better workplace and makes for a better culture in which to go forward as a country. It is for that reason that this legislation is to be debated—as it has been in this chamber—from the point of view that this idea of individualism is not a good idea. Civic leaders, church leaders and other prominent leaders have talked about that.

Oftentimes there is great criticism made of the union movement and the work force. It is worth while understanding that that has been a criticism that has been going on for a long time—for centuries. It is good to know that people have seen the falsehood of anti‐union movements and have seen the falsehood of condemnations of people in the workplace.

Indeed, one person whom I would like to quote who saw that is the wartime Prime Minister in England, Sir Winston Churchill. It is worth while quoting from a speech of his about production on 29 July 1941, when England, of course, was at its most vulnerable. He had this to say:
We are told how badly labour is behaving, and then a lot of people who never did a day's hard work in their lives are out after them.

Sir Winston was saying then—and it is apposite for today—that a lot of criticism is made of the work force. A lot of criticism is made of how Australians go about their industry and that criticism has often come from people who, as Sir Winston says, `Never did a hard day's work in their lives.'
What he had to say about a trade union leader is also interesting. Sir Winston said:

It is the fashion nowadays to abuse the Minister of Labour. He is a workman, a trade union leader. He is taunted with being an unskilled labourer representing an unskilled union. I daresay he gives offence in some quarters; he has his own methods of speech and action. He has a frightful load to carry; he has a job to do which none would envy. He makes mistakes, like I do, though not so many or so serious—he has not got the same opportunities.
In one last quote from the great man, Sir Winston said:
I daresay that some of our critics will not like this kind of talk. They call it complacency. Living in comparative idleness, they wish to lash the toilers of body and mind to further exertions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would he have said about the waterfront?

—Senator McGauran illustrates exactly what Sir Winston was talking about. Senator McGauran says, `What about the waterfront?' Senator McGauran, you are a man of decency, and the problem is what people like you think about the waterfront. I must confess that we have got to say about you what Sir Winston said: living in comparative idleness, you wish to lash the toilers of body and mind to further exertion.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McGauran, you speak on behalf of the government; you are an eminent member of the government. It is of concern to Senator Quirke, Senator Gibbs, Senator Mackay and Senator Denman that you are over there criticising and lashing those people who go around toiling in mind and body and getting criticism that they certainly do not deserve.

The union movement has contributed mightily to this country. May I mention in that context a friend of mine who is about to retire from his position as Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. You would know him of course, Senator Gibbs. I refer to Mr Wally Curran. Mr Curran is an eminent member of the trade union movement and a great man for the arts—he was on the Australia Council. He pioneered a superannuation fund for workers in the meat industry. He is a person of high integrity who has always devoted himself to the interests of his members. He has recently been awarded a medal in the Australian orders—

TALK.START.PARA: —A gong.

—A gong, as you say—and richly deserved. Mr Curran is a person who typifies the sort of thing that a unionist and unions can contribute to the proper working of Australian industry. He is a person who seeks to see fairness done and people properly rewarded. Senator McGauran, no doubt you congratulate him on his very illustrious career in the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech makes the point that the fundamental objective of the act is for the parties to reach agreement without arbitration. If agreements can be reached fairly, if agreements can be reached so that everybody feels that they have had a reasonable deal from the agreement that underpins the work of a person in a workplace, well and good. But the problem is that the proposition that that can happen on an overall basis across the work force is against the history of employment and against the experience that people do have.

Certainly, if a person has great skills, if a person is well equipped with a particular sort of learning that is in demand, then he or she can demand a high price. But even people as highly skilled, as dexterous and as dedicated as our Australian cricketers feel the need to have some agreement between themselves, to have some association that they can go to and put forward propositions that are not only in their interest but also in the interest of the game generally. It is the same for footballers. They have an organisation which was led for a long while by the illustrious Justin Madden from Carlton. He did the same sort of thing.

Our experience is that we do need organisations. We need as leaders of those organisations people who can put forward propositions about how employment should be undertaken and propositions about those things which are not only fair to the employee but also fair to the employer. We must never forget that the employer is part of the transaction. The employer is the person who provides the management, the knowledge and the capital to ensure that the workplace functions properly. The concept that management and employees should work together is a great concept. The issue is not whether that should happen but whether the machinery by which that should happen is well provided for. In this legislation and in these suggested amendments the machinery by which that should happen is not well provided for.

Amendments have been made to the powers of the Employment Advocate. This particular piece of legislation extends the range of people to whom the duties and responsibilities of the Employment Advocate can be delegated. That is of some concern, because the Employment Advocate, within the scheme of the government's legislation, has been given more and more powers and more and more rights. The satisfaction that will or will not be obtained in the workplace depends very much on what the Office of the Employment Advocate does.There is considerable concern about the extension of those powers across the range of people who are concerned with this.

The best way for the employees to do business in the workplace is by having their own representatives, and that is what the union provides. If you look at the Workplace Relations Act itself, you will see that many provisions talk about how representatives of the work force are to be elected. That is properly the situation. The union representatives themselves, the people who represent the workers, are to be elected according to ballots carried out by the Electoral Commission. There are all sorts of laws to make sure that those elections are properly determined and are fair, to make sure that everybody has an opportunity to vote and to make sure that the vote is properly taken into account.

So there is great scope within the union movement for unions to represent workers—as they should be—and to carry out that negotiation with employers, which is so necessary to ensure not only that we have a society that is wealthy through the production of goods and services but, even more than that, that we have a society that is fair. That is what we all want: a society where everybody has their place and where everybody is given their proper dignity as a person; a place where cultural activities can be carried out and where social justice prevails—it is an old, hackneyed phrase but it should be because it is so true.

This bill again changes the Workplace Relations Act, which itself changed the Industrial Relations Act and which, in turn, changed the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The issue of the proper relationship between the workers and managers will always be subject to legislation because it is always changing. It is an organic thing; it is an area where everybody tries to strive for justice and fairness, which is the subject of debate here.

There is a very big difference between the government and the opposition on this matter. While the opposition believes that the best way of achieving that justice and fairness is through a freely elected democratic union movement, the other side says that individual contracts are the way to go. I think history, experience and instinct say that our assessment that there has to be a collection of people in negotiation is right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—To continue, the government's grandstanding ended up costing about $150 million. As a result of its reduced role, the AIRC was forced to wait until the dispute was clearly affecting the public interest before it could act. That dispute, which is essentially about workers wanting to adhere to their rights and existing conditions and about job security, is still unresolved. Over 200 people at the mine have taken voluntary redundancy since then. The matter is regarded as so important by the AIRC that the newly appointed president, Judge Giudice, will hear it himself. I am very pleased to hear that someone is taking this dispute seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I take great exception to the comments by Senator MacGibbon yesterday regarding his views on the culture of mining towns. I had the privilege of visiting the Curragh mine in Blackwater during that dispute, and it was a very peaceful picket. I was impressed by the morale and the fact that they were determined to conduct the strike in accordance with the laws of the land. They did everything by the book.

Most strikes are conducted in this fashion, Senator MacGibbon, and that is why not a lot of media attention is given to them, which was the case at Curragh. When workers are on strike for a long time, they and their families are hurting. If they are provoked by the company and the government, then of course they will react—anybody would and so would you.

The miners enjoyed overwhelming support from the other townsfolk in Blackwater who supported them both financially and emotionally during that strike. In return, those miners worked for the townsfolk doing odd jobs, repairs, painting everything in town that needed painting and things such as that to repay them for their support. The International Park was one of those projects. I do not think I have ever seen Blackwater looking so good.

Comments made yesterday by the government about the freedom of workers to leave their jobs really demonstrates their level of concern for people in outback communities—thank you for sharing that with us! The sense of community displayed by the miners at the Curragh mine towards the townsfolk and vice versa is not something to be ridiculed or belittled. It is admirable and, dare I say it, reflective of the kind of community spirit that John Howard hankers after in the good old days. Mateship is, after all, a traditional Australian value.

The legislation does not provide avenues for what to do next once agreement cannot be reached between management and workers. Given that some of these disputes are occurring in major export markets, I would have thought that the government would have had a vested interest in resolving disputes, not inflaming them and holding workers, their families and other Australians to ransom for the sake of pushing an ideologically driven point.

The Newlands Open Cut mine in Queensland outside Mackay was until recently negotiating an enterprise bargaining agreement—that is, until management spat the dummy and decided to sack their workers instead. The Federal Court issued an interim order only last Friday to prevent these sackings from occurring. I have here a letter from Newlands Coal which is addressed to the CFMEU in Queensland. In this letter, they have the temerity to say:

. . . . as a result of your union's insistence that any retrenchment be undertaken in accordance with Clause 24 of the Production and Engineering Award, we made application for the removal of Clause 24 from the Award as it applies to Newlands Open Cut.

I think it is absolutely bizarre, not to mention unAustralian, for the company to say, in essence, that since the union insists on following the legally binding, mutually agreed provisions of the award, it will seek to have the clause removed. I would also suggest that the independent and objective consultants hired by Newlands Coal—yes, and paid for by them—to assess workers for their suitability or otherwise have been quite rightly regarded by workers and their unions with suspicion.

Proposed changes to repeal section 170LJ(3a) are contrary to the rhetoric of freedom of choice expounded continually by this government. The removal of safeguards such as those which aim to ensure that workers have sufficient time to give informed consent to certified agreements which are up for approval are completely inconsistent with this so‐called freedom. The only freedom the worker will have is the freedom to accept the agreement or the freedom to be unemployed. The government must be thinking how lucky they are to have managed to get their work for the dole legislation enacted. At least workers in that position will have the so‐called freedom to volunteer for that!

For example, what is a new worker supposed to do if a new employer chooses to negotiate a certified agreement just prior to hiring a number of new employees? What kind of real choice are those people going to have? How will you guarantee that they will have sufficient time to understand the proposed agreement so that they are giving informed consent?

The reliance of the Queensland economy on agricultural and mining products, and the demographic dispersion of people in that state, can only increase uncertainty for Queenslanders in regional and rural areas in particular. The increasing Americanisation of our industrial relations system is ironic, not least of all because many employers in the US who have traditionally used contract labour are learning that while there may have been some short‐term gains, in the longer term they lose out.

The aggravation of disputes in small country towns with regional unemployment problems and often, at best, very limited opportunities for economic growth will not help other small businesses in those areas. Actions such as these have a direct and negative impact on workers and their families, and on other workers and their families in small regional economies with few employers or employment prospects. So much for this government's rhetoric of `for all of us'. It is no wonder that there is a growing and vocal backlash from people in the bush about the policies of this government. These people are doing it tough. Worse, they are the very battlers that John Howard claims to represent and who he is not supporting.

The flow‐on effects of job insecurity for workers in these regional economies heralds a grim future for many more people than just those who are unfortunate enough to be directly affected, and who will be affected if this bill is passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all senators who have contributed to this debate on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 . I want to sum up in a little more detail than usual. I think a number of senators have made important points, although there is clearly a very fundamental divide between the coalition and opposition parties. In relation to industrial relations matters generally, in this first of the amending bills to the workplace relations legislation it is important for the record that we set out the important aspects of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to make technical amendments to the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and other legislation. The amendments are aimed at clarifying existing provisions and ensuring that they operate in the manner originally intended by the legislation. The bill also corrects some drafting anomalies and oversights which have led to minor errors.

The proposed amendments have been discussed with both the ACTU and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry through the National Labour Consultative Council's Committee on Industrial Legislation. The bill includes amendments suggested by both the ACTU and the ACCI.

The ACCI has indicated its support for the amendments and, for the most part, the amendments are not opposed by the ACTU. The ACTU certainly agrees that most of the amendments are technical in nature. As to the few amendments that the ACTU says are not technical, we disagree with that view for reasons I will explain shortly.

In addition to the proposed amendments contained in the bill as introduced, the government will be moving a small number of additional amendments. I indicate to the opposition, who have sought an indication about this, that we will ensure those amendments, which are being tidied up a little as we talk, are distributed as soon as possible.

These amendments deal with the disamalgamation provisions and the definition of the term `independent contractor' for the purposes of the freedom of association provisions of the act. The opposition has objected to a number of our proposed amendments. In reality, the opposition's objections to the proposed amendments amount to no more than the fact that they object to the role of the Employment Advocate. That was certainly made clear by the opposition in the debate on the original bill.

The opposition has wrongly claimed that some of the proposed amendments have increased the powers of the Employment Advocate and, as such, the amendments are not technical. In the government's view, this claim misrepresents the nature and intention of the amendments. In relation to the discretion to waive technical defects, one of the amendments would give the Employment Advocate the discretion to waive strict compliance with elements of the filing procedures in circumstances where the Employment Advocate considers that that waiver would not disadvantage a party to an Australian workplace agreement.

In the absence of a power to waive defects, the Employment Advocate has had to return a number of AWAs lodged because the applications failed in some very minor way to meet the filing requirements, such as omitting the employer's Australian company number.

The capacity to waive minor defects is a sensible technical amendment aimed at ensuring the smooth operation of the AWA provisions and eliminating unnecessary delays and procedural burdens. It is a commonsense amendment. It is in keeping with the intention of the AWA scheme—that is, to provide a simple and speedy means of formalising agreements entered into by employers and employees. To suggest that the amendment amounts to an increase in power for the Employment Advocate is absolute nonsense.

The amendment makes clear that the advocate will have to be satisfied that the waiver would not disadvantage a party to the AWA. The amendment will not affect the substantive requirements to be met by an AWA. There will still need to be strict compliance with the substantive requirements such as the provisions relating to the no disadvantage test and genuine consent. The amendment provides only for defects of a technical nature to be waived. This will avoid the waste of time and resources involving correcting minor defects whilst ensuring that the interests of the parties to an AWA are properly protected.

Another proposed amendment extends the time limit for filing an AWA from 14 to 21 days after it is signed. This is a simple, practical change designed to assist AWA parties, especially those in rural centres. It could hardly be described as increasing the Employment Advocate's powers. The bill provides for AWA parties to choose to obtain assistance in explaining the operation of their AWA to the Employment Advocate. This amendment will help AWA parties who have not appointed a bargaining agent or do not wish to utilise the services of a bargaining agent for the purpose of explaining the operation of their AWA to the Employment Advocate. Again, this amendment simply does not amount to an increase in the powers of the Employment Advocate. They are just sensible arrangements to ensure that that office works effectively.

In relation to accountability, the opposition has wrongly asserted that there is a lack of accountability in the AWA process. It has suggested that the advocate should provide written decisions. Where an agreement meets all the relevant statutory requirements, including the no disadvantage test, there is just no point in the advocate wasting time and resources preparing written reasons for decisions. It is just creating unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and unnecessary paperwork.

BREAK.PARA: A requirement to publish decisions would do nothing to improve the operation of the AWA arrangements. It would just simply delay the approval of agreements. Contrary to the claims made by those across the aisle, AWAs are not secret documents. Any party to an AWA is free to disclose the content of his or her AWA to anyone and the act specifically provides that an agreement must not include any provision that prohibits or restricts disclosure of the details of the AWA by either of the parties to that AWA.

The AWA provisions of the act provide extensive protection for employees. These protections are explained in the information statement which employers wishing to enter into AWAs are legally obliged to provide to their employees. This information statement is a detailed booklet prepared by the Office of the Employment Advocate. It explains that, to be approved, an employee must genuinely consent to the agreement and that the agreement must meet the no disadvantage test. The information statement explains how the test operates and provides advice about the appointment and role of bargaining agents. It makes very clear that an employee cannot be dismissed for refusing to sign an AWA.

The Employment Advocate can only approve an AWA if it clearly meets the no disadvantage test. If the Employment Advocate has any unresolved concerns about whether the test is met, the advocate is obliged to refer the agreement to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The AIRC may decide to have particular AWA determinations published if it wishes to do so, and this is a matter for the discretion of the commission. Any determination which is to be published must be edited to ensure that it does not disclose the identity of the AWA parties.

Where any concerns about compliance with the no disadvantage test are resolved by written undertakings given by the employer, those undertakings are deemed to be part of the agreement to which they relate and are therefore enforceable as part of the agreement. The fact that the AWA approval arrangements are streamlined does not mean that the employee protections are compromised. A simple examination of the Workplace Relations Act and the amending bill makes absolutely clear that the opposition's objections are entirely without any foundation.

I now turn to the no disadvantage test. The opposition has also wrongly claimed that our amendment to the no disadvantage test provisions lowers the benchmark for the test. We argue that this claim simply demonstrates a lack of understanding of the amendment on the part of the opposition. Where the no disadvantage test is being applied to an agreement made under the act and the employees concerned are covered by a federal award, then that federal award will form the benchmark for the no disadvantage test. Where the employees concerned are not covered by a federal award, the Employment Advocate in the case of AWAs, and the AIRC in the case of certified agreements, must designate an award to form the benchmark for the no disadvantage test.

It is proposed that a state award may be used as the benchmark only if there is no federal award covering the kind of work performed by the employee or employees to be covered by the proposed agreement. This amendment is necessary because, in some instances, it will not be possible to identify a suitable federal award. The ACTU understands the need for this amendment and does not have any difficulty with it. Unfortunately, the opposition seems to have misunderstood it. I genuinely hope that that explanation makes it clearer to senators opposite.

In relation to termination of employment, the opposition also seems to have misunderstood the proposed amendments to the provisions dealing with the application of state laws in relation to the termination of employment of an employee covered by federal awards or agreements. The Workplace Relations Act ensures that federal award or agreement employees who are, for constitutional reasons, outside the scope of the federal unfair dismissal remedies are not deprived of access to a state unfair dismissal remedy. The amendments will not affect access to state unfair dismissal remedies. What the amendments do is simply make clear that the existing provisions do not give federal employees access to entitlements under other state laws or awards dealing with termination of employment.

In relation to freedom of association, the opposition wants to retain the right to include void preference clauses in agreements and awards. Such clauses contravene the freedom of association provisions of the act and are completely unenforceable. The inclusion of these void clauses amounts to an exercise in futility, but, more importantly, the opposition is apparently unconcerned about the risk of employers and employees mistakenly taking these void clauses at face value. This could result in employees being disadvantaged and employers inadvertently being in breach of the act.

Could I quickly summarise. The minor changes we are proposing within this amending bill will assist in giving effect to the major reforms which have been achieved through the enactment of the Workplace Relations Act. The act is delivering genuine flexibility and choice for employers and employees at the workplace level. Nearly 4,000 new agreements have been certified since the act came into operation, including about 140 agreements made directly between employers and employees. In addition, over 2,000 AWAs have been approved by the Employment Advocate.

We now have an act that is much better balanced than its predecessors. It reinforces a stronger sense of the rights and responsibilities of all participants in the system. Section 127 of the act is providing an effective remedy to prevent and stop illegitimate industrial action. Over 160 applications for section 127 orders have been dealt with by the commission to date. This bill is designed to clarify certain provisions of the act and ensure that it operates as intended. I commend the bill to the Senate.

That the amendment (Senator Mackay's ) be agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak on the 1996‐97 annual report of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, including the Auditor‐General's report on section 4(1) of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Act 1989. I speak to this tonight because of the announcements made in the last budget. One of the most regressive elements in the 1997 education budget was the slashing of nearly $40 million from Abstudy over four years. If there is any chance of reversing or changing this decision then it is important to speak up. I believe that this situation is currently being reviewed. I would like to believe that this is so. I was at Senate estimates when questions were asked of Senator Vanstone—the minister at the time—and there was an indication that there really was not much idea of what the impacts of such a move were going to be.

The predecessor to Abstudy was established in 1969. Apparently there are now around 43,900 Abstudy recipients in both secondary and tertiary education. Abstudy differs in a number of ways to Austudy. It grants additional benefits to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students in recognition of the social and, therefore, educational disadvantage faced by indigenous Australians. For example, the benefits are higher. This government has done a lot without recognising why such schemes were implemented in the first place.

The statistics show that only 33 per cent of indigenous Australians complete secondary education compared with 76 per cent of the rest of the population. Twenty‐five per cent of indigenous Australians do not complete year 10 while this is the case for only two per cent of the non‐indigenous population. It is important to note that participation rates have improved steadily at the rate of 20 to 50 per cent between 1991 and 1995, admittedly starting from a low base. That low base has allowed those figures to show a speedy improvement. In the late 1960s when the Aboriginal study grants scheme was introduced there were only two indigenous students in Australian universities. This year there were nearly 7,000. It is important to emphasise this point because the current policy is at least partially effective in improving the situation in this area.

The cuts of about $38.7 million, or about eight per cent, to Abstudy over the four years are made up of many relatively small changes which have all had the effect of abolishing or reducing benefits. These changes include reductions in course approvals, abatement rates, the number of undergraduate and postgraduate courses that are able to be undertaken, eligibilities and awards, school fees, allowances and travel assistance. Travel assistance has been extremely important—and that includes away from base assistance where it is proposed that a limit of two return trips per year be introduced for travel related to minor essential elements of a course such as field trips and residential schools. DEETYA has estimated that 550 students will be affected by this measure and they have cut, they say, $1.65 million from the budget. I believe the figure might be quite a lot higher than that. It also includes cuts to the incidental allowance.

The government, as I mentioned, has announced a review of Abstudy in the context of other student assistance programs such as the proposed common youth allowance. Given that Abstudy recognises the educational disadvantage of indigenous Australians—and is thus a more livable allowance that those to which it will be compared—the review is extremely concerning. It may also be another example of this government announcing significant change and subsequently undertaking a review of the area. This is not the way to go. If you are going to have a concerned and thoughtful approach to education and if this is, in fact, about efficiency—and I believe that it is not; I believe it is about scapegoat politics—then you do the review first and do the cuts later. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Wool International is a statutory body established by the Commonwealth under the Wool International Act 1993. It began its operations in December 1993, replacing the former Australian Wool Realisation Commission. Its key responsibilities are the management and sale of the stockpile and the repayment of the commercially funded and government guaranteed debt.

In 1991, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission was set up by the previous government to sell the stockpile and, of course, reduce the debt which at that stage was $2.8 billion, largely government guaranteed, and 4.5 million bales. The previous government set up the realisation commission with the priority to reduce the debt and to reduce the stockpile. For the first two or three years, the reduction of the debt was the pre-eminent reason for its existence. In fact, it did quite a good job in difficult circumstances, but it had the effect of pushing the price down to such a low level that the wool industry looked like it was not going to survive.

In 1993, Wool International was set up. Its priority, of course, was to reduce the debt but it was also to reduce the stockpile, and it did so by selling a set number of bales per quarter. In the intervening years, between 1993 and 1997, the stockpile has been reduced substantially. At the end of June, it was at 1.7 million bales and it is now down to about 1.45 million bales, and the equity in the stockpile is now worth quite a lot of money—in fact, about $850 million.

So we are now in a position where Wool International's priority is no longer to reduce the debt. It is basically to manage the sell down of the remaining 1.45 million bales in the stockpile and to return the capital to the stockholders, those woolgrowers who have stuck with producing wool over the last four years. This is the reason for its existence now. The legislation was changed earlier this year which allowed for the amendments which specified that from 1 January 1997 the maximum quarterly delivery of stockpile will be raised from 192,000 bales a quarter to 350,000 bales a quarter and the minimum reduced from 182,000 bales a quarter to 135,000 bales a quarter, and this quarterly minimum was further reduced to 90,000 bales from 1 July 1997.

We are now in a position where we will shortly be able to provide some very good news to woolgrowers because the first tranche of money that can be repaid by Wool International, which is the first repayment—around $84 million, which is approximately 24c for every dollar of wool tax paid—will be paid out in early November. The question the government has to face, and it is of very great interest to woolgrowers, is the treatment for tax purposes of this first tranche of repayments. Woolgrowers hope it will be within the rollover provisions of capital gains tax changes which have been set in place to help small business. If that is the case, it will be treated as exempt if it is put into capital assets of the farming operation.

Treasury has yet to give that advice, but I can assure all woolgrowers out there that I will be pushing very hard the Treasury, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) to make sure that this hard won contribution which will be coming back to wool growers in early November will be treated as exempt from capital gains tax. It can then be put into the operating capital in assets of operators who have found it very difficult over the last few years to increase their operating profits.

The wool industry is still going through very difficult times. Wool International continues to be comfortable with its forward sale position, and the stockpile is about 1.4 million bales, but the eastern market indicator has not moved as encouragingly as it might have. It is still hovering at about the 700c mark, which for many wool growers, especially specialist wool growers, is not profitable. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend what my National Party colleague from New South Wales, Senator Sandy Macdonald, has said. I am merely following up what he has said. He comes into this chamber with a wealth of valuable experience in the industry and he has been a fine representative of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to address the Wool International annual report of 1996‐97. It is worth going back some seven years to the gestation period of Wool International. It was a time when the previous government had put in place a chain reaction that decimated the industry. It started a very long seven years of misery for the industry and for individual and family farmers. Without going into the machinations, which are well known to the industry and to individuals and families, I will simply make some points.

There was mismanagement of the floor price scheme which saw its eventual collapse and abolishment. This created a downward spiral of the commodity price where, at certain times, the eastern market indicator was less that 400c per kilogram. The market indicator was very much like that because of a government that created anxiety and uncertainty in the marketplace where it did not have to.

Remember also that the early 1990s coincided with a manufactured recession in which interest rates were deliberately ratcheted up. The industry could always protect itself against a drought or, for that matter, a commodity price collapse, but it could not protect itself against interest rates of 25 per cent, added to a commodity price collapse. If I remember rightly, there was not a declared drought at that time, but there was certainly uncertainty about the weather. With those three forces upon it, the industry got off to a very bad start in the 1990s.

With this backdrop, the result was a $4.5 billion stockpile of bales overhanging the industry and the marketplace, and some $3 billion in debt. It was a time of great anxiety and uncertainty in the industry. It was in this atmosphere that, in 1993, Wool International was created to manage the sell‐down of the stockpile and to reduce the debt.

BREAK.PARA: This was Wool International's singular mission. As it said in its first report of 1993‐94, it was given a fixed sales schedule, starting from 1 July 1994, under which 187,000 bales per quarter were to be sold. Under very strong pressure from the industry and some commonsense, this fixed sales schedule was changed in January 1997 to a far more flexible method of sale, whereby the quarterly minimum sale of bales was reduced to some 90,000.

The 1996‐97 report that we are discussing today says at page 7 that this decision recognised the process to date in selling the stockpile, the more manageable debt level and the difficult financial circumstances of many wool growers. Indeed, the time had come to change the management of the stockpile to a far more flexible sale price.

The report also said that the federal parliament approved additional conditions that set a target of repayment of the debt by 31 December 1998, and stipulated that the stockpile must be sold and the last bale delivered on or before 31 December 2000. The good news is, as my colleague said, from the disastrous position in 1990, with the overhang of the stockpile, we can now fast‐forward to 1997 where that stockpile is an asset and some $84 million is the first dividend to be paid to farmers. It is good news, and hundreds of millions of dollars more are to be paid from that stockpile dividend.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Honourable senators will realise that this is a report which I have been watching keenly over the last few years. I have also been watching with interest reports from the Auditor‐General in relation to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. As with most of these reports, I will appreciate the opportunity to read it in more depth, but I would now like to note a few items that have appeared in this year's report.

One of those items is the report on fatigue, stress and occupational health. There have been many speeches given in this parliament about the issues of crewing levels. It appears that a research team analysed the responses of the study and presented a draft report to the Study Steering Committee in May 1997. The final report will be formally handed to AMSA in the near future, following steering committee approval. I hope that we will have access to that report to see what the implications are for fatigue, stress and occupational health at a time when there have been a number of changes to the crewing levels on ships, especially ships in Australian waters.
I would also like to point out that the report refers to ships carrying livestock. This is mentioned on page 40 of the report. It states:
Review of the regulation of livestock ships :
Two livestock ships were lost in 1996 after loading at Australian ports. The first, Uniceb —
which has been debated in this chamber—

caught fire while carrying a cargo of live sheep to the Middle East, and a crewman died. The second, Guernsey Express, carrying a cargo of cattle, sank with no loss of human life after encountering heavy weather associated with a cyclone on a voyage to Japan.
It is a pity the report did not mention the number of livestock which drowned in those voyages. The report goes on to say:

On page 41, there is also mention of port state control inspections. The report states:

Obviously that is going to be very important if people are thinking that there might be certain ports in Australia where they might be subject to less scrutiny than others. It is very important that we know what that situation is.

I am sure that as I read through this report I will find many other areas. I will be looking forward to any comments that the Auditor- General might be able to make at some later stage as to how AMSA is going with its safety issues in Australian ports. I am always interested in the ongoing improvement of safety in Australian waters. Unfortunately, it is not always the case that we are going in the right direction. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of government documents has expired. I propose the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to speak on federal road funding and on the road that links Melbourne and Geelong, the Princes Highway west—a road that links two of Australia's biggest cities. I want to speak as a Victorian senator about a critical issue facing the state. I promised when I became a senator that I would represent the interests of the people of Victoria, and tonight I intend to focus on an issue primarily affecting the people living in the corridor between Melbourne and Geelong.

SPEECH.PARA: The city of Geelong and its region has a long and proud history. In 1824 the explorers Hume and Hovell travelled overland to the western shore of Corio, where Geelong now stands. Thirty-three years later, in 1857, the railway between Geelong and Williamstown opened, and two years later this was extended to Melbourne. The Geelong to Ballarat line opened in 1862.

Geelong flourished in the 1850s as a port of entry for gold prospectors and, before the turn of the century, the port had become a major trading hub for the export of wool to Britain. The port remains a great asset to the city today and has now grown to be Victoria's largest bulk port, exporting wheat and grains, wool and other primary produce.

Geelong has, in the past, always enjoyed an impressive transport network, but Geelong has suffered badly too. In the 1980s, under the Cain-Kirner Labor governments, Geelong watched as industry failed, the Pyramid Building Society collapsed and the town experienced the decimation of jobs and pride—a decimation for which Labor governments became well known. These experiences gravely wounded Geelong.

Geelong is now getting back on its feet. I am glad to say that Geelong has revived as a centre for industry and transport. Distribution centres have reappeared, transport terminals have been established and the warehouses and cool stores so necessary for trade have reopened. Pride is now returning to Geelong, and it is again taking its proper place in the Victorian economy.

One of Geelong's great historical strengths—its transport links—continue. The port of Geelong, the Avalon airport, the national standard gauge railway and the transport terminals all contribute to an impressive transport network, but the roads servicing Geelong are not so impressive, particularly the Princes Highway west. Before elaborating on the problems of that highway, I want to record my sincere disappointment in the lack of action on this issue by the member for Corio. The Princes Highway passes through his electorate, and this forms the main link between his electorate, the produce rich western districts and the city of Melbourne.

Some 40,000 vehicles travel every day between Geelong and Melbourne and more than double that between Werribee and Melbourne. But does the good member Mr O'Connor raise the problems of that road in the other place? Does he show his concern for the residents in his electorate by seeking a better road which will contribute to the greater economic growth of the area? He does not. In fact, he shows remarkably little interest in this very major issue. The member for Corio even goes so far as to term the road `one of the region's quality transport assets'—something it is not.

We cannot really just blame the member for Corio for this sad neglect of the interests of Geelong residents. After all, Mr O'Connor is merely reflecting a long-term Labor neglect of the Princes Highway west, of Geelong residents and of all Victorians who use that road for economic and personal reasons. It was the Labor Party which sold the Geelong road and Geelong down the drain when it restricted road funding. The ALP restricted direct federal road funding to the national highway and this is why the Geelong road and all its users are suffering. It was, of course, the Labor Party which diverted $750 million of road funds to upgrade the Pacific Highway. Strangely, it did this just before an election. But the road did run through a couple of very sensitive marginal seats!

The coalition, on the other hand, have a very good record on roads. After all, we are the ones who reintroduced black spot funding when we returned to government. The Labor Party had cut it out after the 1993 election. Black spot funding directly contributes to saving lives in the community. The coalition have reintroduced this funding and it is the coalition who have chosen to consult for the first time with the community regarding the use of this funding. It has also been the coalition who have recognised the importance of the Calder Highway and made it a four-way standard to Bendigo and the national standard to Mildura. The coalition have recognised and acted on the need to substantially increase national road funding.

The Geelong road is not an asset; it is a very dangerous road, made so by the general neglect of infrastructure by the last Labor government. Make no mistake, the road is dangerous. It averages more than one death every 10 kilometres every year. There are 2.5 casualties per kilometre per year and over 100 casualty accidents seriously injuring 180 people per year. Yet it is only 64 kilometres long. So why has it not received better funding? The economic links and benefits of the road are undisputed. It links Geelong and its many associated industries with the port of Geelong, with Werribee, with Melbourne and with the various industries there. In terms of trade alone, nearly 40 per cent of Australia's exports flow through the two ports of Geelong and Melbourne, both serviced by the Princes Highway west and the Westgate freeway, roads which need upgrading.

The economic links are also evident in freight movement along the highway. Freight is moved from Geelong to markets in Melbourne, interstate and overseas. Last year nearly six million tonnes of long distance freight was moved on the Princes Highway and Westgate freeway between Geelong and Melbourne—and, as I have said, the port of Geelong is Victoria's largest bulk shipping port. The area is a transport and distribution hub for many companies and the infrastructure supporting the subsequent freight movements is vital to Australia's trading position and to our future economic growth.

The benefits of upgrading this road are obvious and indisputable. Not only could many accidents be avoided but the National Institute of Economic Industry Research in 1995 also reported the following benefits of upgrading the Princes Highway west: an impact on national GDP of $800 million, four times the investment required, a benefit to cost ratio of four to one; a result in Commonwealth revenue of 32 per cent of the increase in GDP, $256 million; a result in permanent job growth of 4,500 people; and a reduction in freight costs. We all know that the cost of inadequate roads in manufacturing and port areas affects all Australians in higher prices, lost export earnings, decreased business efficiency and, ultimately, jobs.

I am a proud Victorian and I want to help Victorians by having better and safer roads and through having more and better industry and more jobs. Improving the Princes Highway west, helping industry and employment, is a good place to start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Today this parliament witnessed yet another peaceful demonstration against the government's abhorrent treatment of Aboriginal Australia. It was a moving gesture and one which symbolises the ground swell of community support for reconciliation. I want to mention these very public displays of frustration at the current government because they symbolise the dedication and commitment of many Australians who are sick and tired of the punitive approach to Aboriginal affairs by the Liberal government.

SPEECH.PARA: In Canberra today, 100 concerned citizens, lecturers and students attended a demonstra tion relating to cuts to Abstudy. I am told that a second protest will be occurring tomorrow. These protests are a direct response to the cuts to Abstudy announced in the last budget. I wish to draw this chamber's attention to the impact of changes to Abstudy proposed by this government. These changes demonstrate yet again that this government has deliberately and unfairly targeted the Aboriginal community. Aboriginal people face unique obstacles in accessing and participating in higher education, but this government is not interested in assisting Aboriginal education. In fact, it is not interested in assisting anyone's education; it is just interested in cutting expenditure, regardless of the social costs.

The last budget cut almost $40 million from Abstudy benefits. This mean-spirited approach to Aboriginal education follows a $400 million cut to ATSIC funding. Aboriginal education should be a priority for this government and it is its duty to appreciate and understand the difficulties and obstacles faced by Aborigines living in remote and rural communities. If this government recognises the special needs of indigenous students, as Senator Vanstone claimed when she was minister, then its response is a damning indictment of this government's attitude. This government has limited the number of courses for which assistance is provided and changed the additional incidentals allowance, away from base assistance, compassionate travel and graduation travel entitlements. This is not the type of recognition that Aboriginal students need.

I want to draw the Senate's attention to the devastating and harmful effects that one of the government's proposed changes will have on Aboriginal students. I would like to refer to away from base assistance. Sydney's Macquarie University currently offers a diploma in community management for Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people who have shown appropriate communication skills and who are working in Aboriginal communities.

Macquarie's diploma course has enrolments from Aboriginal students from all over the country. Only Curtin University in Western Australia offers a similar diploma course. This course provides basic pre-tertiary education that aims to help indigenous people overcome historical disadvantages. The diploma course teaches Aborigines how to locate and use information, how to write submissions, how to formulate and manage financial matters and how to deal with management and legal dilemmas. Recently, accountancy and land and resource management units were added to the course.

The Macquarie course is designed to allow working indigenous people access to study. Students come to Macquarie four times a year for a period of two weeks under a provision known as block release. They complete 18 separate units of study for which they earn enough credit points to enter into general university courses. In other words, here is a scheme that assists indigenous people in gaining skills and qualifications that are then used to benefit their communities or organisations. There are over 80 students enrolled in this three-year course.

This diploma course has already produced health service and management graduates as well as teachers and administrators. In the last three years, 14 students have been accepted into postgraduate or undergraduate courses. Five Aboriginal diploma graduates are now enrolled in masters degrees, while four are studying commercial law. None have dropped out.

This course has facilitated the education of Aborigines in the very management skills that they need to control their own affairs and finances. It will help overcome the unsubstantiated accusations of financial mismanagement that this government alleges are rife within Aboriginal administration. These changes to Abstudy are nothing more than miserly and penny‐pinching.

Changing the away from basis assistance means that Aboriginal students will not be able to gain sufficient credit points to enter other university courses. In other words, the whole aim of the diploma course will be negated. It gets worse. A proposed three-year bachelor teaching degree focussing on early childhood education may no longer proceed because it too uses a block release scheme that enables Aboriginal students to attend practical placements.

Changes to Abstudy will prevent Aboriginal students from studying in courses that are comprised wholly or substantially of away from base components, such as residential schools and field trips. This will preclude many indigenous students from studying at Macquarie University. It may mean that 78 currently enrolled students will not be able to proceed with their education.

What is the message here? That you can live in your own community but the government will not assist you in getting an education because they are too stingy to assist with travel and accommodation for people who historically have very low higher education participation rates. No-one can deny those statistics. On the one hand, Senator Herron berates Aborigines for not properly controlling their own affairs while, on the other hand, Minister Kemp seeks to deny them access to the very courses that are designed to achieve that goal.

Unlike budget changes to HECS under which continuing students are not affected, Aboriginal students will be forced to withdraw from a program designed to benefit all of Australia. Without continuing students, Macquarie University may have to close down its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs unit, forcing even more Australians out of work.

We are not talking about a great deal of money in a budgetary context. Approximately $278,000 will allow 90 indigenous students to complete a diploma in community management. Even a government that is driven by economic rationalism would have to acknowledge the enormous benefit that such a small amount of money provides. Remember, we are talking about a specially designed management course for Aborigines, a course that will benefit the entire nation.

I understand that Senator Vanstone, prior to being demoted, had confirmed to the National Tertiary Education Union that Abstudy changes were under review as the government had underestimated the impact they would have on Aboriginal students. I trust that the new Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) will reaffirm that Abstudy changes are not fair or equitable. I trust that the Minister Kemp will support Senator Vanstone's declarations that Abstudy changes are not in the best interests of Aboriginal students.

I also understand that the former minister had offered deals with individual universities to assist them with the away from base scheme for just one year. In other words, in a cynical attempt to hose down yet another racially divisive issue, this government is quietly saying to those universities with indigenous programs, `Here, we'll help you out in the short term but our aim is still to attack educational schemes aimed at assisting those most disadvantaged.'

These courses were established specifically to overcome the lack of skills and education Aboriginal people are perceived not to have. They are designed to increase the number of professional managers in Aboriginal communities across Australia. Cutting the away from base allowance can only be described as an attack on Aboriginal education. This decision must be reversed. I urge those who are taking the time to express their dissatisfaction with this government to persist. Your message is a critical one and the government must be made not just to hear it but to act on it and resolve these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past few weeks I have been a member of the committee that has been reviewing the amendments to the Native Title Act. We have been looking at amendments which will make the act more workable, and we have taken evidence from dozens of groups all around Australia. There is general agreement that the act needs reworking. It needs amending to make it more workable.

SPEECH.PARA: The 10‐point plan follows a commitment made by the coalition during the lead‐up to the election to simplify the Native Title Act whilst respecting and accepting native title itself. The amendments reflect hours of consultation by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his advisers as well as discussions with a number of the major groups affected by the changes: Aboriginals, farmers, miners and the resource development indus tries. The experiences that they have related to the committee have reinforced the urgency of the need for amendment.

Tonight, I would like to tell the Senate of the experience of one pastoral family in a remote area in Far North Queensland. The experience of this family was related to the committee during its hearing in Cairns. Alan and Karen Pedersen of Karma Waters Station purchased the grazing land that they now occupy in February 1991—well before Mabo and well before Wik. Two years later, when they submitted a three‐year management plan, they were told that native title or any residual native title that may exist on their property would need to be extinguished prior to any tenure upgrade.

A non‐claimant application by them resulted in a claim in May 1995 by a group of people known as the Sunset Yalangi people. The Pedersens subsequently drove 200 kilometres down to Cairns to attend a pre‐mediation meeting convened by the President of the National Native Title Tribunal, Mr Justice French, the claimants themselves, the Cape York and North Queensland land councils and representatives of two Queensland government departments.

Although the claimants were given two months to prove their traditional claims, the Pedersens spoke to the claimants after the meeting and agreed, in principle, to their request for access to significant sites and areas of cultural importance on the property. Imagine their surprise when only a couple of days later, the North Queensland Land Council advised them that they—the North Queensland Land Council—wanted exclusive rights to the land and the right to occupy and manage the land!

In mid‐June, four of the Sunset Yalangi elders of the claimant group and a land council representative came to the property and, after discussions, it appeared that there was sufficient common ground to negotiate an agreement with the claimant group. One month later, the claimants had amended their claim to omit any claim to exclusive rights to the property. It seemed that commonsense and the desires of the claimant group—and, in particular, the desires of the elders of the group—were actually going to prevail.

Then, in July, five Queensland government bureaucrats came to the property to spend three days inspecting dams, fences, waterholes and pastures. Five weeks later, more Queensland bureaucrats came for another three days to look at some old mine sites and some other improvements. The Pedersens were becoming cautiously optimistic—maybe the Native Title Act was workable. Another month went by and the land council and two claimants returned and it seemed that commonsense would indeed prevail.

Then, on 11 and 12 September, a formal National Native Title Tribunal mediation took place with Justice Robert French, a tribunal vice‐president, a case manager, a Perth‐based land council barrister, another solicitor, two Queensland bureaucrats and 50 members of the claimant group. A heads of agreement was set down with more detail to be added later. The Pedersens thought they were getting somewhere—that the Native Title Act was working.

In November, the land council sent an anthropologist to spend a week at the property. A week or so later, the Pedersens again drove south to look at the agreement and left believing they had the support of the claimant elders. Two days later, at yet another mediation meeting, the Native Title Tribunal representative and the claimant's Perth based barrister—he was back in Cairns—pressed the Pedersens to hand over the right to occupy the land with a non-renewable lease for the family, a proposition which, not unusually and probably not surprisingly, the Pedersens refused. Their offer was then withdrawn. By now, they had spent $13,000, without their legal expenses, and they had received $4,800 in legal aid from the federal government. A sense of despair was starting to descend on this family and a sense of farce was taking over.

In June last year, yet another mediation took place and listen to who was there—Justice French, a tribunal case manager, three bureaucrats, seven members of the North Queensland Land Council, two members of the Cape York Land Council, 10 claimants, some miners and some shire representatives. Almost 30 people were there, along with the increasingly confused and despondent Pedersen family. The North Queensland Land Council's proposal required the Pedersens to surrender their lease to the claimants, who would then lease it back to the family on terms which were totally unacceptable to both the Pedersens and the Queensland government.

In October last year, the matter was referred to the Federal Court, and two directions hearings have already been held. The Pedersens are now seeking further legal aid for the Queen's Counsel, the barrister and the anthropologist they will require, and they have been told the case could cost more than $2 million.

For the past three years, this family on a remote Queensland pastoral property have endured endless inspections, meetings, legal briefings and mediations, with people they have never met roaming all over their property inspecting this, that and everything else. They now face the Federal Court to confront, as adversaries, the very claimant people they agreed could have what they asked for back in 1995. What a farce! No wonder nearly $90 million has been spent on native title claims so far with only one agreed small settlement. And no wonder the wealth‐generating industries of this nation have become angry and frustrated at the current, clearly unworkable Native Title Act.

BREAK.PARA: The Pedersens and hundreds and thousands of other families in this country—pastoral families like them on remote country stations all over the country—deserve better. So do the Sunset Yalangi people, who, three years ago, with no acrimony could have had the access they wanted to Karma Waters Station.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September this year, the Commissioner of Taxation, Michael Carmody, in a speech at the CEDA conference in Adelaide, raised the issue of the taxing of trusts on the same basis as companies. This is an issue that the tax reform committees from the Treasury and the coalition will also be examining as part of the tax reform process. The question is: should income receive the same tax treatment, irrespective of the vehicle that is used in deriving it? Mr Carmody suggests that, since `trusts have increasingly been simply an attractive business structure,' the ATO believes `it is perfectly valid to raise for consideration what should be the appropriate treatment for tax purposes.'

SPEECH.PARA: The two examples that he gives are, indeed, good ones. Firstly, when company dividends are paid out of profits that are subject to building allowances or accelerated depreciation, they are taxable in the hands of the individual shareholder, whereas distributions from a discretionary trust are tax free. Secondly, a similar result is achieved when a distribution by a company is received through the revaluation of an asset, compared with the distribution of a trust from the same type of revaluation.

I hope that there is more than just a simplistic change if we are going to treat trusts as companies. Therefore, I do hope the tax reform groups will look at other issues of taxation, including the changes to the capital gains tax. For example, there may necessarily be changes to the question of the reduction of the cost base of the underlying asset.

A second consideration before automatically accepting change or taxing trusts as companies is to compare the efficiency of each vehicle. In other words, the various reform committees should examine the possibilities of improving the dividend and imputation system should trusts be taxed as companies.

A third consideration is what impacts such change would have on collective investments which are structured as trusts. A fourth consideration is that these two committees should examine the alternative flow‐through methods that are available in other jurisdictions, such as the United States, which allow shareholders of some companies to be taxed ahead of the company. The fifth consideration is that a so‐called deeming approach without extensive legislative backup is fraught with potential difficulties and legal problems.

Finally, coming back to Mr Carmody's speech as Commissioner of Taxation, I would have thought that he and his department would have direct representation on at least the Treasury committee. So I ask the question: what was his motive in raising the trust issue at the CEDA forum in Adelaide? If it was to open up the public debate, the contribution is, indeed, welcome so as to bring forth responses such as mine tonight in this chamber. There was a somewhat similar approach by the Taxpayers Association in their recent journal, No. 7 of 29 September 1997, and hopefully we might get other approaches from the tax professionals.

On the other hand, if Mr Carmody feels excluded from the reform process, then that is a more serious issue which I believe should be raised during the Senate‐Treasury ATO estimates hearing. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —In the other place today, the member for Calare (Mr Andren) made an extraordinary claim. I take particular exception to it. Firstly, I take exception because I have been misrepresented and, secondly, I take exception to being criticised by somebody like Mr Andren who does so little research into the matters on which he speaks that he is quite patently and absolutely ignorant. Mr Andren said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Wik case, Senator Bill O'Chee and others have been peddling the myth that native title tenure is the same as freehold title when, if they bothered to look, the courts have repeatedly stated this is not the case.

Anybody would understand that native title, if it coexists with a leasehold tenure of land, cannot be the same as freehold. It is quite clearly the case—they are inconsistent tenures. It shows that Mr Andren does not bother doing his research. It shows that Mr Andren really is not interested in getting to the facts of the debate.

But I will point out what I have said before: that there are Aboriginal activists, for example, Father Frank Brennan, who will tell you that when a leasehold tenure expires—because they say that native title is permanent and a leasehold tenure is only temporary—at that point in time native title revives in full and, in its fullest form, it should be treated as a freehold tenure and should prevent the renewal of a leasehold interest.

There are those on the other side of the chamber who will disagree with my views on native title, but it was very clearly intended when the original legislation was passed that such claims would be prevented. Of course, they have not been prevented and, in fact, people like Father Frank Brennan have made that claim a number of times. Father Frank Brennan made that claim to me here in Parliament House when we addressed a group of young school students earlier on this year. Father Frank Brennan has made that claim in a number of public places. That is why the legislation which the coalition brings forward in the other place contains provisions which prevent native title preventing the renewal of a lease. That is what we seek to do.

Mr Andren obviously does not bother to look at the facts, obviously does not bother to acquaint himself with what I have had to say and obviously has only a very vague interest or understanding of what native title is really about. If he understood what native title is about, then he would understand that this legislation is of great significance.

I have not seen the whole of Mr Andren's speech but, from the extract I have seen, it seems that Mr Andren is rather critical of the coalition's point of view. If that is the case, then it is important that the rural constituents in his electorate understand that his equivocation, his negative point of view, on this legislation—because he seems to think that this legislation goes too far—means that he is basically holding their title out to risk.

This legislation is designed to remedy not just the people who have leasehold title to agricultural properties but also many different cases. For example, you can have town commons which are subject to claim. Whilst it is perfectly reasonable to have a claim on a town common, it is unreasonable to let that claim preclude development on that particular town common. Anybody living in a small rural town with a town common which is in Mr Andren's electorate of Calare should now know that Mr Andren not only fails to under stand native title but also, by his equivocation, is putting the development of those rural towns at risk.

It is about time that Mr Andren started to look at the facts and to look at what is really going on in Australia. Maybe he ought to equate himself with what we have said in North Queensland. I commend to all honourable senators and I commend to Mr Andren the learned and eloquent speech we have heard tonight from Senator Ferris.

By his comments, Mr Andren seems to think that our amendment legislation goes too far. I would say to him that he should speak to the constituents of mine who have appeared before the committee of which Senator Ferris is a member. Mr Andren has not bothered to acquaint himself with any of the evidence which has been presented to the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Obviously, that is too much hard work for Mr Andren. He just wants to flit around these issues; he does not really want to do the hard yakka.

Mr Andren is more interested in getting his face on television than in making a serious contribution to the governance of this country. That is a great tragedy for the people of his electorate, because I believe they elected him expecting a little bit more. There was a lot of rhetoric from Mr Andren at the time, but there has been no substance to back that rhetoric up.

It is about time that Mr Andren apologised to me; it is also about time that Mr Andren apologised to his constituents, because his blatant and utter ignorance of these issues means that he is incapable of exercising a proper vote and incapable of representing them. Therefore, I believe his constituents should give serious consideration to replacing him at the next election with a candidate from the National Party who can represent their interests.
