QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 8 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 698 (Official Senate Hansard , 27 August 1997, p.5885):

(1) Why exactly does Telstra consider that commercial relationships with global and domestic private sector companies which accepted invitations as guests of Telstra at the 1996 Atlanta Olympic Games would be "sensitive" to having personal details disclosed.
(2) Does the naming of individuals involved constitute "personal details".
(3) Will Telstra provide the names of the companies which employ those ten beneficiaries of the visit to Atlanta.
(4) What is the value of equipment and/or services purchased from Telstra by each of those companies represented by the above‐mentioned ten guests over the past 2 years.
(5) What guidelines and procedures does Telstra have in place to prevent corrupt practices in relation to personal favours given in return for business dealings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer, based on advice from Telstra, to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telstra has indicated that it considers it to be a common business practice for the provision of services to customers and the nature of their business relationship with their service provider remain confidential to the customer and service provider. Telstra also considers that it would breach the confidence and trust of the customer's relationship with Telstra where every customer that Telstra attempts to build a business relationship with is expected to disclose the detail of those dealings to Parliament. Telstra further considers that to make such disclosures would seriously undermine Telstra's or any other company's ability to conduct business.

These standard business practices are reinforced by Part 13 of the Telecommunications Act 1997, which deals with the protection of communications. Under Part 13, carriers and carriage service providers are prohibited, except in certain limited circumstances, from disclosing personal information about customers.
(2) Yes.
(3) See answer to question (1).
(4) See answer to question (1).

(5) Telstra advises that it has an employee Code of Conduct which sets guidelines for the expected behaviour of employees in their dealings with customers and suppliers. The Code of Conduct deals with issues such as dealing with suppliers of goods and services, customer services and general principles for the provision and acceptance of gifts, prizes and hospitality.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 19 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 627 (Official Senate Hansard , 25 August 1997, pg 5647), which indicated that the completion of the Box Ironbark Special Investigation (descriptive report) was a priority fo the Victorian Government:
(1) Has the report been completed; if not: (a) why has there been a delay; and (b) when is it expected to be completed.
(2) What is the current status of the west region Regional Forest Agreement for Western Victoria.
(3) Will the west region Regional Forest Agreement guarantee the preservation of 15 per cent of the pre‐European Box/Ironbark forests in Victoria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The completion of the report is dependent on the development, by the Victorian Government, of new terms of reference for the Special Investigation that are consistent with the provisions of the Victorian Environment Conservation Council Act 1997.
(b) The timing of the completion of the Special Investigation Descriptive Report is a Victorian State matter.

(2) Vegetation and old growth mapping projects and cultural heritage assessments are currently underway in the West region. Fauna surveys and community heritage projects are scheduled to commence shortly. The West region Regional Forest Agreement is scheduled to be signed in late 1999.

(3) In accordance with the nationally agreed reserve criteria, the aim of both Governments will be to ensure that 15 per cent of the pre‐1750 distribution of each forest ecosystem represented in the West region, including Box/Ironbark forests, is protected in the Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative reserve system with flexibility considerations applied if necessary, according to regional circumstances.
